content:
Posted: March 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								I am not going to review the game itself, as it's far too early for this, but I'm going to review how the "Early Access" of this game is being handled.It clearly states on Early Acces that you can get involved with this game as it develops. This couldn't be further from the truth. Every major decision is already set in stone, pretermined by polls from early backers. There is pretty much no Developer interaction - the only known Developer admin is hardly posting at all on either the Steam or the official forum. There is no dialogue about future game mechanic changes. Giant threads of people remarkably unhappy about design decisions made in the past being broken (such as pirates not being a nation like the other 7 but very different from them) are just growing without any official word being taken into account. If a poll like the pirate mechanics vote has the overwhelming majority of 71% against pirates capturing ports, and hundreds of replies in it, it really can't be without a dev response at all.There was a response, but you had to watch a certain twitch stream doing a Q&A session (not advertised on the forum) with an audience of 50 viewers. Not the way to do it. There has been a single blog like post since the EA Launch six weeks ago, talking about upcoming features. One. If you want information, you need to befriend moderators who are also close to the dev team, who will then feed you information that is generally kept secret so far - such as the very near economy wipe and the new economy system - e.g. Steel Sandwich on the official forum. I've received far more information that turned out to be true at this point from this hush hush source than I've received by following the developer announcement posts. Another issue is that it is marketed as a sandbox, when that also isn't correct. There is one way to advance: sink enemy ships. Other gameplay mechanics might be in place, but they do not advance your character whatsoever. Also, they're designed in a way that you can't do them as long as you want, as you will run out of a finite, non-replenishable resource and have to wait for it to grow back - as if this was Farmville, not a full price game. Admin is also completely mute on this subject, making many economy players wonder if this game is even for them, despite it clearly being marketed as a sandbox. This is not an Early Access game, this is basically a gofundme campaign where the developer asked for pre-purchases so he can keep developing the game that he wants. You're not paying to have your opinion heard about the game, you're not paying to help design it, you're paying to be an Alpha Tester for a game that is already finished on the whiteboard. I don't know whether that game will actually be good, because he's also pretty quiet on that subject. I do not believe this to be in the spirit of Early Access, therefore I am not recommending it.As to how that could change: Communication can't be a one way street. The developers need to actively engage the community. Information is key. Share your roadmap. We're left in the dark what's happening within the next four weeks at this point.

Posted: February 27
Early Access Review
								The short version.The game looks good during fights, but the UI is useless, the open world pointless, and progress impossible.This was once one of the single most promising games on Steam and now a year after launch is worse than I have ever seen it. Had it stopped develoment in the alpha arena test mode it would have been a far better game. The long versionOnce upon a time I purchased this game. Months later I got an alpha key to the testing phase where the game was an arena slug fest between the ships and you could slowly rank up and try more out to test the physics. Since then everything has gone downhill. My Yacht does not change that and neither did 3+ years of patience. At first it was a fairly solid game I would have been happy with. Honestly if they scrapped the open world or brought back the arena I would be happy. There is some sort of large pvp mode still in the game but after a year of open world trial I have yet to get it to work. The UI is almost entirely useless and is entirely confusing. Menus simply exist and action buttons trigger with no explination as to what they do. If you somehow manage to get into the open world expect an eternity of endless sailing with no sort of guidance what so ever until you are beaten to death or simply get bored. The open world itself is ambitious and stunningly large but it is 100% empty and you are reduced to watching a sprite of the boasted ship models lumber through waves like a lazy flash game. The game didnt even include a map for months. With transit times impossibly long and the rewards of travel limited to whatever you can scrape up from the miserable and primitive trade system there is no point to going outside of the ports.The highlight of the game is still combat. Where before the ships worked moderately well now they have complicated things with crew, officers, upgrades, and quality. Some of this is neat, other things simply add further confusion to the already abysmal UI. After more than a year the upgrades still display bugged. Officers skills do not work. Crew refuse to follow orders or suddenly abandon tasks. There is no feedback to anything you do and any sort of repair is guesswork. After loading into an admirality order combat mission today only one of my chaser weapons loaded, it took more than 20 minutes for it to finaly be useable. Speaking of weaponsm if you somehow manage to get a new ship good luck trying to figure out what type of gun to use on it. There is next to no way to tell without buying and equipping them.The visuals of this game are still lovely, within their context. The open world is an ugly mess, cities as far as ive seen look entirely the same. There is 0 customization that I am aware of. Crews stand on deck doing a single animation loop eternaly despite the condition of the ship or orders given. The ships themselves are gorgeous, but only in battle, out at sea they are significantly reduced sprites. Inside a port you cannot see anything but a name and a terrible unity basic UI.Sadly not recommended until significant changes have been made to the game. If I were you I would scrap the open world or put out the arena as a different game. I honestly just want to go back to brawling.

content:
Posted: March 24
Early Access Review
								I have been playing this game on and off for over a year and a half now. I was in early access since before open world. The reason I can never recommend this game is because the developers keep constantly changing their plans for the game and development goals. It is very clear that they do not know what they are doing because they make changes and then do a complete 180 on those same changes six months later. As well, they do not warn players in advance that they will lose everything that they have worked for in this game. They have deleted / reset the game and the players accounts now at least 4 times. They are supposed to warn customers in advance of this. Instead, they only post a news section to current players and new players are completely blindsided that they will lose everything that they have worked for except now XP. But who knows when the developers will do a complete 180 on that decision as well.I can say after a year and a half of experience with this game that this game is NOT in development but instead only in experiment. They refer to customers as "Play Testers" instead of early access customers. This removes any obligation in their mind to you the "Customer" by thinking that you are some kind of unpaid volunteer and not a paying customer. In this regard they do not value customers at all, but instead treat them as pests and testers that need to be controlled and managed.Many of the stated plans and development ideas have changed completely since I gained access to the game. Right now, barely anyone plays on the server that I play on. you are lucky at the time of this writing to see 200 players online on the server that I play on during peak time. Usually, it is only less than 100 players. They have alienated anyone who speaks against their constant development / experiment floundering and feel no obligation whatsoever to actually progress the game towards a constant development track towards previous stated goals.I get the impression that this game is being made by a tiny group of people who are only getting paid to learn how to make games with no real intention whatsoever to actually create a full game. This game in my view will never be fully released because then the developers could be held accountable for what they do to their customers.Do not give these developers any more money. They need to be removed from steam. They are only experimenting and not actually continuing a solid track of game planned game development goals. Instead, they keep changing the targets and goals and doing 180's on previous plans and goals.

Early Access Review
								I have almost 1000h on this game and I greatly enjoyed it for the first few months and I gave a positive review of that game at that time despite it having many issues, but that's to be expected from an early access game.Sadly, I won't support Naval Action any further because of the path it's taking.The problem is that this game is currently making a very sharp turn towards realism while casting the gameplay and the fun aside. The devs don't seem to realize that while being beautiful, the age of sail was also plain boring and dull for a lot of sailors, and by making the game more "realistic" they are also making it boring.Currently, at least half of your time in this game will be spent traveling around to get where the fun is at instead of "having fun". Do you remember those moment at the amusement park where you're waiting in queue for an hour and a half just to be able to get on a ride for about 10 minutes ? That's how you'll feel while playing this game.Now the true question is, are those 10 minutes worth waiting for 1h30 ? I would have said yes a few weeks ago.But they are currently working on scraping the remaining bits of fun i had by trying to add more limitations in the name of "realism".It's to the point where I wonder why this game is called "Naval ACTION" instead of "Age of sail manager 2016"

								The Age of Sail and the height of power for Ships of the Line...A beautiful game.  It sums it up simply.  The map is vast.  Days to sail across the Caribbean. Early Access Review
								My first review! I have roughly 100 hrs into this awesome gem of a SIM/RPG and I am completely satisifed with the resultsPROS-The ocean is magnificent! Storms, swells, waves and even the color of the ocean model is SO realisitc that it reminds me of home.-Open world sand box is AMAZING! In fact, would be kool if Stranded Deep was teamed up with these folks to make loosing a ship VERY interesting!Game is still in Alpha and it is worth your time. money and support for this amazing game!

content:
Posted: October 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								I want to start off with something good, the community is absolutely amazing! Theyre helpfull, friendly and they organize events and activities! if not for the community this game would've been long dead.Graphics,The graphics look absolutely stunning, its a bit unoptimized, but it isnt that bad, I wouldnt reccomend this game if you have a bad PC tho cause you need a decent one to run it with like 30fps, I have a i7 6700k 16gb ddr4 and a R9 270x and the game runs good on medium, I need a GPU upgrade badly but I am having issues with OW sailing and large battles, small battles are fine (max 20 ships) it wont go below 60 fpsShips,There are a decent amount of ships in the game and they all feel diffrent and thats a good thing! I dont think theyre actually balanced but I dont mind that, it makes the game more fun tbh cause a gunboat can take out pretty much everything if you know how to play. They do looks absolutely amazing tho!I think these are the only positive things im affraid, Now the negative part...The playerbase,The playerbase is declining and this will not change UNLESS the price goes down atleast 30-50% I see so many posts that people want to give this a shot but its just too expensive, and I agree. A Early Acces game shouldn't be 40 euros or what ever price in whatever currency! Crew and animations,This is a more neutral thing cause the ship animation (sail/rudder/flags etc) are quite good, but the crew animation is horrible, they just sit there pulling and shoving the air and go trough your cannons, I mean its probably better to take it away all together until you have a decent animation, or let them atleast walk around your ship and make them dissapear when they get shot...I also have an issue with the ship crew feature, for the gunboat you need 40 people to fully crew it... what? its like a row boat with 2 cannons and a sail... you need maybe like 10 people MAX to fully crew it... if you get a big ship like a Santasima or a Victory or even a 3rd rate I can understand you need 700+ crew but for like 7/6/5 you dont need more then like 100... Crew is also very expensive if you just start out.. its 500 gold per crew member and you start out with like 40, if you get sunk once and lose all youre crew that means you need to pay 20k gold, have fun with that in youre basic cutter trying to make some gold...No tutorial,This game doesnt have a tutorial, and before you start commenting "players will help you" listen, The fact that the devs didnt bother with a tutorial mind boggles me, This game isnt easy to get a hang off, they dont show you how to sail, they dont explain the UI, they dont explain how to shoot, they dont explain how to make money/xp they dont explain SH*T, and yes the community will gladly help you, they will show you the ropes but a tutorial is needed, tips are needed, there HAS to be a crafting tutorial, a manual sail tutorial, a shooting tutorial a trading tutorial, you cant expect the community to help you if you're too lazy to actually help US.The UI,Oh noi does it look like its made in MS paint, I think it never actually changed over the time I owned this game and I own it for a while now, I get that the Devs are "busy" But for the love of god change the god awfull amateur looking UI...Open World,Open World at this point is just sailing to orders or to get some stuff in another city and get ganked, its bland, its boring, the wind is the worst feature in OW aswell cause youre always sailing against it. Please add more stuff to do in open world... we got fishing but it only gives you a reason to go out of port to get a tiny chance of finding a bottle... Also I understand you want us to sail to out missions etc but if it takes you ~10 min to get there AND youre sailing against wind which will make it 15-20min then it gets real boring real quik... give us stuff to look at, give us something to do! please redesign or take away the wind feature in OW all together!EDIT: They added in forts and towers, I think they kinda changed OW overall cause it looks "better" I guess, they also updated the map, which looks a little better then the old one so thats nice I guess.Missions/orders/whatever you wanna call them,The missions are fun, well for the first 2 levels cause after that it takes longer to get to them and the battles take for ♥♥♥♥ing ever... You can make money and XP by doing PvP but other than missions you cant, and it wouldnt be an issue if the mission only took about 10-15 min but it takes like half an hour and sometimes even 45min, for a PvP battle thats fine! but unless its a special event or dungeon kinda thing PvE shouldnt last longer than 15min...EDIT: They updated the missions, now there are delivery missions (trading) Battle missions (same as the old once) and something with war and giving stuff not sure what it is since there is basically no description. Also you cant do missions from your captial! so now you actually have to sail even further to get your♥♥♥♥♥handed to you and make jack♥♥♥♥♥♥Crafting,I cant say allot about this because I didnt bother starting this yet, maybe someone else could explain in detail whats good/wrong with it. EDIT: still pretty much the same but harderTo be honest there is allot more but I've been writing this post for like 20min already...Please leave a comment if you think I am wrong but I think the Developers are just lazy, I heard they have a small team but they can always hire more people, also the game doesnt seem to move forward and I wont see allot of positive change unless the developers start doing something about it... I also heard that there are allot of people that wanted to help out with allot of these problems but the devs turned them down for what ever reason. I dont know if all of this is true but I saw it in the game chat and on the forums a couple of times so yeah just wanted to throw that out.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								Someone still remembering the age-old title Age of Sail? I loved that title for it's atmosphere and approach to realistic sailing and shooting mechanics.In many aspects, Naval Action seems to be a worthy successor.Ship handling is difficult and demanding, but incredibly rewarding when you finally get the hang on it (I certainly have no arrived at that point. Still missing broadsides at point blank.) It feels very immersive, too.Now add a pinch of Pirates! to the lot and mix it with classical MMO features:Naval action circles around PvE and PvP (there is a PvE only server, too) sea battles in an open world sandbox (yes, that time of the year again). Choose a faction to side with and gain ranks and riches by doing missions, privateering, trading and, well: naval action. Grind your rank from petty midshipman all the way up to rear admiral while sailing the infamous caribbean waters.Be aware there is only a very, very basic and GODDAMMN ugly, but functional UI and port interface present at the moment (place holder)!The AI is decent but not stunningly smart. It benefits from cheating and bonuses, too. Still lots of room for improvement here.As to be expected you can find balancing issues, bugs and glitches but so far I did not discover a game-braking one. Remember: Early Access.If you were disappointed by gamey ship handling in Empire: Total War but loved it's graphics and atmosphere, Naval Action will interest you. If you're willing to look beyond the Early Access issue and the heavy Elite:Dangerous style rank grind, which still feels dull and pretty unrewarding.If you ever wanted to be Jack Aubrey, Mr. Hornblower, Arr! Blackbeard or Surcouf, this is your chance. Don't forget to have a looped volley of shanties running on your music player, though.The Looks and SoundsSailing ships roll and pitch in the seas in all their detailed, glorious splendour. Mighty Ship-of-the-Lines exchanging rolling broadsides under a waning moon, their dim stern lanterns lit while the whole sea is enlightened by muzzle flahes just to be swallowed by dense gun powder clouds again.Listening to the creaking sound of ships rolling in heavy waves and the impressive thunder of firing 32 pounders is impressive.Ah, the ocean! It's colour sheme and rolling wave's look even more realistic and impressive than in World of Warships, and that ocean already looks stunning.Spotting a lone sail or traces of a slowly growing landmass on the fog-shaded horizon amidst the sheer endless, foaming sea really succeeded in immersing me right into the game.I've exclusively playing PvE until now- so I can't give a verdict about the PvP servers or the state of PvP in general.As of update 9.7 there have been many additions to PvE content like gargantuan AI fleets, AI can sail all ship types, a stronger, very challenging AI opponent (as of update 9.73 made easier for lower skill levels), land-in battles (meaning the battle terrain will reflect the open world terrain).The only thing that needs to be added for atmosphere are decent music (and by the way, those STUPID COMMENTS ON THE LOADING SCREENS NEED TO GO! They are not even close to be funny.) and more modelled sailors. Right now you've only got one sailor manning a gun each, the helm is unmanned and no one cares to deal with sails. Which looks kinda silly! Albeit the sailors models themselves are well done and the textures detailed.On CraftingBuilding ships can be a pain. It all comes down to the hunt for blue prints enabling you to buildship type when consuming the blue print item.Blue prints do have a random drop chance while producing a certain ship type:e.g. building a St. Pavel 2nd Rate Ship-of-the-Line might give you a blue print drop for a 1st rate Victory.As chance RNG is involved you may have to build several ships of a type to cimb up the blue print ladder. This can be frustrating. But as of patch 9.6 the chances for drops have been altered so there is a very decent drop chance by now. I have all the blueprints by now and don't even have the highest crafting rank- chances are influenced by your level relative to the BP level you are trying to get and the quality of the shiup you were building- the higher the better)Crafting is also affected by your crafting XP level. You get XP for building ships, modules, components and thus level up until you reach level 50 enabling you to build the mightiest 1st rates in exceptional quality and the best modules (that can be placed as ship components making them better), too.Crafting also requires ressources (surprise, isn't it? :P), which are consumed by producing ship parts. These parts are then used in the building process. Eg. Oak---> X planks--->X planks needed to build ship Y.For the very crafting process you also consume labour hours that replenish over time. As they are also used for extracting ressources from production buildings, buildiong modules or components they are the rarest good. You'll have to be careful on what to spend them if you want to climb the XP ladder / built ships most effective. E.g. you'll have to amass the labour hours worth of two real life days to build a single Santissima Trinidad- without all the components needed!

number of helpful: 57 of 78 people (73%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								Set in the Age of Sail you will captain your ship through the entire Caribbean in search of either the riches of the land or the blood of the enemy. You are able to rank up to command some of the biggest ships out there, like the 1st Rate HMS Victory, or build up your trading and crafting endeavours and rake in the big money.There are a whole bunch of nations to choose from (United States, Denmark/Norway, Sweden, British Empire, France, Dutch Republic of the United Provinces, Spain and the outlaw Pirates), ranging in various difficulties depending on how many islands they start out with and their diplomatic capabilities. You can log onto a server (PvP or Player versus Player) where many of the ports can be conquered by other players of other nations and players of the different nations can fight it out in the Caribbean waters with each other as well, or you can choose to take it easy and sail around on the PvE (Player versus Environment) server where those things are disabled. Rank progression is shared among the two, money and assets aren't.Even at this early stage the tropical world you sail in looks gorgeous and the action when battling looks breathtaking. That being said, it's not a game for the people that are impatient and with a short attention span. If you intend on exploring the Caribbean you can easily spend 30 to 60 minutes sailing without anything in sight but open sea before reaching land again. But it's worth picking up for those who played Empire: Total War for the ships and possibly familiar with Pirates of the Burning Sea.[21/01/2016 Early Access Launch]Mind you that this is a very early alpha build. There's no tutorial yet, neither any pointers, hints or tips, and UI is minimal yet functional and not all planned features are in the game yet. For the best experience it is recommended to find like-minded players through chat, on the forums or better yet join them on TeamSpeak. Many of the seasoned players, many who were able to play for more than a year, are more than happy to help answering all of your questions. If you want to play this rather for yourself on the PvE server, expect a steep learning curve.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								One night I got jumped by several members of a nation we were at war with, all in ships that out classed mine.  I tried to flee, but they chained my sails an ultimately sank me.  I'd like to think I got a few licks in though.  I re-spawned to find they were also attacking a port nearby where I had an outpost, so now, with only the "basic cutter", I sneaked back into the port where my outpost was, loaded up a trading vessel with all of my crafted items and resources (more than enough to make another ship!) and sneaked out.  My enemies caught up with me but I was able to flee the battle in my trader and get back to my nation's capital with my treasures.  It was a heart pounding hour or more of play, even though I was on the losing side of the one fight.  Now I'm out in a bigger better ship looking for some revenge.I've never really played more than a few minutes of an MMO before, and I was intrigued by this game's theme of Age of Sail combat.  I've been drawn in by the player-vs-player politics and fighting.  The battles are wonderfully rendered and the thunder of cannons, haze of smoke, and thrill of victory really bring the Age of Sail alive.

The admins do nothing about this, because crossteaming is only forbidden if you troll the chat channels of your enemy. This issue has first been come up in _February_ and nothing was done about it. Now it's a daily occurence. This is of course not the only abuse of crossteaming alts, but by far the most severe one. And it's all legal. This game is a safe haven for cheaters, assuming they're going the "buy extra account" way of cheating.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								I started playing Naval Action about a year ago. When I bought it, you could only play something called Sea Trails, which was only combat and no open world. I got a bit tired of the wipes, so I didn't play that much. That didn’t mean I disliked it, though. Naval Action does in fact beat all the games I've played about warships from the age of sail. I think it beats Assassin's Creed: Black Flag and Pirates of the Caribbean Online by a long shot, even though I played the crap out of them. That was true even a year ago, when the ship vs. ship action wasn't as good as it is now and there was no open world. The visuals are amazing, too. Stern lights and the day and night cycle gives a really good atmosphere. When in combat, the muzzle flashes of cannons going off as well as the gunpowder smoke looks better than in any other similar game. I have most graphic options on the lowest, but the game still looks amazing. Naval Action already have a lot of different vessels ranging from fast 8 cannon sail ships to giant first rate ships of the line with up to 138 cannons and three gun decks (four if you include the weather deck). If you have played World of Warships, you will recognize certain elements when it comes to shooting. For instance, you can shoot individual shots to make sure the full broadside will hit. It is, however, more difficult and in my opinion better than in WoWs. Wind is an important aspect in NA, as all ships are using sails. Tacking against the wind can be hard for newcomers, but there are good tutorials out there that cover this. Open world is something I haven’t really played that much, but I do like it. You can choose between the British, French, Spanish, Swedish, Danish-Norwegian, Dutch, United States navies as well as Pirates. You become a Pirate automatically when attacking ships from your own navy. The whole crafting and trading system may seem a little overwhelming to some, but it is something that should be learnt quite easily. Off course, there are tutorials for that too. Ships can be crafted, and players can set ships for sale at a price they choose themselves. You can, for example, sell a cutter (The first ship you get) for 100.000 gold, but nobody will buy it as they can get it for free in the store. Also, each ship have 5 durability, which means that if it sinks 5 times it is gone forever. You can buy repair kits, but in combat you can only use one. That means that you will often find yourself running away if you’ve ended up in a bad situation.  Apart from from the placeholder UI, the only thing I dislike about the game is that after you buy it, there’s no way to continue supporting it through the game itself. The game is not for people who are just looking for a relaxed and forgiving MMO experience, but if you're interested in warship games I can almost guarantee that you'll like it. There is more to this game than just what I've mentioned, and I might add to this review when I've played some more.10/10

content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								Hi,I've got a ton of hours playing this game for over a year in closed alpha.  I can tell you the graphics are beautiful, the gameplay is really fun, the community is great, and this game really fills the huge empty gap that is currently missing for Open World Age of Sail games.The OW is huge and It takes probably 20+ hours to sail across the Carribean in this game.  There is trading, crafting, ship building, port battles, storms, varying weather, day night cycle, several factions and free towns, realistic phyics, historical ships, large fleet battles, conquest mechanics...pretty much everything you would want in a realistic Age of Sail game.  For the combat, this game is more on the realism and hardcore, skill based side, easy to pick up hard to master, having to learn things like yard controls with tacking and boxhauling maneuvers.Please note the devs have been rapidly releasing new features and there is not a lot of what I would call 'polish' to the game yet.  The UI is pretty barebones and some gameplay is not yet fully fleshed out.  The good news is their servers have been rock solid so far, no disconnects or anything.If you are an avid PvPer you will love this game.  If you love large battles you will love this game.  Hell even if you only want PvE they got that covered too.  Buy this game as their won't see many like it in this genre.  Definitely a PotBS killer.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've owned this game for nearly a year now, and since then, the game has improved dramatically. When I first started there was no open world, only a battle arena. This was fantastic because it allowed the developers to test combat mechanics. Since then, they've implimented the Open World, basic economy and crafting, a new damage model, and a ton of new ships.The game is fairly niche, and it does have a steep learning curve when it comes to combat, but don't let that hold you back. The graphics are incredible, the sound effects are stunning, and the ships are majectic. The developers have been fantastic thus far; they have been very open to change and discussion, as well as listening to the opinions and suggestions of members of the community.Naval Action has been absolutely fantastic, and I have nothing but kind words to say about it. Now remember, it is an Early Access game, so there are bugs, and there are things that aren't as pretty or refined as they could be. There isn't an "Official" tutorial, but there are many fan made ones here: http://forum.game-labs.net/index.php?/forum/44-guides/  However, at the end of the day, I'd have to reccomend this game. The developers had put this release off for several months, because they wanted to make a good first impression. That alone, speaks a lot for the character of the developers. They're not in it for the early cash grab, but instead, they are devoted to making an incredible game.

number of helpful: 33 of 40 people (83%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								The first time I saw my cannon balls bounce off an opponent's hull, I knew I was hooked on Naval Action.Naval Action is an Age of Sail naval combat simulator wrapped in an open world MMO. The game is really centered around, and shines as, a combat simulator that requires true skill, strategic thinking, and sound tactics to be successful. Combat is not a twitch fest and really only a small to moderate amount of manual dexterity and precision is required. However with wind, ship, and munition physics well modeled it's a thinking man's game where patience, planning, and a solid understanding of what works and doesn't work is super helpful.The devs have done a brilliant job of laying out a long career path for captains in the game as you start with the smallest Cutter and work your way up. Each successive upgrade helps you develop your skills and become more proficient as a captain without dumping you off the deep end. PvP is amazing and a variety of scenarios are available from dueling, attacking traders, port battles, fleet missions, and individual missions. For those who are adverse to PvP a PvE only server is available that offers a solid player experience without the stress and unpredictability of the PvP environment.On top of all this, the game has a solid economy, trading, crafting, ship building, and most recently inter-nation alliances. The devs are continually improving the game, adding perks, features and new twists while striking a really good balance between being responsive to their player base and keeping the game playable and accessible to all.Another selling point for Naval Action is the community. The community within Naval Action is one of the most welcoming and helpful I have encountered. Most everyone is willing to answer questions from new players and help them out. Many more senior players will keep a low level ship or two in their inventory just so they can sail on missions with newer players, help them learn, and level up.Overall Naval Action is an excellent game that continues to improve over time and is well worth your time if you are interested in the genre.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								There are many people who are giving this game a negative review while logging hundreds of hours in the game.  If this is the case, then they obviously got their money’s worth out of this game.  The development team is small, and it can take a while for the developers to address issues with the game.  If there is something that is bothering you, post it on the forums and if it is game breaking for you, just put the game down for a while.This is an early access game and you should expect changes both good and bad.  Development of a game like this takes time and people seem to want instant gratification.  I have seen the developers make drastic changes that angered the community, and the developers have always been quick to reverse these changes or fix them by another means.  The developers have been addressing people’s issues of things like ganking, which was one of my major criticism of this game, and I feel like they have done a great job of fixing this issue with new rules of engagement.  The developers have also added fleets and port defenses to help protect players in their home waters.  No more ganking players right outside of friendly capitals.  This is a niche game that is not for everyone.  The developers strive for as much realism as is possible in a video game which means, combat can take a long time and sailing from place to place can take a long time.  The developers have put a hard cap of 1 hour 30 minutes on each combat instance, and many of my combats have taken the full 1 hour and 30 minutes to complete.  Do not expect to log into this game and jump right into the action like world of warships.  This game is more dynamic and requires you to sail to where the action is.  The developers of this game have built an age of sail naval combat game with a vast open world to explore.  This is a sandbox game, and will require you to make your own fun.  This game can be as boring as you want it to be, or as fun as you want it to be.  There is almost always something to do, just ask nation chat or pick up a trading mission or combat mission.  Sailing from place to place can be time consuming, finding other players to fight can be time consuming, sailing from port to port is time consuming.  It can take hours to sail from one place to another.  This is how unbelievably vast the game world is, and I feel like some people take this for granted, but in reality, it’s quite amazing.  The developers built a mini world and you can sail anywhere you want, although if you are in enemy waters, you may get attacked by other players.  Traveling time in this vast open world has been mitigated with the addition of outpost slots, also, you can easily teleport your ship from port to port by capturing a NPC ship and you only need to make the trip in open world once.  This is not an instant gratification game.  If you want to be sailing a 1st rate ship of the line, it will take you a long time to achieve this goal.  You will need to gain ranks, you will need to gain money, and you will either have to buy a 1st rate ship of the line from another player or join a clan that will build you one once you can fully crew the ship, or build one yourself.  Accumulating the recourse to build ships is time consuming, but achieving this goal feels very meaningful once accomplished.  This game is not a newb friendly game.  Learning how to do things in this game is time consuming and will take you hours of practice to master.  If you are not willing to put in the time and effort to learn this game, and watch youtube tutorials on how to effectively use your ship, than this game is not for you.  Happy Sailing!

Early Access Review
								Hours ingame are not properly represented on Steam. I played ~5,5 hoursThis game, and especially it's developers, are a huge unproffesional mess. Initially the game has no tutorial; making it very difficult to find your way around the poorly designed user interface until you find the button to instantly fight battles. From that point onwards it becomes lobbying for quickmatches. Sadly this kindof defies the premise of a "open world naval simulation" to me.With an average of ~130 or so players online split over 3 or so servers, and nobody lending a hand to new players, the game simply turns into a rather boring pvp grind that repeats itself time after time. I've never played a game that managed to lose grip of my interest this fast. Despite looking fantasticly detailed visually, there's really nothing below the surface of the oceans besides tedious ever repeating tasks.In addition the developers are more than but questionable, legitemately trying to confront players and calling negative feedback "half empty pessimists"; which is echoed over several more reviews. Then there's the roadmap, which doesn't speak of any changes to the current model - meaning it'll only be enjoyable to those willing to put thousands of hours of work(emphasizing work) in obtaining a new virtual item.Unless you're an absolute hardcore naval fanatic willing to repeat the same bland tasks into eternity avoid this game. Might've recommended provided it was 5$, but it's an extremely hefty 38$.3/10

content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								I loved the sailing in AC4; it's the main reason I picked this game up because it took that aspect that I loved and built upon it. You spawn in your little dinghy at a port full of a bunch of other people in their little dinghies and one guy with a giant♥♥♥♥♥frigate showing off. This game doesn't have much curb appeal. You step in and it's clearly unpolished (as expected). The UI is bad and confusing, boarding ships is this minigame that people have described as "rock paper scissors" but really if you just always go offense you can't seem to lose, there are no tutorials or help in-game, and many items/descriptions are ambiguous like "Marines" give me "cannon_reload_time = 10%." What does that mean? Is my reload time going up or down? Or is it 10% of the original value? I also didn't figure out different wood types affect ship speed/health until about 15 hours in. That would be important. Also I didn't know that your rank affected how many crew you can have, not which ship you can buy. Would've been nice before buying a 200 crew ship so early on. I have encountered a few bugs, namely capturing ships and then not receiving them in the loot screen.Still, despite all these flaws, it is a damn fun game. Now that I've figured out how most of the mechanics work, there is a lot of depth to the overworld content as well as combat. The roar of cannons in the big 20+ ship battles is music to my ears, not to mention the game looking really good for an EA title. Also, the lag seems to be non-existant. I play on the EU PvP server since it's the most populated and don't notice any lag at 150ms nor have I seen anyone rubber-banding and such. Finally, the devs appear to be very responsive. They're active on Twitter answering questions and posting about updates as well as being very reactive to player feedback before the Steam launch went live. All in all I give it a 8/10. The core mechanics are good fun and there's definitely enough content to keep you occupied. The devs have a solid base that's rough around the edges; once you get past the initial "wtf is this" from the UI and confusion, the game is really fun. Am I sure this game will move in the right direction? No. But from what I've seen the devs have a good head on their shoulders. Still, it's an EA title so take that with a grain of salt.

number of helpful: 30 of 39 people (77%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is amazing. For me, it is the fufillment of a childhood dream; to be a captian on the high seas, sailing the ships that I constantly drew and studied as a child. This effect was tripled when the Devs added the wonderful USS Essex into the game; I've been drawing that ship since I was in 1st grade. Thanks devs, for helping me fufill a long-thought dream.I'll plainly lay out pros/cons for your convenience, dear reader.+The game's open world is amazing! The map is massive, filled with beautiful islands and ports- and enemies too. It's breathakingly beautiful.+Ship models are mind-blowing not only in beauty, but accuracy.  You're not sailing a digital representation in low def; you're sailing an exact recreation of the real thing. Perhaps not as "rugged" as people imagine, but beautiful nevertheless.+Ship performance and customization systems are extremley detailed and advanced! Characteristics of a ship range heavily from turn rate, speed and even the thickness of your hull- much more involved. A pantheon of upgrades allows you to customize your own ship to fit your play style, which is incredible.+Combat system is divine. The game's entire purpose is first as an age of sail combat simulator, and they nailed it here. Ships perform accuratley as they would in real life; spare for a 25% speed boost from the real thing. Perform complex manuavers like tacking, box hauling, etc, outsmart your enemy in so many ways. +Ballistics engine is mind-blowing. There's no "hp bar"; shots can penetrate through hull, create splinters that could kill some crew standing by a gun, bounce around the other side of the hull (or exit), carry away some unfortunate fellow, ricochet off a gun, etc. It's, in my opinion, the most wickedly advanced ballsitics and damage engine that the industry has seen next to qualitiy titles like War Thunder. +Crafting! A grindy process that really pays off, crafting allows you to custom build your ships and other materials. Gather materials, build the ship like they would in the real days by whipping up things ranging from the hull frames, knees for deck support and even the ship's stern furnishings if she has them. I do emphasise grindy; however, it really pays off in the end; very, very satisfying to craft your "dream ship" yourself!+Officers! It's a new update which is really awesome. You can hire officers that join you on your missions and gain "perks" and other skills to help you manage your ship. There's a really hillarious "coward" perk that reduces the battle exit timer by 50% for example. I think it's a cool little addon that allows one to say "we beat them through superior gunnery". :)Now, the game isn't perfect. Though I love the game, it has a few things to hammer out!-National diplomacy system isn't perfect. The Devs have very wisely been receptive to the community for demands to reform the system in various ways. Pirate mechanics are unusual; as the pirates are manifested as a nation with extra perks to that of the other nations, and hence they have an actual empire, government, ect which is fairly unusual. Declaring war, making treaties are managed by the larger clans, which can be viewed as not too representative of the nation's majority views.-UI is minimalistic; it's not hideous, but it isn't exactly attractive either. It could be better, but the devs have prioritized (and quite simply, rightly so) the game mechanics over the UI. Hope you're not too picky over game UI!-Grindy. Personally, I find Naval Action's ships, ranging from the starter cutter to the largest ship of the line infinitley playable, and hence I really didn't mind the "grind", if you will to get to the higher levels for manning ships. However, if yo're impatient, this game may be a bit slow for you. Grind process is longer than most games!-Learning curve is long! The game's mechanics are complex, so beware those with a low attention span, heh. The Community as a whole is wonderful in being very helpful to new players, but there's no in-game tutorial or official help guides to get you off your feet. It certainly took  me a while to master the art of "manual sailing" in the square rigged ships.I'm not sure why the game's been getting mixed reviews as of late. The game is, at its core, a sandbox age of sail combat simulator; not a fast and boring free to play like World of Warplanes, etc. The game is designed to create a beautiful and immersive enviroment to engage in combat and screw around in the open world first and foremost; the devs here didn't design the game to advance fast, or the goal of the game to get to the "top level". AS a combat simulator, the game excells beyond any doubt. Anyone who analyzes the game from my perspective will agree wtih me. However, those who analyze the game from those whose interpretation of the nature of the game is to level up and win as quickly as they can will look on the game poorly. Please keep that in mind when looking at other reviews that attack the grinding of the game and "ganking" mechanics.Edit: July 30th, 2016I've also noticed a lot of criticism against the devs apparently not "adding much to the game". In a mere month, they've done the following:-Added Fishing, hence expanding the economy, adding new roles to trader ships and yet another way to play Naval Action.-Added Food Rations and other supplies to represent need for resources to mantain crew.-Crew is now a resource. Losing 50 men to a close range rake now has much more effect on your well being.-Added officers, a very significant addition to the game.-Added treasure hunting for some exploration fun.-Added some new upgrades.-Added the wonderful 2nd rate ship of the line Bucenature.-Showcased the Santa Cecilia, a new frigate in the game.Look at the patch notes for the month, and tell me again that the devs aren't adding much to the game...

								First off, the graphics in this game are fantastic as is the combat engine.  I love the ship to ship combat and the feel of sailing these vessels.  I have put many hours into this game and I have made many friends as I have with most mmo's.Naval Action may still  be in early(late )development but I am still going to give it a negative review.   The last consecutive patches have changed this from an incredibly fun and captivating game, into a boring waste of time.  This has led to an increasing decline in the server  popluations which consequently makes the game even more boring.  The developers seem to lack direction or a unified vision and this can be seen in radical shifts in the changes they have attempted with regards to both PvP and crafting in the latest patches.  You are left unsure of whether they intend this to be a game or a simulator.  Feedback from the players(testers) is often discouraged unless it's positive.Unless there is a major change in the development of this game, I predict it will end up in the boneyard of games that had promise but failed.  I would not recommend buying this game until it has made it to its official final release and has had some success.

								I come from playing tons of the old Pirates of the Carribean community mod and tons of hours in Pirates of the Burning Sea. content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								Naval Action has supprised me. Although still early in it's development, the game provides an immersive experiance that replicates the neccessity of quick thinking and adaptation to circumstance that pervades naval combat. The ocean is a 'living' being adding chaos to even the most well thought out and well timed turn to broadside the enemy. This chaos complements the commitment combat entails. This is not another simple a random number generator, HP driven fight with boats. This is more a physical recreation of a universe with accurately modelled physics. Combat is not resolved in seconds, nor even minutes. My first duel in the game lasted roughly 15 minutes, on the edge of my seat, hoping for some turn of advantage that would yield me the weather gage (naval advantage) and allow me to force victory.If you want a deeper naval warfare simulation then get this. If you want another arcade game that yields you easily exploited mechanics and detracts from the naval history of the Age of sail, look elsewhere.

								Somehow it all works.. perfectly.A naval simulation that brings the adventures of Horatio Hornblower to life..There is more than meets the eye on this one and it sure looks stunning with great immersive sounds to make naval battles feel like your actually at the helm shouting orders to your crew.. battles are thrilling and exiting and can last quite awhile.. one can join missions and jump into small or big battles or enter the open world map where you can sail the high seas, trade, fight and or get lost ehm i mean explore the vast map. content:
Posted: August 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								First, this game is not for everyone. Its a niche game. You will not be given a story, you must make your own. This is a sandbox PvP game (also PvE but I don't reccomend that). There may be a huge enemy player fleet around that island even in your home waters waiting to sink you, or there may be nothing. Some people complain about the "grind" but honestly within a week you can fully crew some excellent ships that are very important and effective in PvP (like the Rattlesnake). This is a slow paced game where you can easily take on a group of more ships in bigger ships if you have the skill. There are upgrades etc.. that help, but at the end of the day one missed broadside, or a badly timed maneuver negates the positive effect of most of them. The combat mechanis are very detailed, with tons of room to micro manage all the while you must manually aim every shot. Sometimes this means a whole broadside into a wave, sometimes it means enough hits below the waterline (leaks) to sink a ship with otherwise full HP. I'll add to this review later, but long story short if you are into this sort of game there is nothing else like it, but again its not for everyone.... which is where the best games come from. The learning curve is steel, but the reward is great. Just get into your nations TS or group up with a clan and more then likely they will be very supporting (at least thats what its like in Sweden).

content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								Naval Action is a gorgeous game with a lot of potential, some of it front and center and already realised. The game is an interesting mix of gameplay styles. The ship to ship combat is streamlined but deep. Requiring you to not only use the wind to your advantage, but also the waves of the ocean itself. You must navigate successfully, and command your crew to prioritize tasks onboard. All of this culiminating in an epic and tense battle, with the thunder of cannons and smoke filling the air. The gameplay itself harkens back to Pirates! as well as elements that remind me of EVE (massive map, crafting and trading). Players choose a nation to start with, which will determine your starting location (U.S, U.K, Dutch, Sweden, Spain, Denmark & Pirates). Each nation has unique challenges based upon number of ports and geographical location. Interestingly enough I jumped on the French side, and lo-and-behold, most of the players were speaking French! Once you start in your home port you can grab missions from the admiralty and head out to the open sea (which is an absolutely massive map of the Caribbean). Once in open sea you can engage battles that are under way, other players (if you're on a PvP server) or head towards your mission objectives.Eventually you gain gold, experience and promotions. Allowing you to build, buy, or capture better ships. PRO:- Fantastic looking- Authentic Historical ships- Immersive weather and large map- Crafting (seems decent so far)- Tactically deep- Map does not show where you are, requiring you to use visual markers and a compass (I think this could be a PRO or CON)CON:- UI is a bit rough at the moment but is fairly functional- No tutorial on gunnery, crafting or trading- Somewhat steep learning curve- Map does not show where you are, requiring you to use visual markers and a compass (I think this could be a PRO or CON)All in all, the UI is rough but the gameplay is solid. I was extremely skeptical of this title heading in, but after logging a few hours today I can safely say this game is already very fun and once it gets polished and more ships added in, it will be very very good.

number of helpful: 20 of 26 people (77%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								Reviewing an early release is notoriously hard, the game is still in development and who knows where it is going to go. But Naval Action, while still an Alpha, is shockingly playable for a game so early in its development. Game play is rather unique, and by unique I mean SLOW. Combat is slow, travel in the overworld is slow, crafting is slow, and that slowness is probably one of the greatest points of this game. If you are a fan of most modern games MMO or otherwise this slowness can be a schock. This is not Call Of Duty, or War Thunder. Naval Action is more a game of chess than a game of whack a mole. You plan your attack, you turn a few points off the wind and you wait for the enemy to roll into your broadside. A single ship to ship combat can take up to half an hour, a multi ship battle can take over an hour. Travel in the overworld takes planning and time, a trade route may take you hours of real time to travel. Nothing happens fast and in this quick twitch game heavy world the stately if slow action in Naval Action is a welcome change. Factions are a fact of life in Naval Action, there are no independent ships. You will have to join a faction in character creation but that does not mean Kill On Sight for every other faction; French Privateers will peacefully cruise past Spanish ships of the line in neutral waters, but you do need to watch your back. Just because you don’t attack does not mean you will not be attacked. Overall this is a pleasing game, but you do have to set some time aside to play a good session. I for one look forward to the further development of Naval Action, it has a lot of great potential.

number of helpful: 40 of 63 people (63%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								First off I"m giving a thumbs down only because it's Early Access and many issues have not been fixed that I feel should have been many moons ago.Well, you can see how many hours I've played, it's not  hundreds but it's enough to see what's going on. This game is very pretty, VERY pretty. So pretty in fact, I have to run it on all low graphic settings to squeak out 16 FPS. My gear is AMD 4300 quad core 3.8ghz 8GB RAM Radeon R7 250 w/2GB video RAM, it's not the fastest but I shouldn't have to ride the little bus just to run the game though. World of Tanks I run on high settings and get 25FPS and it's every bit as graphically intense. A minor quibble, let's get to other things.The levelling system is a tad grindy, maybe not Korean MMO grind, but tedious enough that unless you're a fan it will take weeks of steady game play to get from the starting 7th rate ships to 5th (grinding all the way to 1st rate is for the no life crowd). The combat, while immersive, is using the same tired old tricks every dev uses to make the AI "difficult", in other words it cheats. Nobody uses anything other then Round Shot, and there's a reason why. I took a Privateer down to 47% Sails using Chain Shot (the preferred method of anti sail attack) and it continued to achive 10 knots, in close haul to the wind, This flys in the face of the Bernoulli effect on sails...with a dozen melon sized holes in them. The entire point of using Chain Shot is to reduce their use of anything but running with the wind and reduce their speed to a crawl, making them easy prey (a lot of ships during the period would strike their colors once their ability to maneuver was removed). I guess the devs decided that was either too hard to code (or maybe not 'sexy' enough) or ran out of funding when that part came up. By way of another players account of using Grape Shot (think big shot gun) to reduce a ship that started with 155 crew to 25 crew, and they were still able to maneuver the ship and reload and fire all canons as if nothing had changed. Yet again, another option removed for expediency of coding I suspect. I think they incude these ammunition types for historical accuracy street cred, but in reallity the AI doesn't pack it in until the hull is gone, and the only thing that does that is Round Shot. Remember, the whole reason to use Grape Shot is to remove the crew without damaging the ship to much, because then you now own a slightly used ship which is often times worth tens of times more then the cargo it's carrying.Now, lets get to the strategic map, shall we? For some reason, after months of Alpha and Beta testers complaining that open Faction enrollment was leading to grotesque Zerg factions skewing strategic game balance not one jot has been done to fix that. I get it, it's hard to tell people they can't play their favorite nationality in favor of sucking more EA sales and turn a blind eye to the steam roll that is happening with the ports, but the end game is not fun for anyone, even the umbrella factions as they will quickly run out of opponents. Soon, everyone is bored and quits to play something else. As the French I watched the Pirate faction in the USA PvP server take half of Martinique in 2 hours. After logging on before writting this they own most of the eastern French, Swedish and Dutch ports, the USA faction owns the coastline to Mississippi and a dozen ports encroaching on Cuba, Great Britain owns half of the Mexican ports, it's just kinda ugly. There's competitive and there's one sided, the abscence of any balancing makes for these weird one sided steam rolls. The thing is this has been covered by every MMO that's come before and failed to deal with the gorilla in the living room issue of faction balance, we know how it ends, writing your resume for the next game company.I cannot comment much on the Crafting or Trade aspect of the game, but port control is a huge facet of Trade, and the juggernaut steam roll of the ports has left many to give up on Trade if they aren't in the few zerg factions. Crafting requires for the most part a reliable resource influx, which is often tied to...wait for it...Trade. As you can imagine, quite a few have switched sides to the zerg faactions simply because that aspect of the game they like dictates they do so.What can I say, this game is still in Early Access so there's a possibilty these issues will be resolved before release, but don't bet on it until you see a video of some old Alpha dog telling you it's safe to go in the water again. I keep thinking, all they needed to do was pay some German board game designer 10-20 thousand Euro for consulting fees and implement his/her ideas regarding game balance, because those German board game designers know how to make a good playable fair game.

number of helpful: 38 of 60 people (63%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								I like this game a lot; but I can't recommend it.  Designed to, as accurately as possible, portray the Age of Sail in the Carribean and Gulf of Mexico, the game does that very well.  The devs are working very hard to tweak it, add balance, etc.But authenticity comes at a price.  Unfortunately, the main cost is real time. This is a huge problem for the long term success of a game.  Just going on a simple PvP mission can take an hour or more.  By the time you sail to sea (crap - it's against the wind), get to your marker, conduct the fight, then sail back (crap - against the wind AGAIN), you have just spent 30-60 minuites (or more) in the game.  Seek out a larger PvE battle and the time goes even higher.  PvP battles can be even worse.Any battle can last up to 90 minutes.  That means if you have 60 minutes to play before you go to work, before your next class starts, etc you can't play because you may still be stuck in a battle by the time you must leave.  And even if you get out of the PvP battles, you may well find friends of the enemy waiting for you as you leave - sucking you back into another up to 90 minute battle - sometimes 2-3+ times in a row.For someone with no time constraints, that is fine.  For the majority of players with class, jobs, family, etc, the time cost is too high.Yes, if you can only play a short time you can pursue your crafting skills.  But, it literally takes only 10-15 minutes tops to use up all the labor points you have for the day, so crafting can't fill the short time void very often.  You can also make trade runs, but smart players build their outposts so trade runs are rarely needed; why risk losing one's cargo when one can ship in complete safety using the automated delivery system that entails 0 risk to ship or cargo - and again can be setup in 10-15 minute tops?And that really, is all you can do.  Fight.  Trade. Craft.  Even with the most well thought placement of your outposts, getting to an enemy port to raid or try to seige takes a long period of real time - followed by that up to 90 minute fight - or multiple fights back to back.Not only can most players not afford the IRL time sink, many others can't handle the long periods of inaction.You can select Small or Large fleet battles in port and skip the sail out anf back.  This helps a little but the battle can still go on for 90 minutes.I'm not sure what the devs can do to lessen the time drain.  The overall concept of the game is outstanding.  Battles, especially between groups of frigates are great fun.   But the average gamer is going to acknowledge the game's potetntial then move on to other games that offer more fast paced action.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								This review is intended as a counter review to this guy's post: http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561197991377081/recommended/311310/I have replied in the comments to his review http://i.imgur.com/GlEdvIE.jpg , but just like it was suggested this guy deletes all the positive feedback making it look like this game sucks. Go try to find my post. It was deleted 5 min after I posted it!That is a very close monitoring if you ask me. Is he on some kind of mission to destroy an image of a great game? To fool you to walk away from a very promising title? Here screenshot of other people trying to response to his post and got deleted too http://i.imgur.com/0WMHnPP.jpgMake your own call, but please make it educated.As for me, I will be reporting this guy to Steam moderators. Sounds more like a competitor's dirty play to me.Also... look at the average hours played of all the recent negative reviewers. 20-50 hours into the game for most of them? Are you really going to trust someone's opinion if he has just scratched the surface of a subject?I don't write reviews normally, but sense of fairness simply urges me to do something for the great game, its hard working developer team and the great player community. So here is my own experience with the game. No more, no less. But if you don't like to read and all you want to know if I will recommend this game? I will return the question back to you.Do you like the Age of Sail era?Do you understand that this is NOT arena based game like WoT and that you have to invest time in it like in any MMO games?Do you understand the fact that this is a very early access (not even a beta)?Are you ok to explore the limits of the game and report back to the dev team your feedback, suggestions or concerns?If the answer to all this yes, then HELL YEAH! I will recommend this game to you!And below is how I came to this conclusion-----------------------------First 5 hours into the game:What's with the UI???? It looks dull. I can't find anything. UI makes no sense... Oh! They have a message on the UI screen - Test UI Please Ignore. Ok, fair enough. How do I load cannons??? How do I do this, or that? Let me ask in Help chat. Wow! That was quick! The help from community was awesome. No trolling which was VERY refreshing. It felt that players loved the game and cared for it. Ok time to set sail..... WOW!... No words, the graphics, the land, THE SHIPS!!! Everything looks so amazingly real!. Oh this sound of squeaking rigging and bumping sails on air...  I mean, if your computer is half decent it will handle the astonishingly done Caribbean world. This water makes me want to jump in it!10 hoursWent back, picked up a mission and got out to the open world. Took a bit of sailing (3 minutes to be exact), but finally I'm there.Hmm... how do I shoot? How do I control the ship? I'm so confused! Back to Help chat and with help I got through the first missions. When the adrenaline got settled a bit, I decided to  invest time to learn properly, so off I went to YouTube.50 hoursI have learned basic controls. I have learned how to aim and how to use different cannons. I have done few missions and advanced couple of ranks. What next?OMG! I got tagged by a pirate! If you are not hit for 2 min then you can run away from the battle instance (that I've learned very quickly). I'm trying to get away from this dude. The Black Flag on his ship is getting closer. 10 seconds before timer run off he managed to hit me with his chaser cannons (I didnt even know those existed!) and reset the timer. I'm doomed now. I can't run away! I can't? OMG! Well hell with it! I'll give him a good fight of his life... Of course I was smashed miserably, but man... I have never ever experienced such adrenaline boost from any other game.Its time to look for a good community. I need more help and info. I need to learn. Where is the best place to learn PvP? I need to become a pirate!. Hard decision, but I'm no carebear. I got to find me good teachers!200 hoursI got pretty good at killing AI, I could now afford to get better ships (not perfect, but better). I had few encounters with real players. I made friends! I was given so much help (money, ships and most importantly all the valuable info)I was so surprised to learn that sails can be controlled manually and that to be efficient in PVP you actually have to sail manually.I have learned Point of Sail for the ships I sailed.I have learned how to rack the Stearn of an enemy ship (the back).I have capped my first trophy ship from another player.I have learned to manage my time properly so I'm busy doing other game related stuff during the long sails to distant areas (you only have to sail to the destination once, then you set up an outpost and can teleport to it instantly).But every time I think I got it sussed there is still something to learn.500 hoursI'm now on good terms with port battles and the conquest mechanics. I start leading raids. I've learned to use Mortar Brig.I have now mastered manual sailing and it is now just a second nature and feels like driving a manual transmission car. You no longer thinking about it.I have learned all aspects of ship mechanics. I have learned how to run away from ships that supposedly faster than the ship I sail.I've learned to understand The Wind in the open world and in the battle. How to turn it into advantage.I've have learned perfect wind tack (turning across the wind) without ever getting stuck in the irons.I've learned to shoot specific areas of the ship depending to what I want to achieve.I've mastered shooting under the waterline giving him so many leaks that ships were going down from a single broad side fire.I've learned how to de-mast the enemy.I've learned advanced tactics of naval combat how to read your enemy and predict his next move...1000+ hoursI have been pretty much in every corner of the Caribbean .I've made tons of friends and enemies.I've sunk more players than I could count.I've made numerous posts on forums helping the development of the game and was incredibly surprised and happy to see some of my ideas implemented into the game play.I confirm that:Developers DO listen! They even talk and reply to your comments on the forums and discuss game stuff.The content is getting updated and polished all the time.New ships are added (not as fast as we would wish, but every 2-3 months), though there are so many ships there already that we have plenty to choose from.The game is very alive and the development is very active.This is as much as you can get from a reviewer. The rest is up to you to try and decide for yourself, but don't let someone to fool you that this is just another ordinary title. With the community's support this game can really achieve a lot.Sail dangerously captains![BLACK] KoltesUS PVP2 Server, pirate faction

number of helpful: 28 of 42 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've been in this game since it was in private alpha, more than 500 hours with a long break in the middle. There are pieces of it that are simply magical. There are others that are pretty rough. Hard to judge a game in early alpha, but as of now, I can only give it a very tentative thumbs up.The good:- As other have noted, the combat is incredible. If you have even the remotest interest in the Age of Sail, this is the combat sim for you. It is amazing. Combat is by far the best bit of this game, and may be worth the purchase price right there -- IF you are willing to stick with it. You really only begin to see the potential once you get out of the earliest levels and out of your default cutter.- The open world is beautiful to look at, and the ship models are gorgeous. They look and feel like I imagine frigates and ships of the line would have looked and felt at sea. Cannons roar, smoke billows. It’s jaw-droppingly realistic.- The PVP aspects are great, even for those who don’t like PVP generally (like me). This is a very slow game. It’s all about tactics, about limiting damage against and taking advantage of your enemy’s mistake. Fast twitch does nothing for you in this game, which is, frankly, awesome.- The new damage system is fantastic. It is physics-based, and takes into account range, size of cannon, the angle of your shot, the type of armor your enemy has, where on the hull or masts/sails it hits, etc. You can honestly snipe someone’s rudder, which is a very big deal. People are complaining about it now, but I think once it is tuned a little bit, people will come to love it.The bad:- So far, 90 percent of the effort has been on combat and new ships. If you aren’t into combat, and PVP in particular, there isn’t much else going on here right now. Careerwise, it’s pretty much all about fighting. Trading is dull. Crafting is tedious. And this is coming from someone who has done a lot of both, a level 48 crafter.- The devs have done a lot to limit ganking, and I don’t think it’s anywhere near the problem others do. I’ve never minded an unfair fight if it’s fun. This is a game, after all. But others seem to get more worked up about it than I do.- The worst part I think is the lack of newbie zones, and instead the game relies on players for the most part to defend those areas. I stopped playing MMOs seriously a while back, so maybe this is a new trend -- that somehow players will balance the world out. It hasn't worked out that way, at least on PVP1. And I'm not sure that’s realistic in a game world. But as a new player you’ll be thrown right into the thick of it. - In fact, I can’t imagine what this game would be like to come to new. There isn’t, as others have noted, much in the way of instruction. No in-game tutorial (yet). No really safe place to practice and learn. And as noted already, if combat isn’t your thing, you’ll tire of this game quickly. There is a pure PVE server, but the AI combat isn’t anywhere near as fun as PVP. - The port battle system sucks, and needs a massive overhaul (which, allegedly, is coming). Currently, it leads to incredibly boring dynamics where a nearly indestructible fleet arrives because they had time to prepare, and defenders didn’t, and it’s over really before it starts.- Pirates are silly as currently implemented. The devs are trying to maintain some connection to historical accuracy, but as of now the game system, oddly, allows pirates to be the most powerful nation in the game -- on PVP1 that is. Pirates should operate solo or in small groups. They should have completely different reward dynamics such as disrupting trade, running contraband, etc. And privateers should be a career option. Pirates should be flat-out banned from owning anything bigger than a frigate -- nor should they want to. Seeing a fleet of 25 pirate Santisimas is just -- wrong.All-in-all, this game is worth buying if you are a fan of Age of Sail. Even now, it’s well worth it. If you are not, or if you want to pursue a career other than one that is combat-oriented, I’d wait.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2016
Early Access Review
								After over 1000 hours played, I'm going to tell you why this game shouldn't be on your list of must have games. BANs and chat bans. This community makes every effort to basically pvp via chat versus effectively PVPing in the game. If you dont do something somebody doesnt like then if you say anything "toxic" as defined by ♥♥♥♥ing nothing, then you will be banned. no refund, not any way to state your side of the case, nothing. BTW there is no chat filter, which i would be fine putting in, but there isnt. This in turn has fostered a community of the thinnest skinned, crying little kintergarden teachers that you can imagine. And no matter how good your imagination is, this is worse. So dont for a second think you can act like anything but ned flanders from the simpsons while fighting in a game of murder and conquest. midwestern housewives should be all about this game, anybody else? not so much.The second problem is the pvp combat. This would be a great game if you got to actually fight somebody. The game has basically devolved down to playing fetch for an hour or better. The way the mechanics are currently you cant do anything, instead it takes upwards of 45 - 90 mins to actually chase down and sink somebody. Its basically boring as hell and unfortunately the only "exciting" combat is against NPCs which roll around the open seas like sea cows that never attrack any other player from another nation. This game started in pvp combat via the sea trials, and has made every attempt to get away from it's roots.
