content:
Posted: June 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								PvE server review only.Pretty ships.Mostly fun combat.Boring as frag world. Hope you got a 2nd screen, cause you will spend 75% of your time in this game, watching movies.You spend so much of your time, just sailing from A to B, doing nothing.They could easily have made sailing automatic, because after a week, you've learned how to navigate and from then on you simply point your ship in the right direction, alt-tabs, and watch a movie meanwhile.At this stage, I'm not really sure what they aim to do with the world, except it being a "capture eachothers ports 24/7" kinda of thing for PvP...As for the PvE server... well... fight AI ships every day. Thats about it.Sure, you can lol... trade... lol!... Even Elite: Dangerous does trading better, and that says alot.AI... oh boy.. 1v1, very easy to predict, and even force into certain maneuvers so you gain the advantage.In 2v1 or fleet orders with several enemies, you better NEVER point your ships stern (rear) toward ANY enemy ship... They will fire pin point accurate laser guided balls at you, that ALWAYS hit your stern nomatter the range, killing crew and destroying cannons + rudder.Server crashes. Dont happen often, but when it does.... well read below.Ships have durabillity. (basicly the amount of times a ship can sink, before its gone forever).Server crash during missions, causes ships to lose a durabillity.The most expensive and time consuming to build ships in the game, only have 1 durabillity...So... 1 crash = -1 ship."But you wont lose the ships with 2+ durabillity!".Right... But it makes it impossible to resell thoose ships on the market again and thus is reduced to either NPC fodder or breakin them down to materials.So yeah, if you want to buy this game for its PvE, keep in mind that you will enter a very empty world with very little to do.

number of helpful: 50 of 83 people (60%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								First off, let me say to those poor souls that have not been buying this game due to bad reviews, i am sorry. Here is why you should give this game a true chance, and I think you will find most people whining on here just wanted easy game play. -First and foremost, the teleport thing. I am tired of seeing people cry about teleporting in here, then in game rage quit because they got caught and couldnt teleport away. The teleport only works every 3 hours, and it only teleports you to your main capital. You can however move from outpost to outpost once you have docked your ship in a city with an outpost to another outpost, in a sense teleporting. This is simply due to the time it takes to sail, do you really want to sail for 5 hours to go to somewhere that only requires you to be there for 2 minutes for? -The TRUTH ABOUT THE DEVS.          The Developers of this game are not all English, so of course there is sometimes a slight language barrier. However i have dealt with and happily worked with these Devs since January of 2016, and let me tell you. These guys work hard as all heck to get it right. They believe in taking the time it requires to test everything out, from extreme to extreme in order to find a balance and the best possible way to allow for pvp in the pvp servers, and give good pve in the pve servers. I have lost several ships to glitches (its Early Access it happens) the devs know that, and they completely brought those ships, and everything on it back from Davy Jones' locker several times for me and several other players.         The devs on this game take a lot of crap from players that dont understand how to test a game completely with a smaller playerbase, it really is as simple as that. The devs want to try everything out because honestly, this game while not the complete first of its kind, has reached a point where no other sailing game has ever gone before or even gotten close to. It is required of the smaller dev team to work on one thing at a time from most to least important to find balance, try radical things to see what happens and how to fix any errors in game and to truly know how to further develope the game. -This game has so many great things, my favorite is the AMAZING GRAPHICS. And i mean truly breath taking graphics. For once in gaming history, the screenshots on the store page need to be taken down because they are not good enough to show what this game looks like on med-high settings.  With the amazing graphics also comes the support of and almost a symbiotic relation with the physics engine, its awesome, needs some work, but its still awesome none the less.THE BAD... -If you dont enjoy a grind.. This game forces you to do well and do it often in order to advance ship wise and crafting wise. -Like i mentioned, the updates take a bit, usually once a month for major updates, but patches come for the next 3 days generally after a major update. I think its worth it. -Right now the player base is small, and this game needs a larger player base, i am writing this review to help that, everyone on this game wants you to buy it and join their nation, the mroe people that play, the more fun this game truly is. especially in the pvp server.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've played this game a fair bunch, so let me give you some pros and cons : PROS : + Realistic combat, battles can take ages, but are really exciting and fun to do. + Beautiful battle graphics.+ Really fun to play with people you know. But also fun to play alone.+ If you're not really good in fighting, you can always switch to trading and crafting as a way to make money.+ You can teleport to the capital every 3 hours, so meeting up with friends is easier. + A lot of interaction with other players, there's always one telling you where to look out/hunt for pirates.+ Battle from a port. You don't have to sail ages to get in a big battle with multiple ships,you just can hop right in one using the tab in any port. + Fairly balanced. + You can create multiple characters, but your progerss is bound to your steam id, this makes it easy to change factions if you've got a friend willing to help. + Durability system for your ships, you won't lose it after it's sunk the first couple of times. ++ Epic large battles :DCONS : - It takes a fair amount of time to get from one place to the other, there's no teleport system. (kinda understandable, as it'd be unrealistic)- Leveling up takes a long time if you're on your own. - Open world graphics are a bit worse than the battle graphics. - Hard to begin with. (Early stages of the game are a bit meh)- Repetative missions.- Crew is way to expensive.- People who play on the pirate faction and board you :( (If you're with friends, always team up when on a trade mission).- Uninteresting UI.

number of helpful: 66 of 114 people (58%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								Man, I was so hoping to really like this game, and for the most part, it isn't "bad". It's an EA game, that seems to have it's "goals" set a little low, and unwilling to improve it.The ship combat is top notch. No doubt about that. They spent two years polishing the combat, and it shows. But, with a 10 man team, and 2 years to get this combat down, seems slow, even for just 10 guys. The ship models are sharp, great looking..BUT..The damage model is lacking. All you get is some torn sails, and holes in the hull that look like bulletshots in a wall on COD. No real destruction, no gaping holes, no little guys going flying(which isnt really needed), and the fire that can break out, looks dated at best. Sure, you have to aim your shots, and you have different "modes" of firing them. Plus if you want to maximize your turning, you have to manualy turn your sails. (There is an "auto skipper" that can do this, but it isnt going to work if you play any pvp). There is a thread on the forums, on steam, where the Dev's "answer" some questions. And, most questions (granted some are a little ridiculous, but most questions seemed to ask about things that could only improve a MMO. And, the answers were; "Maybe, could, Dont know, and it's in there already"..Not what I would call answers to any of them. Yeah, some things may be out of reach for a small 10 man team. But, some things sould be very do-able, and were/are shot down, for "reasons". With a mini-game boarding action, and can't be bothered to give you any map tools (because it's "Hand Holding")I find that this game is going to be very over priced.In my opinion, if you are going to make the "next" Pirates of the Burning Sea, but realistic. You need some MMO aspects that people can get behind. Not, just a great "feeling" in battle. If that was their main focus, they should have just kept their "Battle Arena" game they were working with, and left the MMO part to other games. It could have been a great 1700's "World of Sail", like World of Warships...And, left it at that.This review may change later, if I can tell that they will get rid of this idea that making a game unnaturally difficult, in  disguise because they call it hand holding. (Which I feel like its more because it would be a pain in the ___ for a 10 man team) And, spend the time, or hire more Dev's to help, because it will be lacking a lot, if they don't. (It's not like they couldn't afford it with 40$ a pop)So, the pvp/pve action battles: Id give a 8 out of 10the trading(which they say they are working on, they probably are) 3 out of tenThings to make it feel like a MMO: 2 out of 10I would wait!(Update) Ok..It's been a year since I bought this 40$ game. And, I can't see any real progress. Some towers added, a "Officer" (that I cant tell does anything), s few ships, and some weird crud with the map. (cant even explain the map junk)....10-100 ppl on a server at any given time....Dont waste your money on this title!

A epic battle system Not like in the majority of other games which have a stupid HP system and if the health reaches 0 you are gone. in this game your sides have armor. when recieving DMG the armor will drop and it will be easier to pierce a shot. when the armor is almost gone you can easyly pierce with shrapnell which does a LOT of crew dmg. and it easyer to pierce below the waterline. each penetration you score below the waterline will create a leak when you ship have leaks will will take water but thats no problem. your ship have a PUMP when you are taking water you´ll need to assign a part of your crew to the pumps. and the leaks will be fixed over time. but when your st. pavel ( a very big ship ) will get a whole broadsider of like 40 cannons under his waterline  he´s gone in like 10 sek. but it hard to score hits below the waterline (because , if you didn´t know : its usually UNDER water) there is a easier way to sink a ship: you can just shoot down the armor of one of the sides to 0 . when the aror is gone he will take big amouts of water and will sink in a couple of min.  loosing you Bow or stern armor is not so dramatic. you will need just like 20 men on the pumps all the time to compensate it.in the open world there are lots of harbours. they belong to a couple of fractions. you chose one on start.but if you dont like your fraction, dont worry . you just need to attack a ship of the same frac to turn PIRATE  which are basicly a own fraction. so players can capture enemy ports for there frac. each port produces it own resourses. you can buy them there for cheep and sell them somewere else (this is the AI economy) if a port produces ex. iron ore you also can build there an outpost and build  a iron mine. there you can "buy" it for much cheaper but you also will need labour houres ( you get 42 in one RL h or like 1008 a RL day) .there is a crafting system . you have a separate crafting lvl. so a LVL one (there is no lvl one  but anyway) player can be crafting lvl 50 to craft a ship you need the resourses , the BP a given LVL and LH (labour hours) .  there are some ship Blueprints that are given once reaching a specific crafting LVL. and some you can get by crafting other ship (for ex. i craft a frigate(you get the friagte BP once reached LVL25) and with a chance i will get a Belle poule BP, a ingermanland BP a trincomalle BP and so on.  the chance is based on some factors.mainly on the quality of he ship you are building (there are : basic,comon,fine,mastercraft and exeptinal) there are some ships you need like a week for(if you are doing it alone)p.s. im sorry english isn´t my 1st language . if i done some grammar errors or something else pls excuse me .

content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								Believe the hype.Naval Action offers a borderline simulator experience with its age-of-sail combat gameplay. Take command of anything from a simple schooner to powerful Ships-of-the-Line. Travers a massive map of the Caribbean and experience beutiful sights and sounds of the Age-of-Sail. In-depth naval combat mechanics means you control your yards and aim your cannons all while attempting to manuever and dodge gunfire yourself. Mistime or aim incorrectly and watch your broadside fly over the enemy's deck or hit the sides of a wave insted of the enemy's hull. Misuse your sails and you'll find yourself face-first to the wind and unable to move, am easy sitting target for your enemies.This is NOT a pirate game. This is an Age-of-Sail game. While pirates are a playabe option, they are by no means easy to master. The game offres a challenge while still being fun. As is expected with Early Access, there are still a bit of impurities and imbalance, but even so, the combat system alone is very well honed and can offer some interesting yet not altogether lopsided battles. This is a must for anyone who is interested in the Age of Sail.

								Be it known I have recently gotten the game  (11/3/2016) about the time I got it there was a huge wave of recently negative review's because the player base is Whinging about not being able to build there precious Exceptional ships whenever they like with next to know effort, because that is what they have gotten use too....All I can say is GOOD....  I am also looking forward to the server wipes that WILL come pre-release...This is after all a game in Alpha that is not finished.The fact that this game has recieved so many negative reviews is just a straight up TRAVESTY of epic proportions!But hey its the new generations way, if everything is not handed to the new generation with a silver spoon well lets right a review crying about how dumb the developers are for making the game harder!!!Okay now that I have gotten the above out of the way!  Its time for an honest review....This game is a Masterpiece!!!!  Its not polished, its got alot of tweaking and fine tuning to iron out but the core concepts are rock solid.  Its the first MMO I have started playing in years that has actually hooked me and kept my attention, this is a rare gem.Most games today Pre release in a terrible state, they have nice graphics and thats about it, its like the video game industry has turned into a major cash grab.  This game atleast doesnt leave you feeling cheated...So what is it?Its basically Pirates of the Burning Sea without the Tiny Fast forward OverWorld map...  In Naval Action you still have an over world map and you then zone into the battle but its 1 to 1 so that makes the over world large and spacious its genius really....  Its exactly what PotBS always needed....  So now you can sail around and you may not see another player for 5, 10 , 15 minutes or you might see 6 of them in less then 5 minutes...  So makes for the perfect balance on PvP and PvE all on the same map!  -However Naval action has cut down on the number of ships you see in the over world dramatically compared too PotBS.  This can at times make the world feel empty or dull, but ultimately as a person that loves realism I still love this because its realistic  if you were cruising around the carribean back in this day you would not see ships EVERYWHERE...  -One Major issue with Naval Action is the Over abundance of players with 1rst 2nd and 3rd Rates....  Infact thats like 95% of the playerbase...  And they all seem to have this point of view that its there inherit right to own a 1rst rate...  This really makes the game feel cheesy and gay when everyone is running around in an exeptionally crafter 1rst rate...Thankfully the developers have started to take steps to make exceptional ships harder to make and larger ships harder to make....  This is MUCH NEEDED but it also created all those Negative reviews from the spoiled playerbase complaining about how they had the stuff to make a 1rst rate yesterday and now they don't.... BOO HOO cry more!!!  This game has a vast array of resources, materials, trade commodity's it has the tools and potential to create a game with an economy to rival Eve Online....  However Currently the Economy is broken money is stupidly easy to make, ships are stupidly cheep to buy and the playerbase as a whole is spoiled rotten, and they feel that money is too hard to make???As a new player less then 4 days into the game I have over 3 Million gold which I could use to buy my way into the elite ship club?!?  After 4 days???  And it wasnt hard nor challenging to accomplish this....  So I dont understand all the negative reviews and all the crying....  The Dev's are making steps in the right direction to fix the economy and I pray they stick to there guns and keep going as the Player base is obviously not always right....So overall this is one of the best new MMO's to release in ages....In many ways its everybit as good as PotBS wasIn many ways it needs alot of tweaking and adjusting to make it what could be a Masterpiece.And in many ways its not as good as PotBS....However if you enjoyed PotBS or if you enjoyed Port Royal games or you liked Eve Online...  This game is in Alpha and even in its unfinished state can rival all those games and give you right now an amazingly fun game experience!!!11/28/2016 Update the I still feel the same way about the above review!

number of helpful: 25 of 39 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								First off, this is an early access game. I realize the price is steep for an early access game, but this is quite simply one of the most fun games I've probably ever played, both in the open world MMO genre and in general. I've easily gotten more enjoyment out of it than the last $30-$40 full release titles I've purchased, and the hours speak for themselves.The Awesome:1. Combat is absolutely amazing. It plays somewhat like a chess match, in both large fleet actions and single ship actions. Each side makes a move, to which the other side attempts to counter. In a large battle, this mainly comes down to your side's shot caller attempting to give as many of his ships as possible a shot on the opposing fleet. In single ship fights, much of  the skill comes down to maneuvering to rake your opponent's stern to kill crew and dismount cannon until he can no longer fight, while preventing him from doing the same.  The combat is definitely the most polished part of the game, and it shows.2. Development: I say this mainly because the game already is in development, but I've seen very few games capable of treading the thin line between giving the players what they want, and doing what's best for the players and the game as a whole. These devs have done an amazing job on this, and many player suggestions throughout closed alpha and even early Steam release have found their way into the game. In addition, the development cycle is very regular, with a major content patch around the middle of each month, along with usually 2 ships added to the game. In addition, the devs have added multiple player-made ships to the game.3. The Open World map: This is probably the most important part of the game. The open world map is a scale representation of the Caribbean and Gulf of Mexico, based off of maps from the time period of the game (early 1800s-late 1700s). This is how you get from port to port and find other players to sail or fight with. When engaging other players, your position relative to them and both of your positions in relation to the wind translates directly into the battle instance, making positioning in the OW almost as important as actual combat skill. A recent update now translates any land you may be nearby into the battle as well, meaning cunning captains can pin smaller and nimbler ships against land when they would otherwise be able to sail away unscathed. In addition to that, major fleet AI battles can be found quite easily in the open world as well (but make sure you bring friends).The Not So Awesome (outdated, see EDIT):1. Finding a fight: One of the biggest complaints is the difficulty of finding a fight in the open world. This can be a challenge, but it does depend primarily on where you are trying to find fights. Generally, the closer to Cuba/Jamaica you are, the better the change of finding a fight (this primarily concerns the PVP1 server). Free Ports (uncapturable by any faction) allow you to base ships closer to these areas to get into the action quicker. In addition, duels can be set up in the port screen (just ask around in national or local chat for a dueling partner, and remember your ships must be the same battle rating to duel), which gives a loss-free way to practice handling your ship before jumping into real danger in the open world. 2. Game Economy/Crafting: This is probably the least polished portion of the game, meaning everything I say here is subject to change. The economy is inbetween a full player driven economy and an AI driven economy. Money can be made quite easily by your production buildings, and those resources in turn supply the shipbuilders. Ships require resources to build if you want an above average one, otherwise basic versions with a minor flaw or minor improvement (to speed, crew space, rigging, etc.) can be bought for very affordable prices from the AI. AI only sells up to 4th rate 60 gun ships however, anything larger must be built by a crafter or captured from another player. If your objective in buying the game is to become a major crafter/trader and nothing else, you may want to wait for this feature to mature before purchasing.3. The "Grind": You'll find many reviews that complain about the game's grind. At the end of the day, the game is only a grind if you make it one. Unlike War Thunder, World of XXX, or other arena games where you are forced to play a vehicle  to unlock the next, the only limiting factor in Naval Action is the crew you can command. You start with 40, and this increases as you go through the ranks. You can still purchase any ship on the market if you have the money to do it, and some ships can be used without much downside with less than maximum crew due to crew management mechanics added to the battles shortly after steam release. In addition, the thresholds for how much experience (earned by damaging and sinking/capturing enemy ships in battle) is required for each rank was recently reduced by a large margin. All that being said, don't fall into the trap of thinking "bigger ship = better ship." The captain's skill ultimately decides the battle. Even a cutter (starter ship) can make the difference in an open world battle, and I know this from personal experience.EDIT FOR 9.8 PATCH: With the 9.8 patch, finding a fight in OW is no longer an issue. Teleport timers have been completely removed when going from outpost to outport, allowing players to jump around the map to various hotspots as they please (so long as they have an outpost in the area). This makes it quicker and easier than ever to fight PVP.In addition, ship durability/HP has been compressed, meaning there is no longer as much of a difference in the punishment each frigate can take compared to each other, or for how much each ship of the line can take compared to each other. Also, many new upgrades were added to further allow players to customize their ships, as well as all the other awesome changes in the 9.8 patch notes.

content:
Posted: March 1
Early Access Review
								Bought this original cause of Empire Total War and Darth Mod's additions to it, though while the ship combat is enjoyable and reminiscent of Empire, the overall gameplay is severly lacking. The combat gameplay itself isn't bad, and at times enjoyable even.  Ships sail like proper ships, you can adjust sails individually to pull off specific maneuvers, guns feel solid, ships feel proper for their class, crews are quite a bit lacking specially compared to Empire but they do exist there to provide a semblance of not sailing a ghost ship.Though the issue occurs what happens outside of combat, the UI is primative though that's really nothing that can't be easily fixed.  The game is grindy, quite grindy and overall trys to play like Eve Online.  Deaths matter quite a bit, your ships have durability and once that's gone you lose your ship, it is open pvp though there isn't quite the base there to support it.  PVE is mudane, you spend couple minutes sailing to some designated spot to fight a ship that will spend that entire battle just running away from you which is a valid strategy but doesn't quite make for fun gameplay.  Once that's over you get a trickle of xp, barely some gold and sail back for a couple minutes to rinse and repeat for slow progression.  The game does somewhat allow you to play above your level cap in return for paying into a essentially gold sink in the form of crew members, but the paltry rewards never quite make it worth it.  Beyond that there is a semblance of a crafting system, though it isn't anything spectacular or interesting.  Overall PVE is simply just a chore.  If you're playing for the PVP you may have slightly better luck out of the experience, though pvp relies heavily on the people, but without a proper fundation to build the pvp on your experience may vary.Really a shame given how enjoyable Empire's ship battles were, but in the end this game at it's current state is and unpolished, endless grind that never really seem to get anywhere.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								Just from browsing a few reviews I couldn't believe how many negative reviews this game has gotten. I see people with around 1,000 hours giving it a negative review. How can someone drain that much time into a game and not like it? Doesn't quite add up to me. Obviously there's something good about the game and they're lying their *** off if they can play for a solid 41 days and still say it's crap. Or maybe they're that dense and it takes them that long to realize they don't like something. Other reviews I see people saying it's a boring world and you spend most of your time going from A-B doing nothing and blah blah blah. Do you even know what game you bought? Did you research it at all? Helloooo, it's a 1800's naval game that takes place in a huge ocean and you sail old wooden vessels at 2-18 knots depending on the weather gauge; obviously it's going to take some time getting around. Realistically it could take ships weeks or months to get from A-B, in the game yeah it can take 15-60 minutes depending how long of a voyage you're embarking on.I've seen some reviews saying the devs don't add much. I think they add plenty and are taking their time to get things right. Everytime they add new things I'm always excited for it to patch and get into the game. If they aren't doing enough I think their expectations are too high, not every game is produced with a massive dev team. Some things I've found amazing they've added to the game just off the top of my head are: ship armor thickness, weather systems, seagulls (with sounds), different nations ports have different looks, fishing, they average adding about 2-3 new ships each month, and plenty more.All in all this game is everything and more that I can ask for. Just a few experiences from my voyages in the Caribbean, the other day I stumbled upon Captain Kidd's hideout (not on the map), currently I'm sailing to the Santa Cecilia ship wreck (the location of which I discovered in a sealed bottle), all the while having my crew fish from the sea. Last week I went and visited the American Colonies just to say I had been there. Before taking off to find the lost ship wreck I intercepted a French Essex and also a 3rd Rate Pirate vessel with the help of my brother. It's a great game to play with friends, the community is excellent, and there is more than enough things to do with more and more being added each time a patch comes out every week or so. Don't let the negative reviews fool you, this game is absolutely amazing and I absolutely recommend it to everyone who loves the seas!

number of helpful: 21 of 32 people (66%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								Naval Action. What can I say? Firstly, I had to wait months to buy this game. It isn't cheap, especially when money is tight... $54.87 Australian to be exact. Some may think this isn't much money, but to some it is. Well, even in it's Alpha stage it is more value for money than you can imagine.... less than 14 cents an hour for me at the moment, 14 cents! Is it the right game for you?Do you have an interest in the Age of Sail?Do you like your games to look beautiful?Do you have time to sit back and enjoy a game for what it is, lots of sailing around the Caribbean Sea and the Gulf of Mexico?Are you aware that it is a game under heavy development?Do you enjoy chatting to people from around the world?If your answer is Yes to any or all of these, then Naval Action is the game you have been looking for!Before I continue I must say that I only play on the Player vs Environment (PVE) server at the moment. It is the perfect place to hone your sailing skills, learn to fire your cannons accurately, and learn about the trading and ship building. I will give Player vs Player (PVP) a go when the final game is released.There is something about the mesmerizing movement of the sea that really draws me in. This is so in real life, but also in this game. There are many great Youtube videos around that I watched for hours before I bought the game. I really fell in love with the graphics and sound. I won't link to any particular video, but just do a Youtube search for GrunfWorks or Jeheil.The detail and rendering of these beautiful old ships is second to none. I would love the developers to introduce a cinematic replay option for the battles, that would be fantastic. I have to say there is a certain amount of pride when you finally manage to buld a ship from the next level up and finally get to sail her :)Some other reviewers have said "All you do is sail", or words similar to that. Well, it is a game set in the age of sail, and yes there are many hours of sailing in the "open world", but this is done at 60 times faster than real time. At first I thought this was too fast, but when you look at the sheer size of the map I think the developers got the speed about right.As I mentioned earlier, it is a game that is heavily in development. That isn't a secret. Why would I or anyone buy a game that isn't even finished? This is easy to answer.... because even in it's current stage of development, it is better than many AAA games out there, and it is without doubt the best age of sail game ever produced.Finally, (well almost) I would be lying if I said this game didn't have a steep learning curve, and there is no official game manual or tutorial yet. However, there is a help chat in game that all players of varying levels of experience willingly provide help to rookie players. To say that the player community is helpful is an understatement. It never ceases to amaze me how patient the vast majority of players are when providing support to new and not so new players. No question is too dumb :)I started this review by asking if Naval Action was the game for you. If you have read down this far then I would say don't wait any longer, just buy it!!! It's a great game, great people play it, and it is developed by passionate people.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is awesome ! You get to play beautifull ships in an eve online mmo type environment. Graphics are quite good and immersion is great.Pros :- Naval combat gameplay is great. You have to deal with wind, gravity, penetration, waves... You can damage enemy's sails to harm he's speed, his crew to harm ship handling and canons reload and his hull to sink him. This mix allows a wide variety of tactics, skill is extremely important and you can surprise your enemy by mixing things up.- You can play any way you want. Trade, craft, play pve for lvl ups AND practice (very important before you start pvp).When you pvp you can play as a soldier in the army and work together in the conquest of enemy ports, as a privateer and kill players in hotzones to harm enemy nations, or as a pirate type hunter boarding traders for valuable cargos.- A cruel world : When you loose a battle, you really loose something if you cant escape ; your ship, your cargo, your mens, your officer... But not everything. Ships have several "lives", same for officer, and if you dont play like a fool, you'll manage... But this sensation of "real death" in defeats brings immersive tension to fights.- I cant list everything i love about the game... Just too many.Cons : - An unfinished product : Interface is ugly, rules are changing from patch to patch, but it's all about the early access state of the game. I have no doubt the game will become more user friendly at release.- The relation between OW accelerated time and battles real time. When you sail in open world, time passes faster, your ship moves faster etc. Obviously because if it was not, sailing from one point to another would take way too much time. But battles are played in "real time" so the devs have to find a way to make things fair about this, because you can not allow a player who is 5 hours of real sailing away from his clanmate to be able to join and help him in 5 minutes. Which means the game has to pull some artificial engagement rules to make things fair+fun+realistic. And, this is not polished yet in my opinion but hopefully it will come.

								I was one of the First guinea pigs about a year plus ago when they made it available long before Steam When I bought it, you could only play something called Sea Trails, which was only combat and no open world. I got a bit tired of the wipes, but loved the detail of the ships and the excellent graphics. When it went onto Steam and started "open World" it looked like it had taken 20 steps backward. The whole concept of open world is appealing, but its implimented so poorly, its a struggle to even understand how any of the menus or selections work. I happily played this when it first strarted moving up thru all the ships rather easily without to much gring until you go to some really big stuff. I did enjoy the matches, and the Trafalgar battles wee terrific.As it is now, someone who has not played this game before wont have a clue as to what to to or how to play. Its just awful. At least I had the benefir of having many hours (160) sailing and fighting over a period of 6 months.There is core group of those early players who have gotten to know each other quite well, and many (not all) have that superioity attitude and either ignore, insult, or sealclub the "noobs"The "noobs" a lot of them are going to pass the word about the incredibly horrible interface, the interminable grind and the somewhat toxic environment, not to mention the price they are asking.This is  a GREAT sailing ship fighting game, it overeached on its goals and regretfully is going to disappont a lot of people.I

content:
Posted: May 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								This is an amazing "Sim" set in the 18th century. Man-o-Wars, Frigates, Brigs, and so on. Even named vessels are available, such as the Essex, the Constitution and the Victory. (and more)For an early access game this game is pretty well polished. A nice selection of ships for the state of the game from 7th Rate all the way to 1st Rate.The graphics are beautiful. The water looks spectacular, and thats a good thing for a ship game. The Ship models look outstanding as well. Then there is combat; when those cannons flash out in front of you and you lose all direction from the gun smoke rolling across the water, and as the cannons impact you can watch sails tatter and shrapnels of wood spray into the air. Just amazing.The main practice of the game is warfare (both PvE and PvP), however there are rather good trading and crafting elements built into the game as well. A sort of... Elite Dangerous but with boats.I do recomend this game, however be warned, this game is a time sink. Even traveling around the map can take hours of sailing. A larger battle can also take upwards to an hour sometimes more, but this game is not boring even with the lengthy battles and travel times.Overall I look forward to what this game has to offer in the future as even in its current state it is very playable and Ive already sunk (<- ship pun) hours of time into it.

content:
Posted: April 9
Early Access Review
								Disclaimer: I am a age-of-sail combat fanboi. Have been since I read Hornblower when I was age 6.That said, Naval Action delivers everything I expected and more when it comes to ship and fleet combat. The sailing and gunnery mechanics are intricate without becoming unmanageable, different ships behave very differently. Particularly in PvP engagements, combat for me is tense, even though it moves at a relatively sedate pace.The open world and the RvR meta-game is where Naval Action leaves little middle ground between love and hate. Personally, I like playing in a clan and dabbling in grand strategy, but I get my main kicks out of ship combat. As such, the major mechanics and balancing shifts that took place on the strategic, RvR level do not tick me off as much as they understandably did some players who are in it for the strategic conquest before anything else.Thus buyers will need to beware that the game is in Alpha, and therefore the center of balance is still shifiting around (particularly on the strategiclevel). I have been abaoard through a number of changes that the players consider quite fundamental, and they have not diminished my enjoyment. Rather, meaning I have to re-think standard recipes every now and again keeps me on my toes.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								I have bought the game back in November/December 2014. I liked the period, but was a bit sceptical, especially when combined with a paypal payment method and was just willing to try it.How much was I mistaken. It is my most played game on steam right now. I did hunt AI ships alone. I did chase player ships off the perceived turf with a group. For a time I was the one of lucky few, who were able to build HMS Surprise. I did successfully trade iron, when there was almost none left in the whole carribean. I went to the edge of the world. I met people that were nice and crude, honorable and dishonorable, dauntless captains as well as cowards. Does this appeal to you? If yes, this game might be just for you. HOWEVER, you have to be willing to overlook some substantial flaws, at least for a time. Terrible UI. No help, if you don't search for it/ask. You have to be willing to accept behavioural standards of the community (courteous, gentlemenly). You have to be willing to learn. You have to be able to think of the battles as battles, not as the grind. 2nd HOWEVER, you get an opportunity to participate in the development of the game you have been waiting for for the last 10-15 years, due to the great devs, who really listen. (I can pinpoint some features that are in the game to originate with specific players and specific posts on the forums).I will not tell you if the game is right for you. For me, best 40 EUR I spend on a game. For an early access title 9/10.

number of helpful: 14 of 20 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								I have never written a proper review for a game on Steam before, but I feel as if I have to for this game.In short, it's beautiful. The Open world is gorgeous and seemingly full of activity that ranges from lone/grouped pirates on the hunt, AI fleets or trade ships are full of cargo and are ready to be plundered. The map is stacked full of visitable ports/cities (as long as your nation has a hold of it).The combat is in-depth and can be complex. That being said it can also be forgiving against the AI and the game developers allow you to have unlimited free repairs for the beginning ship which gives you the freedom to test your skills without punishing you. Everything from the winds direction, the waves & the caliber/type of your guns can affect the course of a battle significantly, which adds an unexpected element to the battles. Does your enemy have long range cannons or Carronandes? Are you Up wind or Down wind? Is there a storm at the moment, or is the ocean calm? This all adds a unique experience to each and every battle which personally, keeps me drawn in.PVP is awesomly fun, with both open world PVP or Small/Large battles you que up to and play in. They are generally 10v10 for small battles and 25v25 for large battles, which can get hectic but are always fun. Teamwork plays a major factor, shepherding ships across friendly broadsides, keeping the ship distracted while a friendly rakes their stern or even assisting in boarding by grape shotting the enemy ship (careful not to hit your friendlies).The ship designs are wonderful, even though I would prefer to be able to see my crew during the open world sailing. Each ship has different characteristics, some being hulks with more guns or corvettes built for speed which allows the player to explore with their prefered traits. The crafting system also allows players to construct and modify ships to add special abilities. For example, a Snow- typically a slower ship- can have upgraded rigging and be built out of a lighter wood, which will increase it's speed for a lack of armor.I would prefer if they added some in-game music from the era, but I usually just remedy that with some youtube of either the Assassins Creed Black Flag sea shanties or some classical music from Mount and Blade: Napoleonic Wars.The community is wonderful and always ready to help, which is quite rare in my mind. It may be because the game has a bit of a learning curve that it deters people who would rather "troll" then play properly. Some people have been around for a long time, and some since the steam release and they integrated quite easily to form a very solid community that I am happy to be apart of.Overall I honestly suggest this game even though it's in early access. It is not one to miss if you are in love with the era or if you are naval fanatic like I am. If not and are hoping to dabble into the genre, this is a great start - the game is forgiving to new players & the community is willing to help teach you the basics.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								My review - From my experience in the early alphaFirst of all i wish to state that the community of the game has been amazing and the developers have been listening very well to us. I have been following this game ever since early 2014 and it's grown to a very enjoyable game.PLEASE NOTE: This game is not made for the impatientThe game requires atleast a decent interest in ship combat and sailing, you need to navigate yourself, the combat is made realistically. It is not an arcade, note that if you just want to kill, kill, kill this game won't be a good game for you.First of all, the graphics look fantastic. Probably the best looking game I've ever seen in the Unity engine. The Open world currently does look a little worse than the battles, but this is understandable for performance reasons. The game runs decently, haven't had any issues to achieve a solid 60FPS. Yet the dev's stated they would improve performance in the future so no worries about that.The ships are beautiful and detailed, just look up the trincomalee in the game, and irl. It looks identical. Honestly amazing how detailed the ships have become. I hope to see more crew on deck in the future. More activites there would be nice.The sound design is AMAZING, it sounds like you are actually in an 18th century sea battle, the smoke really adds to the battles aswell. Couldn't be more perfect.Overall the battles feel very complete already, it is the open world which does require a bit of work. Of course, the UI can be confusing at first, and it does not look the greatest. It is not the priority, and we understand this. The UI is something to improve on definitely. Another negative thing about the game is that there is currently no tutorial. So finding out what to do can be a bit tricky at first. So please use the help chat in game, someone almost instantly helps you on there.The open world is a WIP and that is clearly visible, and this is most likely where the developers will focus on in Early Acces, so you will mostly see that progress.Overall, I bought the game on a Thursday and within a week I had played over 100 hours. A recommendation for sure, dedicated dev's, good communication with the community. Best Naval game out there right now!

content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								First off, I must say that I have been called a “Fan boy” many times.  However, I seek to give an honest review that contains the good and the bad, so that people know what they are getting into, and whether the price tag is right for them.FeaturesAuthentic Age of sail naval combat game that blends realism and gameplay for an enjoyable and unique experience.  Era of game:  mid 1700s to the 1820s.  It is not a sim.  It is not an arcade.  It is not fully realistic nor fully historical, but a blend of all these.  Authentic and Addicting Combat SystemNaval Action features one of the most beautiful and authentic Age of Sail combat systems to date.  Every cannonball, every wave, and many parts of the ships are all tracked to see where the ball hits.  Accuracy is not based upon rng or a magical skill number but actual gunnery, which is your own ability to judge the following three things:  the distance between you and the target, the characteristics of your smoothbore cannons, and the pitching and rolling of your ship through the waves.  I don’t know if this is well known or not, but I have hit the wheel of enemy ships and seen their ship go into “rudder shock,” which means they cannot turn.No artifical skillsThere are no skills to artificially train.  Instead of training skills at level up, you yourself have to get better at the game.  Whether it is knowing when, how and where to maneuver in battle, your ability to process the tactical situation, your own personal skill at gunnery, the way you position your ship while under cannon fire, or your ability to navigate the world, this game is all about how good you, your friends, and your enemies are. Your hand is not held by the game, but you will find the community is typically helpful if you have questions on how to do something.Open World (OW)Explore a massive world that would take weeks to fully explore.  It is time compressed because otherwise it would take days of real time sailing just to go between ports, let alone the weeks needed to cross the Caribbean.  How it is right now, it takes 4-12+ hours of real time sailing to cross the map.  Travel can be long.  Local knowledge of the area, the channels, shallows, and hiding spots are all vital. However, at the moment, the islands can seem a little boring beyond the majestic views.  There is dynamic weather and you can get lost, especially in storms and heavy fog.  Venturing out of sight of land for the first time can be a little intimidating.  MapThere is a very rough ingame map that shows the ports.  The devs plan to beautify the map once UI is decided upon.  There is no “You are Here” marker.  You will have to keep track of that yourself.  Navigation is a skill you will want to learn if you want to venture outside the Arena.  It is extremely daunting at first but easy to pick up.  Soon you will be pretty good at it.  The map lacks navigation tools.Battle InstancesBecause every shot, every wave, and detailed parts of the ships are all tracked by the server, battles have to be instanced. Instances can have up to 50 ships, whether they are small cutters or ships of the line.  Shallows and land do not appear in battle yet but is planned.Realistic Sailing ModelSailing in the battle instances is fairly realistic and authentic. To tack properly (turn through the wind), you have to learn manual sailing. Easy to pick up, fairly easy to master. It becomes second nature, like learning manual shift in vehicle.  UIBattle Instance UI is pretty good in my opinion. I am a minimalist when it comes to UI. I don’t want all the extra crap blocking my view of the beautiful ships and environment. The Open World and Port UI are horrible (tech demo). I wish Game Labs would have spent a week polishing it a little before Early Access. The UI will be finished later. They don’t want to spend a lot of time working on something that will have to be redone in the future.Economy and CraftingThe economy and crafting is basic, but every time I turn around, something new has been added and fleshed out. Don’t fall into the pitfall of buying crafting resources from NPC ports and selling them to NPCs. Sell to players or build your own stuff to sell. That is where the money is. Crafting and trading takes time, experience, and a lot of gold, but the payout is good.Boarding CombatThere are no avatars.  You cannot walk about your ship.  When you board the enemy, a tactical mini game appears.  Some people compare it to Rock Paper Scissors.  Some like it, some hate it, I think it is fine.  If this is a deal breaker, watch YouTube first before you buy.PVEThere is Player Vs Environment (AI).  The AI can be difficult at first, even very difficult.  But they soon become easy and boring once you get to know them.  There is a pve only server if you don't want to play against players.PVPThis is where the heart of the game is. Expect Ganks. Expect great 1v1 fights. Expect on-the-edge-of-your-seat group fights, where teamwork and skill is needed to clutch victory from defeat. This is the addicting part of the game.Port Battles:Right now port battles only consist of a few towers that you have to destroy along with any player defenders that show up. There is no land yet or proper forts, but these are being worked on.  A successful port assault will change the current owner to your nation.  Do not open player outposts in national ports except the capital city. All other national ports can be captured and you will lose access to anything in the port until it is recaptured. Port captures are way too frequent (negative).ArenaThere is an arena option available.Technically you never have to access the open world if you don't want to. Battle seems daunting at first, but in the Arena you can practice in a low stress environment with the free basic ships. Combat is easy to get the hang, very difficult to master.  ProgressionYou start with a small cutter.You can progress to a ship of the line.The progression can be long.  Just pvp and have fun; no need to grind. You will get into the larger ships in due time and you will want to learn the game first. This game is all about the process.Forget the end game. If you get to the end game without learning the game you will cry when your extremely expensive ship ends up on the bottom of the ocean or in someone else’s dock. If you grind, it isnt any worse than WoWS.PriceThe price is expensive for an early access game. But in my opinion, it is very worth it. At almost 2000 hours, I have paid about 2 cents an hour to play Naval Action.StabilityEven though the game is Early Access, I haven't had any crashes in almost a year. It is very stable on my machine. There are annoying bugs from time to time and very rarely something is wrong with the server. Other people report crashes but those are usually people who don't meet the minimum requirements. People do report fps problems. People say the game is poorly optimized, but with a 980 ti, I get 70-100fps on Open World and typically 100+ fps in battle.  I play on 1920x1080 and ultra.You only get 1 character per serverNegatives/needs work/I dream of:No crew managementOW and Port UIPort Battles are a new feature and are still very roughNo land in battlesNo navigation tools where your skill as a navigator mattersOnly Basic clan features.Port Captures are way too frequentOW needs some little details to make it varied and interestingNo built in tutorials or manualNo reputation system yetPositivesBattles are amazingAddicting pvpRealistic sailing modelWell developed damage modelBeautiful shipsLearning curve means you are always learning new things.  After almost 2000 hours, I am still learning new things.Immense and impressive Open WorldEra is set in the Napoleonic period and golden age of sail instead of the overdone golden age of piracyThe best Age of Sail game I have ever played

content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've been playing Naval action for a bit now. I'd like to say that I could endorse this pretty looking game but I can't.There are quite a few unsavory elements to the game. And here's a few.1. Unrealistic and overpowered AI.The NPC ships in the game routinely break nearly EVERY sailing rule of physics in the book, maneuvering like hydrofoils even in a headwind. And if THAT isn't bad enough, their gunnery puts even present day warships with their guided missiles to shame with a near 90% hit rate even at extreme range with maybe 2 out of every 3 hits landing criticals. Also they seem to have a higher rate of fire than most players.The devs DID recently reduce the AI accuracy on small ships such as cutters and brigs hoping that less experienced players won't notice that all frigates and SoTLs still have the "sniper elite" level AI and dance around like fairies.2. Toxic and hostile player community.The game is supposed in alpha stage, which means that people playing the game are supposed to be providing feedback and making suggestions. However the player community will usually try to shout down player suggestions, throw insults and name-calling around, and attempt to derail the suggestion thread by leading it off topic into wild and immature tangents. They also seem to celebrate on the forums when frustrated players announce their intention to leave <like good riddance or don't let the door hit you in the *** on the way out, etc>.3. Devs alienate PvE and Independent players.With only a single PvE server and no access to alt characters if you want to experience something new, for example playing another nation or just plain want to play a new character they give you only 2 options either completely delete your old character and make an entirely new one sacrificing all your gold, ships, crafting resources and all that even though you still retain both your rank and crafting xp or be forced onto a PvP server where only 3 of their 7 or 8 playable nations are even viable and where ganking and griefing runs rampant.They claim that this is designed to prevent economic exploitation but that kind of exploitation already exists in the game in the form of the current guild activity.4. They are setting the stage for total disaster for the game economy and solo playability with their future economic goals.In their most recent patch they did away with player ability to sail captured warships. Instead players now have to auto turn in warships they have captured in boarding combat over to their respective nation's admiralties for a tiny sum of gold and only allowing players to commandeer merchant ships. They also have future plans to completely do away with NPC resource vendors and allowing players to have the complete run of the economy. This action coupled with the canned ability to sail captured warships will inevitably open the door to massive overpricing of ships, and other items and make it impossible for any independent player to survive and be competitive.It's like Pirates of the Burning Sea all over again.....Perhaps even worse.At least portalus games has since begun to offer means of solo player survivability (if only to line their own pockets with real-world cash).With this all said I can not in good conscience recommend this game to anyone.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								NOTICE:  This is a Early Access Review.By the time of this writing I have played 894 hours in this game, and one of the leading commanders of the Dutch Antilies Squadron.  I've enjoyed this game a lot through it's development and progress, however, you need to know about this game before you get into it.  Spend a week or two reading the fourms, watching videos on YouTube and such, and you should be well aware what this game is about before you perchase it.  Naval Action is a beautiful and entertaining game with a mostly decent community, therefore, you should want to know what you are getting into before getting it.This game is not fully fleshed out yet, and many features are still yet to be developed, such as a port UI, official in-game diplomacy, proper economy, and provisions.  Development with the game is slow, and requries patience. This review is not about the individual features of the game, but how this game is largerly operated by most of the community.Naval Action is an Open World Naval Combat game.  The game's era is between 1750 and 1820, therefore, this is not a galleon, sea-dogs and pirate game.  Instead, it is more of a game of national sepremacy from the Seven Years War to the French Revolutionary and Napoleonic era.  Right now, the map is the Carribean, Gulf of Mexico and lower seaboard of the American coastline,  but don't be dismayed, it's plenty big enough right now, as it will take hours to sail from one side of the map to the other.This game is not a game where you can log in an expect a quick and decent battle however.  Battles themselves can take 30 minutes easily, and not to mention the amount of time looking for a target to attack.  If you want to play this game properly, you need to set aside an entire afternoon.Most of the real fun in this game are the large national fleets fighting for conquest.  These are largely operated by organizations, for example The Decatur Armada and Tattered Flags for the Americans, the Sea Lords Royal Navy for the British, Enfants du Roy for the French, and the Dutch Antillies Squadron for the Dutch (as well as many other groups, more information for them are on the Naval Action fourms).  Most of these organizations opperate off of a TeamSpeak 3 server to allow for communications.  Some are more strict than others, and is up to your prefernce.  These organizations however will try their best to help you through the ranks and teach you all the qualities of seamanship you need for Naval Action. The real excitement are the large ship battles that will occur as rival nations clash with each other on their borders in large battles for sepremacy in the Caribbean.But yet again, people need to be aware that war is not fair.  If you sail away from areas protected by your nation, you are a free target for any other nation or player to attack you, fairly or not.The fact is, the most important decision that you will ever have in this game is which faction you are going to pick at the very start. Some factions are easy due to the sheer number of players, like the British and the Pirates due to their sheer numbers, while others are thrown in the middle of the most contested waters in the game, such as the Danes, Swedes and the French.  Spain will forever be a target for the more expanively minded nations until they get a population, while the Americans and Dutch will be cursed in the early game due their lack of ports and resources.  Currently, there is not official diplomacy implemented between the nations and all are theoretically at war.  Diplomacy is largely crated by the player organizations.  For example, the Dutch and the Danish organizations are allied with each other, even though theoretically they are at war with each other in the game.  Therefore, it is wize to learn about which organizations are allied with which, and which ones are at war.In conclusion, at the current state of the game, and particularly on the PvP server, the best way to treat this game is a battle for National Sepremacy.  Each nation has its own story: the Swedes, a story of survival; the Spanish, a story of prevervation; the Americans, a story of expansion; the British, a story of sepremacy; the Danes, a story of progress; the French, a story of unity; the Dutch, a story of achievement; and the Pirates, a story about too much rum and watching the world burn.  These nations may or may not achieve the stories the way that they wish, but they are the vital core of the game right now.  It is these nations and the people that follow them that make this game what it is.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								Good! But Slow. I'm not opposed to a 'grind' in a MMO.  I like when games make you work for it, and you have something  to strive for.  This game does that well when it comes to ships, and levels.  What I mean by slow, is the combat itself.  Sure you can destroy a small ship with a large ship with ease, but when it takes 20 minutes for a group of players to kill one large ship, it's just silly, and feels like a big waste of time.  The biggest pain point is that when you destroy a side of a ship, it WILL sink.  There is nothing they, or you can do about it.  You can slow the death by going into survival mode, but death is inevitable.  So my question is. WHY NOT JUST SINK ALREADY! You cannot accelerate the sinking any faster.  If the armor is down on the ship, and you keep hitting the ship, it doesn't matter at all.  Just pound away for 3 minutes and the inevitable happens, or just turn sail and ride away and wait for it to sink.  JUST SINK, EXPLODE, DIE!  The combat is good.  High skill based shooting, and strategy.  I've been playing solo, so it's not been nearly as fun as it would be with friends, like most games.  I do see a lack of end game in the current state of the game.  You pretty much progress in ships and xp for it's own sake.  The only end game I see is either just disrupting other countries with groups of players killing them, or taking ports, which is difficult, but relatively boring.Players of POTBS or BBO will see a lot of resemblence in this game, although this game seems more shallow, with less to do.  The boarding function is clicking what you want to do, not actually doing it.  No 'adventure' type thing.  No land based gameplay at all. (granted that was pretty lame in POTBS but it did add depth. Land combat which was boarding combat, farming, gathering ect.)Community is solid enough.  Lots of questions get answered pretty quickly, and you will have LOTS of questions your first week.  I'd definitely reccommend it if you are playing with friends, and hopefully the devs will come out with some more engaging things in the future, rather than running boring/slow missions, and fighting fleets for the sake of fighting fleets.  PvP is good, and fun, but also rather meaningless unless you go out and hunt players which will not be worth any kind of reward for the most part.

content:
Posted: April 19
Early Access Review
								I used to love this game, I played countless hours grinding so I could join my clanmates in port battles, which were quite enjoyable. I participated in the weeks long Aves campaign from the British side, this campaign started as gudfights of ships of the line and degenerated into the enemy yoloing cheap, big ships (Constitutions) into our ships of the line to sink them for minimal effort. This was due to the fact that the devs broke the damage scale for ramming, go figure. That particular update kept many 2nd and 1st rates in ports for some time because people were too scared of losing them to a yolo-ram, and for good reason.The community varies from useful to toxic, most unaffiliated players are toxic, useless, trolls, alt accounts from a player of another nation, or a mix of anything previously stated. Speaking of which, alt account abuse is rampant. Get ready for some sorry neckbeard to ruin your day by doing some dumb♥♥♥♥♥♥in a default ship.I have not played this game again until recently due to news of the upcoming wipe. I am now cautiously returning because I do not wish to invest too much time in a game I am incredibly skeptical about.With all of that said, here are the pros and cons! Notice the effort I put into cons, take that into consideration.Pros:Amazing sailing and combat mechanics - there is no better sailing ship battle game out thereAccurate models and ship handlingCons:The devs are absolute ♥♥♥♥ing mongs and only know how to make extreme decisions. They refuse to make gradual changes to see how things go. Instead they go balls to the wall and completely overhaul some system because 4 people on the forum complained about something.Very slow game to play, get ready to invest a♥♥♥♥♥♥ton of time into the game before you get to do anything fun. I didn't have the level to crew a 3rd Rate Ship of the Line until roughly 300 hours in, but I did take a little bit of a long way to get there.The Pirate Nation is broken - they get all of the benefits of being a nation such as location bonuses to skills, trade, ship building, etc. while retaining the ability to be a massive middle finger to anything and everything. Get ready to have your ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ christened by a big ol group of pirates, because it's going to happen, a lot.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								If there was ever a game with so much potential, it'd be Naval Action.  By far and away the best sailing experience you will get out of a computer game. The finer parts of what the Devs have accomplished thus far would certainly be the optimization and multiplayer integration. Both of these two key features make the game a pleasure to play both alone and with others. The ship combat is amazing, firing a broadside into an enemy ship's hull is one of the most satisfying things in the game. The sound of the cannons is perfect and you can hear them roll out across the water like they should. The ships themselves are marvelous to look at and the scenery around them is wonderful. The only gripes I have with the game are the boarding experience is a bit lacking at the moment and the UI is underwhelming however the Devs have stated that it is only temporary. The game overall is wonderful to play and I would highly recommend the game if you are into the age of sail.

Early Access Review
								This is one of the best games I have ever played, hands down. I started a year ago in Sea Trials and recently came back to it while sparingly playing in between.If you are a fan of simulation then you'll absolutely love the game due to the physics of sailing and combat. While the game isn't fully fleshed out in terms of "content" it makes up for it by the skill cap of fighting, for me at least. There is a great feeling once you understand the mechanics of sailing and put them into action. The game has an incredible open world at the time of review and it is ever changing as nations control and fight over territory. The graphics are beautiful with small details like cabin lights at night reflecting off of the water, waves, and the horizon.Whether you are a sandbox enthusiast or you enjoy quick battles queue style (they have these too!) I would fully recommend picking this game up as there is depth to the combat which is rewarding if you stick with it.

number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								Although being in Early Access, Naval Action has a very good foundation upon which the game is being built upon. They started with the very basics by first developing, fleshing out and testing the combat module years ago. It is clear that this is where Naval Action shines.It's not a true simulator by any means, however, it takes whatever realism it can and molds it into a fantastic gameplay experience. Sailing mechanics such as manually controlling the yards is extremely fun and rewarding as your maneuvering the battlefield trying to line up a perfect broadside. Constantly keeping an eye on the direction of the wind, the angle of your yards, the angle and direction of your targets yards and ship. Outmaneuvering your opponent can be a truly rewarding experience and most definitely will help you in coming out on top and surviving a battle.The 'overworld', or 'open world' part of Naval Action is very much so a work-in-progress. However, it shows us the potential of Naval Action as a large-scale war between multiple nations trying to outsmart eachother through stategical prowess and manipulating the political landscape. Naval Action has a long way to go but it has shown us that the concept works, beautifully so, and they plan to make it so much better.Albeit a tad bit pricey for being an Early Access game, I personally believe it to be one of the best we've seen thus far. So if you like the Age of Sail in general, perhaps the masterpiece film 'Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World', the great series 'Black Flag', you might want to check out this game.

number of helpful: 18 of 29 people (62%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								The Flash of light, a billow of smoke, and the crash of splintering wood! Naval Action is an Amzing Age of Sail sandbox world! The map is HUGE! reaching from halfway up the United States Caost, all the way down to the north shore of South America!  The Islands are so accuratly mapped, if you get lost you can compare the island's shape to a map and find wehre you are! =oDGameplay: The ships have a nice balance between action and simulation. Wind profile and hull design are taken into account... and improving all the time as the game devlops. Available nations to sail for are; USA, Britain, France, Denmark, Holland, Spain, Sweeden, and of course... Pirates!Combat: Can get very intesise! The ships handle well in combat and can be sunk or caprtured in battle, and via several difernt methods! =oDComunity / Moderators; Ive been playign this game sicne it began in closed alpha... these guys in game are some of the funnest and funniest players around! Ever group has some bad apples but the Moderators are active and take thier role seriously... which keeps the community happy and having fun. I consider them to be the best iI've ever dealt with.   Pros: Immersive sandbox world of immense proportions! Good sounds. Good variety of ships to buy/craft/steal. Ecconomics for those who want to be a trader captain. Fun and lively group, most of whom respect skilled players and are very noob friendly. Port battles for the war mongerers... stealing ships for the pirate inclined fellows. Arr har har!   Cons: Still some growing pains in combat mechanics, some things get out of balance. The ability to have AI ships escorting players dilutes the PVP experience.Over all 4/5, and likely to improve with age.

number of helpful: 18 of 29 people (62%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21
Early Access Review
								Firstly, do not buy this game. I know it looks awesome, but it's not. Now lets get into the reasons why.GAMEPLAYI had originally been watching this game since before the open world was created. It looked incredible. I thought this was the game I had been dreaming about for ages. I bought it as soon as it became available on steam; however, life got in the way and I never really had a chance  to play it until half a year later.  At first, I thought the game was great. However, I soon realized that this WAS NOT the game I had been watching for almost a year. First, I was thrown into a poorly designed open world system that slows every aspect of the game down. I had no idea how to get started or what to do. Thankfully, the community was there for me. As I slowly (and I can't emphasize slowly enough) worked my way up to larger ships, I became increasingly annoyed. Where was the huge PVP combat? Where were all the other players? When do I get to fight a ship that isn't a bot? All of this was supposed to exist in the game, but didn't. Granted, I sometimes saw allied players, and I had also encountered gank squads composed of high level players camping outside ports. But I never saw any of the real PVP combat I had drooled over on youtube. In the current build of the game, You will spend 90% of the time sailing, 5% in port, and 5% fighting incredibly overpowered bots that will hit your boat ship no matter how far you are away. PVP is a joke, simply because there is none. Henceforth, I shall refer to the game as Naval Inaction, as that should be it's proper title.UPDATESIn Naval Inaction, updates are unreliable. The devs refuse to listen to the community, WHICH IS CRITICAL in an early access niche game like this. Instead, the devs continue to pursue their idea of what the game should be. The only problem is they don't know what their game should be, or where to go from here, so they keep pushing out updates that don't focus on anything specifically, so nothing is ever fixed. The community of this game has several great ideas of where the game could go from here. Unfortunately, however, the community is almost never listened to, and so Naval Inaction continues to remain in limbo, progressing nowhere while experiencing a steady decline in player population.The devs also are also known to release unreliable information about upcoming patches. For instance, a gamewide shipwipe was announced in late 2016. The devs claimed the wipe would occur in December or January, but no wipe has happened yet. To my knowledge, the devs have not released any information about this failure. EDIT: The devs released information about the shipwipe on the community hub two hours before the time of this edit. DEVELOPER ABUSE/CENSORSHIP"Sensorship reflects a society's lack of confidence in itself"Potter Stewart"The first condition of progress is the removal of censorship"George Bernard ShawIf you have read other steam reviews, many players are accusing the devs of censorship on the Gamelabs forums. Some reviews provide proof of censorship. While I personally have not experienced censorship, I feel I must bring up this topic. Developer censorship of differing opinions is a serious problem. In my opinion, people who have purchased this game (which is not a cheap) have a right to express their views freely. The developers have a responsibility to respect and listen to their playerbase, not throw it in the back of the closet. Without the players, afterall, the developers would have nothing. If the developers truely care about their product they must respect the rights of those who purchased it. This is why I think the Developers DO NOT CARE  about their product any longer. The game has gone nowhere for almost 3/4ths of a year, despite several updates. At this point, I feel the game has been abandonded and the devs are hoping people will continue buying the game. This is essentially fraud, but the devs avoid this by providing low-effort patches every few months. Naval Inaction is seemingly nothing more than a scam at this point in time.CONCLUSIONDo not buy this game. It is not worth the price, and the developers do not deserve the money due to the behavior they exhibit towards the community. If you really feel you must buy this game, buy it, leave a negetive review, then refund it.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								Well, a friend has been going about this for some time, and being a fan of wooden ships myself finally got to try it.WOW. This, this is a really great find for fans of the era, or just looking for something different. Some things you must have a basic understanding of before you play.. or you will be really frustrated... You will / can learn but better to admit to yourself what level you are before rage quiting.. take that frustration and learn how.. its not so hard.1. Real compass to map navigation. There are no giant quest guides. No mini map route to use. You have a map. You have a compass. Terms like S by SE begin to come clear.  If your in the deep water, landmarks dont exist.  You have your compass, the sun and you have to think about how long you have been sailing and speed.2. Sails / tacking etc.. The physics are pretty good in what I have seen. Fortunately you do have wind direction available on your compass.. a little knowledge of sails goes a looooong way.  Also remember.. these vessels dont stop, accelerate or turn on a dime. It takes the crew a moment to make sail changes also.Combat is really well done. Cannons, various ammo types of the time, shipboard musket fire.. boarding.. The tide is with us, the wind fair, cast off!
