content:
Posted: March 9
Early Access Review
								It´s currently in dev limbo, slow and small updates, not the nicest of Devs but a small and helpfull community. If you are willing to stomach the really steep learning curve, invest some time into this game and are able to make friends and join a gaming group, you´ll have some decent fun in challenging PvP matches. The solo-experience is rather bad, NPC Ship combat ranges from pretty decent to downright abysmal, trading and crafting are basically Travel Simulator and looking at Excel-The Game. The open map... serves its purpose. it´s big, it has a lot of ports, islands and NPCs to make the vast Carribean sea feel somewhat alive but that´s about it. You can fish while you travel, but the fishing is a completely passive process based on RNG. The Combat feel is unparalleled. The ships handle great, it feels very realistic and hitting a full broadside, watching the splinters fly and seeing the enemy sinking is really damn satisfying. So: If you´re coming for the combat: Prepare to stomach a steep learning curve and sometimes tedious NPC fights to be rewarded with splendid looking, well modeled ships and a nice community trhowing PvP events from time to time. If you´re coming for the sailing: It´s only the "real deal" in combat, the world map sailing is basic WASD maneauvering. Don´t come for the rest, that´s not really fleshed out (yet)Conclusion: Do not buy this at full price. It´s not worth the money in it´s current state and the propability of reaching such a state is there, but it will take time, likely lots of it. Grab for a Tenner on sale if you are in dire need of age of sail naval battle simulations but that´s about it, after all it´s still alpha/beta/hatever you call the early access state limbo steam does nowadays. Do i recommend it? Yes-no. The battles are fun but incredibly challenging, they can take well over an hour, expecially in smaller vessels with 4-6 guns per side. Large-scale Big-ships-brawling is damn sexy tho, but it takes a harsh grind to get there. 5/10, room for improvements, might be improved in the (near) future.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								I purchased Naval Action via their website just before the Steam Early Access release. In general I have been pleasantly surprised at the current quality of the game. I have logged 30 hours on this and game has never crashed on me or become unplayable. I have experienced the odd bug but the devs seem to work quickly to resolve them. The game itself in its current state has plenty to do. The joy of sailing around an Open World Caribbean is there. You join a nation and are essentially at war with all other nations (attacking your own nation’s ships, unless they are carrying contraband, makes you a pirate for life). So whether it’s hunting down a trade ship or a frigate, there are enemies to fight, both PC and NPC. There are also Port Battles which can decide whether a port will change hands to another nation. These often become big organized PvP affairs.The game was already populated by an active community before it came to Steam. There are active player groups with each nation. The website forum has  many threads on the full range of subjects that a new player will want to know. This is a good thing because the game currently lacks tutorials. Right now there are two sides to the game, combat (sailing around, accomplishing missions or fighting) and crafting/trade. You can craft basic goods and ship upgrades all the way up to crafting ships, which can then be used by you or put on sale in a specific port. You can also buy/sell goods in different ports.Please note that in Naval Action, your XP rank limits how many sailors you can command but there is no limit on the ships you can buy. So you start off at 40 sailors (and a Cutter that needs 40 sailors to man it). Thus, even if you have the gold to buy it, you won't be able to man a frigate that require a crew of 200 or more, let alone a Ship-of-the-Line. An undermanned ship often performs poorly in every way. So resist that “buy” button, even when you have the gold to pick up a big warship. Make sure you can crew it (and outfit it with cannons/carronades, with you must buy separately).The other thing that should be noted is time. It can take a while to sail around in the Open World, especially if the wind is not in your favor. Hitting the seas for a full 30 minutes or an hour is not unheard of if your destination is several ports away. The Open World also has no real navigation tools. From your starting point you really have to look at the map (M), decide on a bearing and sail in the direction you want to go. Once land disappears you don’t know where you are, its pure guesswork and planning. Just sailing off without paying attention to the compass can get you lost. Note that behind the chat window in the upper left hand corner of the screen in Open World Sailing there is another panel that gives you some options, including allowing you to teleport back to the nation’s capital port. For faster play, there are missions that typically allow you to jump into combat fairly quickly, from a load screen for a simple PvP match, or a mission that sends you to a spot in the Open Worlds near your current port to do battle. These two mechanisms are often the best way to grind up gold/XP but are also the most convenient for players with limited gamer time. Expect a slight learning curve because of the lack of tutorials and a sometimes not-so-intuitive UI in a few places. I spent a lot of time combing through the forums on Naval Action’s website for the answers to various questions the first week I started playing. I highly recommend spending a lot of time in the starting Cutter (it's free and replacing it is free) to get acclimated to the game. In general, if you enjoy Age-of-Sail, you'll enjoy this game, even in its current Early Access incarnation.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								Three things that distinguish the game:-It's the best naval combat simulator out there. It beats such giants as Age of Sail, Pirates of the Burning Seas or Sea Dogs. You control every individual gun if you want to, you can control individual masts to turn faster or decide at what angle/distance the guns will converge. Ships react realistically to wind or gunfire damage, they can even be set on fire. This game offers slowpaced but hugely realistic and fun fights where a small cutter can outmaneuvre anyone, a swift frigate is the jack of all trades and a huge, slowturning ship of the line should better stick to a strict line of friends to survive. -It's a true MMO sandbox. The downside: there is no tutorial, you have to rely for forums and youtube for (good) explanations, there is nothing resembling a "story" and leveling up takes a lot of time. The upside however: It's an enormous open world where you can sail anywhere and it will take you more than 5 hours to cross from east to west and you will have to use only your compass without relying on an automap. It's a world of thousands of players, if you play on a PvP server you can be part of high politics made by the mighty guilds/fleets, conquer ports for ressources, try to starve your enemy out or make your nation the ultimate underdog, biting the large empire in sensitive spots. While the main part of progression is nearly exclusively combat at the moment (it will change in the future), traders and especially crafters play a huge role in supplying this war effort, where large crafting chains of coordinated players are usually coming together to build huge ships of the line. Important Disclaimer: You can play this game as a casual pretty well, however a game session of 15-20mins will not bring you anywhere since travel times are longs and fights might lasts for some time. However if you can spend an hour a day on this game and are an avid age of sails fan it will not disappoint you.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2016
Early Access Review
								I say recommend, but it comes with some serious caveats. For those of you who love age of sail and have patience, this is a solid game as its stands (although certainly no where near a finished product). PVP is stimulating and with the right groups requires coordination for major campaigns (for example, not strange to see multiple squadrons with some attacking the port and others screening for enemy players in order to keep them from reinforcing). For those with a more tentative interest, whether it be the final vision, a passing historical interest, or desire for a new MMO... I suggest you fully research what you are getting into and perhaps give the game a little more time to mature. The economy, the mission structure, the crafting, diplomacy, etc. are all still heavily in development.

								Vastly underrated game. Tons of fun for anyone with a taste for an age of sail game with great combat mechanics. Still early access, still alot of content to come, but they seem to be churning it out at a reasonable and steady pace. There is a deceptively large amount of stuff to do in the game, I don't even play on the PvP servers myself. you can craft your own ships or craft them to sell, you can build buildings on your outposts now, fish passively as you travel, use the fish for selling or crafting. lots of combat options from the basic missions and smuggler hunting/capturing to massive battles between factions and the Epic Events at high level. Great game to play with friends.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								A game really worth trying, even in alpha. This is a must have for every age of sail fan, it is really promising and full of detail and even if you are not a big fan of sails and cannons i think you could easily become one with this game.The developers know what they're doing and listen to the players in their forums.In game, you start by choosing your player name and nation, then you are brought to the Capital of your faction in the port screen (User Interface is a bit clunky right now, but they are obviously planning to improve it) where you can see your ship, buy equipment, trade, craft items, upgrade your ship and accept missions or simply jump in a random battle room and fight.But if you press Sail you get to the open world, which is really huge, ranging from the northern coast of South America to Florida with the Caribbean Islands in between, of course, and the gulf of mexico, with lots of settlements and places to explore, fight or trade.The various factions in game can conquer settlements belonging to each other, by assembling invasion fleets.Sailing and fighting might seem hard at the beginning. but you will quickly get used to the various keys and maneuvers.And fighting is where this game really shines, with a great level of immersion, nice graphics and awesome sounds (though the game could use a bit of soundtrack and a bit more variety of sounds), learning to maneuver a ship in a battle with many ships, with cannonballs flying over your head is really satisfying and when you manage to sink or capture your first ship it gets even more, the only negative thing about combat i can find personally is the "text based" boarding actions, though it's not that bad an idea, but could be improved.So, get the game, find some friends or invite yours and build up a fleet to join the great community already present in Naval Action.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								In the last two weeks, I've logged 60 hours. Five of those fourteen days i haven't been able to come on at all, or there has been considerable downtime due to preperation for launch.   In those two weeks, I've lost everything, built it up, lost it again, begun again, and I'm still playing, and loving every minute.  In those two weeks, I've sunk, caught fire, exploded, capsized, run aground, and done much more and worse to other people.  In those two weeks I've felt as close to the age of sail as I ever have, including the time I've spent standing on the decks of two of the ships in the game, HMS Trincomalee and HMS Victory.  I cannot recommend this game enough. It has limited UI, which is being reworked. It has a good playerbase of a few hundred early alpha testers, it already has an active forum and community ingame, and it's beautiful. What it doesn't have, is a difficulty curve. Things are hard at the start, and stay that way, this is not a game for the casual arcade crowd. Don't expect World of Warships, don't expect Black Flag, and you'll enjoy yourself.  It can be played casually, so long as you don't mind going at a steady pace. Large scale PvP battles are available right from the starter vessel upwards, there is no stage in this game at which a player is left out, high level ships are only high level because, just like the real things, they require experience to command and money to build.  TL;DR Version This is Elite Dangerous, in alpha, but with tallships.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								After 432 hrs: I highly recommend, with the caveats - that you are an aficionado of The Age of Sail milieu and have a considerable blood-lust for battle.Unlike Assassin's Creed, Black Flag, that was entirely arcade-like in its sailing and battle dynamics, Naval Action endeavors to be more of a sailing simulator and has very sophisticated physics models for ballistics/ ship damage and other ship dynamics. This, combined with very good graphics, cements my interest in the game.For the above mentioned aficionado, this should be enough to enjoy this Alpha release as  it stands.  For others it seems, perhaps wanting more polished nuance, a AAA game team of developers making leaps and strides of breathtaking advancements weekly, may find themselves  disappointed.The UI is rudimentary, the crafting is basically looking at lists that resemble a spreadsheet.  In fact in the lower corner of the screen the developers have a little note the states ‘Please ignore the UI’.  I find this all forgivable at this relatively early stage in development.There are many ships available in the game that you access as your leadership experience advances.  Every ship is modeled to have its unique strengths and weaknesses, this is fleashed out in more detail then you  will ever need at - http://navalaction.wikia.com/wiki/NavalAction_Wikia A recommended site to have bookmarked for quick reference if you play the game.There is no way the game could be at its current state without dedicated passion from the development team.  This gives me great faith that, going forward, we will see the game evolve into an icon of the Age of Sail simulator/ MMO. Again, highly recommended. I have my money’s worth several time over already.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Edit after 600+ hours in gameMy interest in the game is increasing over time.  A rare quality in a game.  The developers continue to tweak the dynamics and add features.  A notable incident that speaks to the character of the development team happened recently when their ISP provider had a technical problem that took the Naval Action servers off line for something like 24 hours or so.  Although it was no fault of the game team, they gave every player in the game a newly developed ship of considerable game-value as compensation.  I have played many AAA MMOs that have been in full release for years and when they have similar server issues that ARE their responsibility, they do nothing, no compensation, not even to paid-up patrons.  So kudos to the Naval Action team.See you in the Caribbean...

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								Looking at the time I've spent, I can tell you I'm not the most informed about this game.  The only reason it's so low is that I plan on refunding the game, as in it's current state, I'd rather have my £20 back for the summer sale.Is the game bad?  That's not a quesiton I can answer.  The UI is terrible though, and there are no tutorials, so the first 10 minutes of the game are interesting to say the least.  What little of the combat I experienced was ok, but due to me starting in such a small ship, it was lackluster.  I can see it being more fun in larger ships or more versatile ships, but in the starting ship, it's a case of: - Fire right hand side cannon - Turn left side to enemy - attempt to fire/hit - turn away from wind direction - repeatThat doesn't make it bad per se, I just don't want to invest my time in it that much, and this is coming from someone with 500 hours or so in Elite: Dangerous (not through steam if you're checking my playtimes).If you're after an age of sail game, it's worth trying the first 2 hours of your gameplay before you decide to refund or not.But due to the timesink seeming nature, terrible UI with use of hilariously mismatched fonts (it's some modern sans-serif font plastered everwhere for god's sake), I'm refunding it.

Early Access Review
								As the Early Access moves on, the game changes. Still I can have fun in it:http://forum.game-labs.net/index.php?/topic/14676-pvp1-june-the-british-honduras-campaign-pirate-perspective/At €0,04/hour I'm more than satisfied with the return of value, but I sunk (yarrr yarrr) a lot of time in.Now you don't need to invest a lot of time to get a good experience, but you do need to reckon with game sessions that last anywhere between 1.5 and 3 hours. Yes, you can spend 10 or 20 minutes in game, but then you'll never see a battle to the end. In other words, you won't have the opportunity to leave harbor, this missing a huge part of the game.So before you dive in, be prepared that your expectations might not be met. Now or in the final release.Or be open minded and enjoy the experience.So I'm not going say pros/cons, that is something for you to evaluate, but you'll see:- Sandbox (both by design and by lacks of structure)- Realistic Battles- No guidance- Hardcore on a level beyond PvP- Time dilation between strategic and tacticalI forget to mention the potential bugs you might encounter. :blissful_creep:

number of helpful: 10 of 18 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
Product received for free
Early Access Review
								I wrote a previous review in which I stated  my "Negative" was actually a "Neutral"This is now a Negative review. Why? Well, I'll try for the first time ever to write a comprehensive reviewGraphics: 6/10This game is stunning to look at. The sea is dynamic and rolling (although I believe they removed storms from the overworld), and the ship models themselves are quite detailed and gorgeous to look at. They obviously did a ♥♥♥♥♥on of research and probably were able to get their hands on the blueprints and measurements for the actual ships. So why so low? Why not an 8 or a 9 or a 10? Well, if you've ever played Empire/Napoleon Total War, you know that ships show heavy damage as they fight; masts fall, holes are torn in the bulkheads, etc. In Naval Action, you can demast a ship, but 'damage' is reflected by pockmarks in the hull, like the bullet holes in Goldeneye 007 (N64). It really takes you out of the moment to realize that 32lb carronades (big honking guns) do no visible damage except for basically scuffing up the paint. It also denies you tactics such as firing grapeshot (think a shotgun blast from a cannon) into holes you blow into the ship to kill crew. Instead, blue bars in the UI show how much of a ship's armor you have destroyed. It feels cheap and isn't satisfying. You may be lucky enough to cause a fire and have an enemy ship explode, but I haven't been that fortunate to witness, so I cannot comment. Also, visible crew is limited to one animated sailor operating each cannon; this is understandable due to framerate issues, but it still looks a tad silly. The 'ports', if you can call them that, are indistiguishable from each other and are visually uninteresting. The user interface, once you enter a port, is a bland and uninspired blue-themed mess that looks like something from Windows 3.1 (Yes, they say they'll have a better UI on release. Yes, it's a lame excuse; take a couple days to whip up some nautical-themed graphics, if only as a placeholder, it *can't* be that hard). So, while the ship models and the sea may be absolutely stunning, everything else just seems cheap, half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and uninspired.Sound: 4/10The cannons boom majestically, but there's no ambience aside from the sea itself; no seagulls, no whale or dolphins, nothing. There is no music, either. Some good sea shanties, epic battle music, or even some Celtic-style stuff that would fit the era would really add a ton of value and enjoyment. I rate this so low because, as the developers for the Total War mods called "Darthmod", they added some beautiful and epic music to their mods for Empire and Napoleon, and it's unacceptable that they wouldn't even lift *those* tracks, even as placeholders.Gameplay: 2/10Oh dear, oh dear, what could possibly be wrong? The answer: Everything. This game is the densest time sink you will ever play. It can take hours and hours of real-life time to sail the map, so grouping up with friends or clanmates means you will need to plan *far* in advance if you want to play together. Assigned missions can be up to 30 minutes away (thanks to the rotating wind direction); this, of course, assuming you can even find the missions. There are no tools for the in-game map, so if you want the exact bearing of where you want to go, hold a protractor to your screen; otherwise, you could overshoot your mission marker and waste a large chunk of your life looking for it. Some may say "But Sluggo, you tool, you have a compass in the overworld which shows your heading!" To which I reply "Yeah, but look at where your mission marker is on your map: tell me the exact bearing it's at." Because, especially if where you're headed is far away, a mere 10 degrees can mean the difference between reaching your objective or getting hopelessly lost. The battles themselves are fun, at first, but quickly grow repetative. There are also port battles, where nations fight to capture ports, but a wonderful mechanic to determine when ports are 'open' for battle means if you're in bed at 3am, you're not fighting.  Speaking of nations, there are 7 historical nations to choose from, plus a Pirate faction. All nations (plus Pirates) have access to the same ships, the only difference being the flag you fly. Pirates, amazingly, are an actual 'nation'; they operate exactly the same way as a real nation, without the high-risk/high-reward bucaneering you may be expecting. You can sail right past a British NPC fleet and they'll politely wave as you sail past; it's disgustingly immersion-breaking. If you're looking for a game where you'll be high-tailing it from Commodore Norrington with a hold full of Aztec gold, look elsewhere. You can choose to become a pirate when you create you character, or simply become a pirate by attacking a ship from your own nation. This is irreversable, as is changing your nation from any nation to anything except Pirate; there are no pardons, letters of marque, etc. So if you would like to be a privateer, er, independent contractor, you're out of luck. The in-game economy is completely broken; clans dominate the economy. The economy in the game is based on shipbulding and material trade, both of which are extremely time consuming as you must sail from port to port to port to collect resources and spend 'labor hours' from a limited pool to craft items and ships.  Because of the wealth amassed by clans, ships which should be worth no more than 100k gold cost millions and millions; anyone who would like to play on their own and not in a clan is at a severe, severe, disadvantage. Aside from battles and economy, there is no other content in this game, and this is where it really falls apart. Visiting ports is pointless as they all look the same; there is no reward for, or need for, exploration or adventure, which, in the Age of Sail, is what this whole era is about. The developers have ruled out the possibility of there ever being a first-person component to this game; if you want to walk around your own ship, look at charts and maps in your cabin, walk around a port, meet your Admiral, participate in deck-to-deck fighting with the enemy captain, look elsewhere, because this game will never have it. The battles quickly become repetative, and all except the most die-hard will grow bored and move on to another game. The contect availbale in no way justifies the price tag. Development on this game has been very, very slow, with no major changes aside from tweaking of damage values; if you're expecting a bigger, better game a year from now, you're not going to get it, because all further contect will be within the limits of the current framework, which is itself extremely limited.  It honestly, truely feels like a proof-of-concept for a few mechanics of a bigger and better game that we're never going to get. I am longer ambivalent in my feelings for this game, and actively discourage anyone who hasn't bought it to not buy it and spend their money elsewhere. The playerbase is abandoning this game in droves with fewer than 700 average players, per steamcharts.com, and it continues to fall. In a few months I predict this game will be dead and just another failed Unity-engine project.Not only to the developrs of Naval Action, but to the gaming 'industry' in general: This early-alpha-pre-access-beta-test-for-us-and-give-us-money extravaganza needs to stop. Now.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game has alot potential and it can be fun but there are alot of flaws and issues as well if the direction of the game continues to go a certain way.A big thing is the game at the moment isn't new player friendly. You'll to do your research on the forums for guides (assuming they are even up to date since the game is constantly in flux and most aren't) and look up wiki info.Leveling up, you can find fun playing against the NPCs in your tiered boats but the moment the player aspect is added it changes the dynamics.The culprit being is damage model 5.0: Smaller cannon calibers have a harder time penetrating thicker armor which gets bigger and bigger the higher tier ships you face against.If a cannon ball can't penetrate the armor, it bounces and richochets off doing nothing to the enemy. This renders smaller ship PvP/PvE against bigger ships time wasting and unfun in its current form.To add more to this, you have get a 90 degree angle shot for most of them broadsides to get your damage to penetrate as well.It like World of Tank's damage model, but on a hardcore grinding gaming model.I'm coming from playing other sailing games which I was able to bring my knowledge and relate to how they did this in Naval Action which I caught on quick, but I could already see if it was from the perspective of an average player that picks up this game they wouldn't be able to enjoy it.I just can't recommend this game. I would wait for a few months before buying it to see what direction they take it.Realism is good but is way on the border line of too much realism.Alot of stuff is still being tested, but new additions of content in the game currently being done aren't up to par to addressing its current issues.

number of helpful: 10 of 18 people (56%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								Although Naval Action has some flaws, there are still many reasons to play. First, for an early access game, Naval Action is very well polished and recieves substantial updates and bug fixes each month. The devs are really good at listening to the community and making necessary changes. Along with that, the community is great dispite its small size. There are plety of new players joining the community every week and many will happy to travel and fight along side you in both PvP and PvE. The combat is the main attraction for Naval Action and is realistic and challenging. There are a few problems that will likely be addressed in future updates. The open world travel is painfully slow and the world is massive. Most of the time you will spend is around your own coastal ports. In addition, there isn't a ton of variety in the combat, which is made worse by the long grind required to reach the higher ranks. For me, getting money is the easy part and you will certainly be able to by a first rate before you have the men to crew it. This is because the amount of crew you can have is dictated by your rank. One last thing is that I really recommend playing this with friends as it cuts down on some of the boring grind. Overall, I recommend Naval Action despite its flaws. You have to remember that this is still early access and has been around for only a short time. The updates every month are refreshing and make noticable changes. For under $60, this game is tremendous fun for anyone interested in the age of sail.

Early Access Review
								Absolutely not.  This game has a lot of potential but frankly I am sick and tired of these 'Early Release' games being offered (especially for $40) that can't even be played.  Since when did customers become paying play testers?  This game could be great if it was a finished game but it has crippling bugs.  For instance, you can't even stay on the damn server.  I don't know how many times I have been painfully floating around (it is sailing after all) to finally engage someone in combat just to be kicked out.  Then sign back in and do it over and over again.  Even worse is getting into combat, fighting it out for 30 minutes and then get kicked out again, basically wasting your time.  This is utter nonsense.  Beautiful environment and the ships themselves look classy.  But knowing this is going to be a slower paced game and expecting that, it is far too frustrating to play when you keep getting booted.  After googling it to see if perhaps I was having a hardware issue or connectivity problem I found I am certainly not the only one.  If it is a game still in production and you want player input (admirable) that is great.  But stop making us pay to playtest your half baked games.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've purchased this game quite recently at the time of posting this review, and the negative reviews posted right before did make me waiver. I'd like to go over why I am so happy that I decided to try the game for those that waiver as I do.I've played Sid Meier's Pirates for well over 1k hours before it was added to steam, this game sort of comes across as a much more in depth MMO version of that. Choose a nation, participate in PvE missions (small and large scale), capture ports of Pirates or other nations for your nation, fight people or capture traders/player ships in the open world, participate in a player driven economy. All of these aspects of the game accompanied by fantastic feeling combat and a true sense of accomplishment along the way, something I've found missing in a lot of games.It's true that you don't show up as an X on the map, and must use your compass as well as landmarks to get around. I have yet to get lost (perhaps other than a couple minutes of questioning my exact location), and honestly navigation feels great and after a day of playing I could find missions far off of land easily.There are several nations as well as pirates, and each one feels like a unique community. As you play throughout the day you see server wide messages of port battles, cities being conquered, you see in global chat people mentioning huge expensive ships being captured by pirates. The world feels alive, actions seem to matter and when you see a first rate ship sail by or you see people taking part in these huge battles with huge perma-loss risks and rewards, it excites a new player to want to continue.I already feel part of a national effort, I already feel a sense of accomplishment after getting a new ship and crafting enough to make a lot of gold. The combat feels fantastic, and though 10+ minutes may feel slow to a lot of people for missions, it never feels artificially slow. Each mission is still fun to me, fleet missions feel rewarding and sailing back to port with the risk of pirates jumping me and taking all of my rewards is honestly fun to me. (though very rare, but the possibility is there)I'm very happy that I'm playing this game, though it seemed hard at first it very quickly became a fluid and fun experience. Though people said missions were super slow, nothing has felt anything but natural and entertaining. This is a game that feels rewarding, the faction system makes me feel like I'm a contributing member and honestly this is the pirate game I've been wanting for years. I hope the development keeps going strong and adding more, but either way I've already gotten more out of this than a lot of games and plan on continuing for quite a while.Currently as of writing this, the best advice I was given before playing was to pick EU PvP 1, even as a North American player. There is no noticeable ping in game, especially with the slower pace, and the national politics and action make for a great playing experience.  A definite recommend in its current state, May 20th*, subject to change of course.

content:

Early Access Review
								All I can say is this game is awesome. I have put many hours into this game and it's hard to loose interest since there's so much to do. Naval Action kind of reminds me of POTBS meets a warship simulator. It's still in alpha, but it's pretty solid with very few bugs.General rundown-You start out by picking one of 8 nations. British, America, Spain, Dutch, Danish, Sweden, French, or Pirates(Pirates are #1). You start out in a little cutter and work your way up from there. The more you level the more crew you can have under your command. You can get into any ship, but until you can fully crew it you are at a disadvatage. There is a good crafting system, economy system, huge port battles, epic battle events, dueling, planned events, exploration, fishing, and even the ability to pray. There is a pretty big time sink involved. It takes awhile to get around the open world. On PvP servers(which is the best way to go) you can always be attacked by other nations. The community(at least on PvP2) is great. If you enjoyed POTBS, World of Tanks, or EVE you will probably enjoy this game.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								Naval action is just a great game, .... still in developpement, but with a great potentialGood stuff : FIRST, the developer team is small, but actually listening A LOT the community regarding developpement and suggestion. The bad part is sometime they release some strange things, to test alternative ideas , not always good, but they really listen, and do not fear to deeply change the gamplay if the community ask for it. Played a lot of early access games, in this one, your voice is heard :) Naval combat : realstic, but not boring, a very nice balance between simulation and arcade, with simple controls, but a lot of tactics (wind, rolling angle etc...), and combat is slower than in world of warship for example, much more tactical, forcing player to be smart and carefulGraphics : Graphics are truly very nice, they lack a little bit of life (not a lot of crew viewable on board right now) , but are still great, especially smoke / waters and ships models who are just great, and better than any other naval gamesOpen world : Huge open world, truly beautiful, with realistic map of all the carribeansCrafting : still in developpement, but very interesting, with a lot of sub components needing various ressources, buyable or lootable in Open world. Any crafting path is actually realistic with realistic sub components. Bad stuff : The way combat is initiated is actually not yet ready, there is a time compression in open world, and battles are fought in real time, , so the mechanism to enter or join an instance to join a battle is actually not enjoyable, leading to sevral exploits, and sometime a lack of "Fair" PVP situations. Developers are aware of this, and actually discuss with the community to find a proper solutionAlliance and Politics : This part is actually being patched and more developped, so there is good hope in the near future to have something more exiting, more like EVE online on the seas.Trading : not specially exciting ... as it should be I guess ? :)Time : the game like any MMO is very time consuming, even more ... A single combat versus another player can last for 30 minutes, huge battles 2 hours almost, combat is not too slow, nor boring , but playing with the wind, cannon reloading , is taking time, and let's be honest, this game is a time sink ! Conclusion :  Exellent game, with hopefully a lot of bad stuff disappearing patch after patch, with a lot of potential, realism, politics, alliance, PVP, PVE .... A huge and endless sea opening in front of you !

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								If you're looking for a game with excruciatingly detailed naval combat mechanics, everything from needing to turn the yardarms appropriately to the wind to accelerate a turn, to devastating raking shots that slaughter crew, damage cannons, and damage key components such as the rudder, pump, and powder magazine, then this is quite simply the only option available. Unlike something like World of Warships, you can take charge of nearly every aspect of commanding your ship, whether it be commanding crew to abandon their posts in the rigging and move to the gun decks to help reload and aim the guns, or aiming and firing each deck of guns individually. Conversely, there is a very nice balance there, in that you can set the skipper to auto, at which point the position and turning of the yards will be handled automatically, if somewhat simplistically, allowing you to focus on other aspects of the combat. The economy is heavily driven by the players, in that every ship you will sail of any quality or of a rate higher than 4th was created and sold by a player. Those ship crafters need materials to build those ships, and those materials need to be themselves assembled from raw resources gathered both by trading routes sailed by players between different cities and different islands, or by farms, mines, and forests owned and controlled by players. Frankly there's a reason that so much of the playerbase is composed of former and current EVE players; there is an appeal to games with such depth that is difficult to satisfy elsewhere.

								The game is good. Leveling is a bit grindy and will take a minimum of 2 months of straight up repetivite gameplay to get even close to a ship of the line. The game is very social, and if you choose to get involved the nations politics, your character will become known to those in and out of your faction. If you do get this game I suggest you get your movie playlists in order.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Above is what I wrote originally. While the above statements are still somewhat true, alot has changed. It still takes alot of time to level up. The politics in the game have changed completely, and is no longer a pit of social decay. I have 1000+ hours of gameplay now, and I still watch movies when I'm sailing. I realized when I wrote the above (about 6 months before this edit) that I was totally engrossed by the game. I didn't keep coming back because the game was perfect and polished, all shiny and chrome. I kept coming back because this dev team is so damn good!The changes to the game, was done by the dev team listening to the feedback the community gave to them. They listen to everyone, and everyone who registerred to the site (the site's registration mechanics is basically a dumbass filter btw) gave constructive criticisms, and were able to vote in the direction they wanted the game to take. The directions that were available were all compiled based on what the community asked for.I changed my review because the dev team is one of the best in the indie game industry and their quality of work is some of the best I've seen from an indie developer, and it keeps me coming back for more!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								First off, I am somewhat biased because I EFFING LOVE SHIPS. If I could go back in time and join the Royal Navy I would. I know the life was rough but the ships are so freaking awesome.Anyway, this game is like a wet dream for me (no pun intended). I think there is still a lot of room for improvement but so far this game has really satisfied the need for a game centered around these type of old world naval combat.The grind is REAL. XP does not come quickly or in large batches but you quickly become lost in the immersive details of the game. You literally have to run your ship and pay attention to everything that is going on. This game is almost like the DARK SOULS of boat games. It takes time, a lot of work and patience, but when you see those 3rd rates riding around decimating people left and right you know it is all worth it.My notes to the devs:-  More XP per PVE battle would be nice. it is 1000xp to the first rank after you start and ~50xp per battle is brutally slow especially when the battles can go on for over an hour (especially when the AI jerkoff bot keeps riding into the wind)- Add collisions while roaming the open world. Force people to pay attention at all time. this would of course you to stop loading ships on top of each other as well.- If you are in Sailing mode during battle I don't see why your ship wouldn't maintain the same speeds it does in the open world. Everything should be consistent. I would understand a penalty while being in another mode during battle.- Please add the spyscope/telescope view to open world!- When zoomed all the way in on the starting cutter the mast is directly in the middle of the view- Better tutorial in the beginning. I had no idea how to earn XP or what to do other than drive the ship. Took a lot of outside research to figure out main objectives. I don't mind a challenge and figuring stuff out but i spent the better part of my first couple hours just riding around in the open sea aimlessly not knowing what to do.- YOU ARE DOING A GOOD JOB KEEP IT UP YOU ARE MAKING MY CHILDHOOD FANTASIES COME TRUE

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								Very impressed with this game so far, in early access. The combat similation is absolutely top notch for an Age of Sail game, and certainly many players who have been looking for a similar title to Pirates of the Burning Sea will find a new home here. As I write this the game is pretty barebones apart from the combat areas, but entirely functional, and stunningly beautiful. Combat is simply sublime. The developers are active on their forums and take their heading from the community as to what the focus of the upcoming patches should be. New ships to be included are submitted and voted on by the community and are then pushed through to development. I really, honestly, don't have any major complaints to make about the game in its present state, I think the only thing major that needs to be addressed is the inclusion of some form of tutorial, as you do see in the in-game help channel a lot of new players a little confused about the same topics over and over again. Thankfully however the community is both welcoming and helpful, and seem entirely happy to patiently help you as you take your first steps (and mis-steps!) in the in-game world. The Basic Cutter starter ship is free anyway, and losses are to be expected as you learn the ropes! Its a fun process anyway, and rewarding when you get to grips with it. I find the the game has a certain feeling of satisfaction to it when you win a fight that you should otherwise, by rights have lost, only to prevail due to your skill at handling your ship. In that regard, it is definately a rewarding game.Literally cannot tear myself away from it right now, its very good.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								First off, Ghroznak's review (see below) described this game's current atmosphere pretty darn well.  Second, and without a a doubt, this game is the best "Age of Sails"/naval warfare game I've yet to play and I've been computer gaming for over thirty five years.  Third, and the best part of it all, this game is only in "alpha stage" at this point.  This means this game will only become better as its developer continues to introduce new content and flesh out their current coding.As to what I'd "like to see" (in regards to issues/improvement)... well... some of the reviewers (below) already mentioned what was on my mind.  I'd love to see the "Port" UI improved both graphically and functionally.  As it stands, it is relatively rudimentary but works just fine.  Furthermore, it would be nice if the "world map" had latitude/longitude lines in place.  For if we are to sail without sextant nor maritime map, we should be able to figure out our map/ocean location somehow... other than simple "gamer memory". All in all, I look forward to hours upon endless hours in this game.  I thoroughly enjoy it as it stands.

Early Access Review
								This game is one for the history buffs, one for the gamers, and one for people just looking for fun social interaction online.  I'm not only all of the above, but also a fan of the Patrick O'Brian novels in which the ship HMS Surprise features prominently.  I originally joined this game with the sole intent of sailing that ship, which I'm happy to say I have done so.  The only problem I have with this game is it is addicting.  I find myself waking up in the morning and needing to check in on my historic world.  I highly recommend this game.  I think I'll be playing it for years to come.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								Naval Action Early Access Review, Grade : Captain, written at around 350 hours of game-time.Pros- An unique open sea battle simulation. The (few) naval battles games that exist can't get close to the gameplay, realism and beauty of this game.- Combat is really well done. Every tactical option is here : 3 different ammunitions, crew management, advanced sails management with wind direction, different kind of canons, different kind of ships and possible strategies...- Very enjoyable with a group of friends, large or small. As it is a PVP designed game, you'll enjoy the thrill of naval action together. If you don't have a group though.... you'll get ganked !- A very large map. It easily takes half a day of sailing to get through one point to another !- Devs are very engaged on this game, and close to the community. They often reply on the official forums. Tired of AAA game devs ? Here they're really awesome.- Port battles are going to be awesome once they'll release... forts. But from the previews it'll be epic !- No subscription, no cash shop ! It's basically a MMO like the first guild wars, Buy to Play. Price is OK for the content.Negatives- Open sea mechanics are still new, and not very well designed. Trouble to find enemies that don't run, trouble to find missions... ports are conquered way too easily etc... That will change but the actual state of the open world is bad.- Grind is real. I didn't grind much, as I like to experience quite a lot of different things in the game, and after 350 hours I'd have thought to have end-game ships. Not really ! I am yet to unlock constitution and 3rd rates. So brace yourselve if you're a casual player that don't like grinding, you might never experience the end game anytime soon. - The game is a sandbox, and is definitely unbalanced on small servers. Choose your faction wisely if you don't like to fight with unfair (impossible) odds.- Crafting system is terrible as it is purely based on RNG, but hopefully it will change next patch.- UI is awful, as it is a placeorder. This will change before release.- Customisation is missing : no character or portrait, no ship cosmetic customisation. But that will likely change before release.- You keep combat XP forever, but devs will maybe/probably reset everything else before release. You've been warned. Nothing is final yet.Overall : 7/10 if you have a group of friends or meet nice players in game. If you are also a fan about ships of the golden age of sail it gets to  9/10, THIS GAME IS FOR YOU. If you're a casual solo player : 4/10. Unless you want to play in group on a regular basis, this game has not much to offer to you.Final verdict : RecommendedThe game is unique in its genre and should definitely be in your library if you like simulation of early 19th century sea battles. I repeat, this is not an arcade games and it is realistic to a certain extent, while not being a full simulation. The pace is slow, but needs skills.  If you like or don't mind simulation-paced games, then consider the followings :The open sea mechanics are bad, but the excellent combat mechanics more than make up for it. Open world is still recent though, and the game will only get better until release. Devs seem to be very engaged at keeping work on this game, and don't really care about money.Also, this is a PVP game before everything, and to enjoy it you need to group and grind at least a little. If you don't mind both of these requirements, then it is definitely a good game. It is still far from being perfect, but worth it even right now. Then, if you're a fan about naval battles don't hesitate. You'll probably love the game.If the devs fix the open world mechanics and keep putting more content, I'd recommend it even for casual players.

								2000hrs on :)Well at 1st I really like the comunity, but did not take long for their true colours to show.What a bunch of whiney mofos. No wunder the devs chop and change the game around to try and keep them happy, which they never are lol.The game now seems overdone to me. I still like the PvP side of it, but not the hostile/toxic global chat spam. Thank god for mute. No matter how they try and even up the game in regards to teams/nations, they just can't keep it simple. If ppl wont join an out numbered nation force it on them. The game is only good when there is somebody to fight. As it stands now ppl go 3 ways Pirate, Great Britian or US. Which leaves 4 other nation with hardly any players. To make things worst US\GB\Dutch are allies lolol Which are the 3 most populated nations, aside from Pirate that are not a nation as such.All they had to do is give each nation 10 sustainable ports. That could not be capped.Nice simple system, but instead they complicate things so much ppl have left the game in droves.The Trade system is over done and unbalanced and unnescesary. It just seems the more they do the worst it gets. Its a shame the Devs can't make their own game instead of making the game certian players want. I think the Devs should not be playing the game with clan groups and stop showing what seams to be favs with nations. May not be the case, but sure as♥♥♥♥♥♥seams like that. As the game is right now I cannot recommend this game anymore.

								Coming from someone who played a great deal of PotBS, and any game that was about the age of sail, this game hits well above expectations. I have all settings set to the highest level. content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								Yes, this is an early access game that are unfinished. But is it fun to play as it is now? The answer to that is absolutely yes. The core gameplay is there. Trading mechanics is working fine, and battles are fantastic. It runs smoothly too as long as you dont enable AA. There is a lot of things i expect to be improved. But as an early access review i wont deduct points for that. This is not a finished game. Join now, and be a part of the community that shapes a naval warfare game with huge potential. There is no tutorial, but we are very helpful in "help" chat in the game. There is also tutorial videos on youtube. What you need to know is that it is no arcadish game. You aim and shoot manually, the navigation is done with a map and use of compass. You dont appear as a dot on it. But there is a great community with many good guilds to join and be a part of. The big ones offer voice chat(Teamspeak). And we have great fun warring other nations for ports and control of the high seas.Conclusion is that the base game is there. And it is absolutely fun, and that i think, is the only thing that should matter in a early access. Its not perfect(yet) but i hope its going to be, and everyone that supports the developers buying in at this stage, will contribute in making it so. I wrote this review with 45.5 hrs played in game.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								Naval Action is a unique and beautifully made game that gives you complete freedom over your destiny, you take your role as a captain in the west indies during the age of sail, you may simply want to trade or like me take enemy ships your prize.The community is greatly helpful and i spent my first few hours talking to more experienced captains who were talking me through what I could take in my starter Yatch. After a few more hours I got to grips with navigation and once I worked out where I was I had to rely on map and compass, no player location marker in this game im afraid, you are forced to learn and adapt in this wonderful world.After basing my now upgraded yatch at kingston I operate in 5 day tours in which I will go into enemy waters, take a prize and bring it back into kingston for my own gain. I am under the flag of the UK which means I mainly attack French and Spanish ships, attacking an English ship would make me a pirate!I would recommend this game if you are intrested in the Naval history of this time and have an appetite for the learning curve, however you will not enjoy your experience if you are not willing to listen to more experienced players.Thankyou for Reading!

content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is more then just a game. It is an experience, and not one to be missed.I have thoroughly enjoyed every minute of playing this game. Sure, I was a bit frustrated with some of the gameplay at times, but that was my own fault. Naval Action takes a bit of time to get used to the mechanics, but it is no where as bad as EVE Online's learning requirment. Playing a few battles here and there will get you caught up to speed with how the game needs you to play.I was part of the Early Alpha of the game that you could only fight/battle (AKA Sea Trials), and even then I enjoyed the gameplay. Since the "Open World" segment was released, I have enjoyed it even more. During the Sea Trials, you were put into a arena to bombard your enemies with balls made of iron, however it was not a arena of land. No, you fought on a large sea map, with small islands that dotted the horizon, while other times you were surrounded by mountainous land formations.This game may be created in the Unity game engine, but the team at Game-Labs has done a increadible job making the game look beautiful and play well. I hear many developers complain about how the Unity engine looks terrible, but Game-Labs has created a game to show just the opposite of what many devs think of Unity. The boats you sail and fight in look stunning and the environments are just as good.When this game releases, I hope that many people give it a chance, because those who choose not to will be missing out dearly.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								Despite still being in early access, it is already one of the most beautiful games I ve ever played. It is an unforgiving game, a mistake during a battle can turn the tides completely, and a course badly plotted, without considering wind shifts or dangerous zones, could make a 30 min voyage last an hour. But Naval Action doesn´t rush you like other multiplayer games and gives you the freedom to play it at your own time. It´s not hard to recover your losses, and you learn very quickly from the mistakes you make.While playing I also haven´t felt a lot of pressure to level up. It´s as fun to play with a Privateer or with a Small Trader, as with the huge ships that require higher experience. Small ships are fast and can escape easily from those monstrous floating fortresses, while making fast attacks on vulnerable slow traders. Big ships are more challenging but really powerful and fun to play.One time I was hunting for Brtish traders. When an enemy player with a frigate appeared in my line of sight, he immediately started to chase me. I was several miles of the coast, but south of my position was an island with a huge area of shallow waters surrounding it. So I, sailing on a Brig and with a huge disadvantage of firepower, and with the enemy controlling the wind, decided to run to this waters where the frigate couldn´t enter. My plan worked perfectly, the frigate once near this waters had to desist the chase.But then, I realized several other enemy players were expecting me near the island, tired of running I let them engage me, 8v1, I manage to give them a big punch, but they were smart, destroyed my masts and sank me. Totally worth it.Naval Action is a game that requires patience and planning. But at the same time gives you accelerating and fun moments.Before you buy, is important that you realize it is still early access, so a there are plenty of things that aren´t finished or polished. But the developers are extremely aware of the players comments and ideas, wich is fantastic.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								If you are somewhat into Naval Combat, pick this game up. Also, if you are not so far, you might still like it (as it was the case for me).A lot of early access reviews that are positive say something like "the game has potential". That's not the argument in the case of Naval Action. Yes, it has potential, but it also already lives up to it. Nice graphics, the core gameplay mechanics are already fleshed out (general ship movement, combat...).It's already in a well playable state, it just gets filled with more content on regular basis.The game also has a growing economy part (trading & crafting), so if you don't want to be fighting all the time, there is still something to do for you.

content:

Early Access Review
								Is this game good? Yes, defintly.Is it for everyone? No, defintly not. You need a lot of time, patience & willingness to learn if you want to have fun with this game. There is grind, the Open World is huge and therefore the sailing distances are huge. A single PvP fight can last 2 hours and chasing ships can last hours. That being said, it is currently my favorite game. It looks gorgeous, the sound is good and everything just "feels right", from the thunderous sounds of your cannons to the smoke obscuring the sight. This is by far the best Alpha i have ever played.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								Despite still being in early access, it is already one of the most beautiful games I ve ever played. It is an unforgiving game, a mistake during a battle can turn the tides completely, and a course badly plotted, without considering wind shifts or dangerous zones, could make a 30 min voyage last an hour. But Naval Action doesn´t rush you like other multiplayer games and gives you the freedom to play it at your own time. It´s not hard to recover your losses, and you learn very quickly from the mistakes you make.While playing I also haven´t felt a lot of pressure to level up. It´s as fun to play with a Privateer or with a Small Trader, as with the huge ships that require higher experience. Small ships are fast and can escape easily from those monstrous floating fortresses, while making fast attacks on vulnerable slow traders. Big ships are more challenging but really powerful and fun to play.One time I was hunting for Brtish traders. When an enemy player with a frigate appeared in my line of sight, he immediately started to chase me. I was several miles of the coast, but south of my position was an island with a huge area of shallow waters surrounding it. So I, sailing on a Brig and with a huge disadvantage of firepower, and with the enemy controlling the wind, decided to run to this waters where the frigate couldn´t enter. My plan worked perfectly, the frigate once near this waters had to desist the chase.But then, I realized several other enemy players were expecting me near the island, tired of running I let them engage me, 8v1, I manage to give them a big punch, but they were smart, destroyed my masts and sank me. Totally worth it.Naval Action is a game that requires patience and planning. But at the same time gives you accelerating and fun moments.Before you buy, is important that you realize it is still early access, so a there are plenty of things that aren´t finished or polished. But the developers are extremely aware of the players comments and ideas, wich is fantastic.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								I know a lot of people having been giving this game a thumbs down and I get it. Although the devs want to make a realistic naval game set in 16-17th century they aren't focusing on the 'fun' aspect of the game. The devs keep adding more mechanics to make it realistic (which is fine) but they don't focus enough on things to make the game more fun to play. When I say fun I mean more things to do other than trading, crafting, and fighting in battles. Although these things especially combat can be fun it does get repetitive at times. There are also other issues with nations/pvp (Pirates are OP)Now other than the things I mentioned above the game is actually a very good game. I started off in a basic cutter with only 12 guns and worked my way up to a 1st rate ship with over 100 guns. Right now i'm currently in a trading bussiness making 300k gold a day. I love being able to sail around the west indies to all the different ports (keep in mind sailing can take hours because of the scale of the game and you can often get lost) and fighting and plundering enemy ships. The game is very realistic, it looks very realistic and has great graphics, and the combat is the best over any other naval game. Trading and everything else needs some work. If you love naval history, sailing, or being a drunken sailor then I have to reccomend this game. Although every game has issues this one has a lot of playablity and you will get a lot of hours out of it.7.5/10

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								Well, while I used to recommend buying this game, I cant at this point.It was a simulation, and now for "balance" have even broken the rules of physics.long cannons that fire the same 6 pound projectile as medium cannons, at a higher velocity... somehow now do less damage than the cannons that fire the projectile at a lower velocity..AI have turned into snipers.. they can hit your modules (water pump, rudder, etc) with alarming regularity. The chances of you hitting on of their modules are staggering. Enough so, that you will feel very lucky when you actually hit one.I will re-make this reveiw if and when they fix the game, which I expect they will.. but Im not going to hold my breath.=======================Original review below===============    This game is classic naval battles. Rolling seas, winds, sails, cannon aiming and your skill at managing these will go into each shot or broadside you send to the enemy. Aim for their sails with chain to try to demast their ship or shred as much of their sails as possible to slow them down. Or, aim for their water line with ball or double ball to open up some holes and let some water in. Aim for their crew with grapeshot to widdle their numbers prior to boarding. Your choices, your skill, your guile, your ship make the difference between success in battle and a wattery grave.      You start out on a small ship, with a few crew. The world is open, your oyster to pluck pearls from. You can trade with other ports, set up proffitable routes and make your money as a trader. Or, you can fight battles for your nation, earning money and skill in naval combat. You can hunt down pirates and smugglers, taking their cargo for your own. Or, you can be a Pirate! Hunt down enemy ships, fight, board and steal their cargo, commandier their cargo ship and bring it back into harbor to sell or use as you see fit.     Dedicated PvP and PvE servers allow you to play with as much (or as little) player interaction as you desire.    I started out on a PvE server, playing with a buddy. We learned to sail, shoot, fight, craft on the PvE and eventually, we longed for a battle against other players. The fights with AI are fun and definitly worth the practice of battle, but the fight against another human controlled ship, who can make mistakes, fool you with their guile, surprise you with their speedy ship, or just beg you to spare their ship and cargo from your plunderous ways, make the game exciting and very playable.   This game is in early access, and as such, is constantly being developed. Each week or so are updates that improve, expand or occasionally break things. But that is to be expected in an early access game.   I have played several early access games and this is one of the better ones because you can instanly file bug reports from within the game and the developers actually listen.   I cant wait to see what this game will eventually become, but at this point, I do recommend it to friends.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								If you are not looking for productions that requires some sacrifices in order to have fun, dont buy this game. You will only waste your money. BUT, if you are a patient man and you love the climate of the age of sails, that's something for you. Every travel even between two close ports takes at least 10 minuts and this is the big disadvantage of the Naval Action. The "action" word should be removed from the title cause the speed of this production is really slow. In fact, about 80% of time you will have to spend on travelling (especially now, when the developers removed the "taxi" option) between battles, events etc. Fortunately, everything changes when you enter the battle.The viev of max. 50 (!) beatifully detailed naval ships shooting hundreds of cannonballs in each other just amazed me. The falling masts and exploding ships are seen hardly ever, but even without them battles are really realistic and beautiful. The combats are the strongest advantage of this production.The optimalization is mediocre. On my PC (i5 4440, 8GB RAM, GeForce 650 GTX Ti) i have about 25-35 fps in Open World and 30-50 fps in battle with HD resolution and everything set on low except the water (medium) and trees. Also i noticed really interesting thing: whem I set all settings on a maximum lvl, I have about 5-10fps in Open World and about 15-20fps in battle, so there is a chance that they will improve it and even weaker PCs will be able to run this game.And that's all. You have to decide if you will like the hours of sailing in OW for one exciting battle. But thrust me - in my opinion it is worth it.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								I have had a lot of fun playing this game, there are still some little issues due to the fact its Early Access, you occasionally find bugs and strange things happening, graphics are also not optimised yet. The game itself has 3 core elements right now, trading, crafting and battles, each of these features have their own fun and challenge to them. The game can be played PVE or PVP, with most people playing PVP, I prefer PVE. Currently You can play one of 8 nations; Britain, France, USA, Denmark-Norway, Sweden, The Dutch, Pirates and Neutral, although Neutral is a bit lacklustre right now and Britain is vastly overpopulated.The mechanics are similar to that of Assasins Creed: Black Flag and Empire/Napoleon Total war naval battles, feeling more like the naval battles from the two total war games, going beyond their level of realism. You can control sails individually or have it automatically done for you. As a warning the game does not handhold, currently there are no tutorials and the UI hasn't been properly implemented yet, but the community is very welcoming and people are happy to answer questions to anyone on the in game chat, people are also often happy to show you the ropes of battle against an NPC to help you get started too.The Future of the game includes a monthly update, adding new features and with a very active and engaging development team who do their best to take in suggestions and answer questions both on their own forums and the steam discussions page.Personally I thoroughly enjoy the game, and will be keeping a close eye on it into the future, playing along with each period, checking out new features and being involved with the develpment as much as I can. If it continues on the trend it is on then I expect it to be one of my all time favorite games, I am glad to support it and praise it highly.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game does exactly what it means to; and that is, fulfills the desire of everyone with an interest in the age of sail to captain their own ship and venture the high seas of the Caribbean and Atlantic coast. Despite being early access, it's relatively content complete insofar as the open world is available. People have called the game "EVE:Online at sea", take of that what you will.Combat is instanced and content complete. If you've ever played the naval battles in Empire: Total War it's pretty similar to that. Although there's an auto Skipper, it pays to learn how to manage your sails as the wind is fully simulated. This game probably has the most realistically simulated water I've seen in a game too, as waves can rock a ship and knock your cannons' line of fire. You can switch your cannonballs out for chain shot to demast your enemy's sails and follow that up with grapeshot to knock out their crew enough for a successful boarding. You can even ram them if you're feeling particularly cavalier, I once got lucky and capsized someone's ship but I doubt that happens as much with the bigger hulls.I look foward to seeing what else the developers have in store for this game, so far they've promised a better economy and enhanced inter-factional diplomacy. For now I'd have to say it's one of the few impulse buys I actually didn't end up regretting.

								This game is really terrific.  It captures the essence of naval combat in the Age of Sail.  Tactics are complex and nuanced, and fighting does not become repetitious.   The open world is beautifully rendered, and the ships are also gorgeous.  There is a nice balance of PVP and PVE action, and the game caters to those who like PVP but doesn't really lend itself to griefers.  I have played quite a bit of EVE Online.  So far, I really prefer Naval Action, if for no other reason than the combat is a lot more engaging.    Can't recommned this game highly enough, especially for anyone who loves the Age of Sail.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is early access, let's start there.  There are bugs.  There will be changes.I have participated in this game since the Sea Trials a year or two back.  The combat has continuously gotten more detailed, and new features have been added.  The economy, for now, seems to closely mirror that of Pirates of the Burning Sea.  The combat focuses on realism wherever possible.The map is huge.  It takes hours to sail from one end of the Caribbean to the other.  The conquest mechanics are in development still, but the foundations are there, and seem to work well.  Each nation seeks to localize and then dominate their area, with forays out into other territory.  All is driven by control and commerce.If your inspiration comes from the likes of Patrick O'Brian or C.S. Forester, this game is for you.  If you want to zip around and rehash Pirates of the Caribbean, it probably isn't.----------------------------There is another review on here that Ant has put up, with a lot of negative comments for it.  I wrote this in response, and had it spread over four comments due to a 1000 character limit.  He opted to delete it, with no response.  It is unsurprising he deletes any comments that disagree with him so that he creates this aura of agreement.  It is a shame that Steam allows one to do so.  Now, I edit my own review to save it for posterity:You have to wonder why someone would spend so much time bashing a game, instead of listing a review and moving on. The feedback could be useful, but, from what I gather, this user has decided to remove any the development team's direct feedback on the game, right here, rather than letting people leave their comments and have a productive discussion.That said, this player has decided to try to do exactly what he accuses others of doing: Silencing those of differing opinions. Let us address this review point by point:He cites that there is nothing to due, as there are not enough people sailing around. Yet, it would be interesting to figure out just where this player was sailing. There is plenty of traffic in the Antilles. There is plenty of traffic around Cuba/Haiti. There are quieter zones as well, such as the Gulf.He states that the massive grind is a huge turn-off, yet... there is no need to grind. Smaller vessels are viable, as are larger ones. The Lynx, the lowest ranked vessel in the game, is great for running down Trader's Lynxes, which are what people run their high-value cargo in (due to their high speed upwind). Concerns of optimization and lack of UI are curious, as it is an alpha game, where optimization is towards the end, and UI will be worked on once the features themselves are in. The developers have said this themselves.Content patches are generally monthly, with new patch notes for October already posted. New ships are regularly added, new mission types are in this patch, forts along coast lines are in this patch, land in OW battles has been in for some time, and land in port battles is still coming. A "lack of content" seems to me to simply say, "I want it all, and I want it now."The playerbase has contracted from peak times when huge content patches were added. This is shocking to none. In a lull period between patches, the game still hovers around 800 players at peak hours, and 400 players at off-peak hours. In an alpha game. As far as microtransactions go, I believe they are still working on that, with potential changes to come. I do not believe anything is finalized yet.The ultimate concerns of this player comes down to the developer staff, and in particular, one person. Simply put, Ant doesn't like admin, and seems to have made it his goal to do a character assassination of him, and of the game. He still brings it up regularly, and tries to make an issue out of it. And yet, the key thing this player was complaining about is being added in this month's patch anyway.Maybe this player wants to have an honest assessment of the game. Maybe he has the integrity to allow for a differing view. We'll know that he does if this response is still here in a week or two.If he simply deletes it, well, then we know he just has an ax to grind, and should be given that level of concern.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								If you are not looking for productions that requires some sacrifices in order to have fun, dont buy this game. You will only waste your money. BUT, if you are a patient man and you love the climate of the age of sails, that's something for you. Every travel even between two close ports takes at least 10 minuts and this is the big disadvantage of the Naval Action. The "action" word should be removed from the title cause the speed of this production is really slow. In fact, about 80% of time you will have to spend on travelling (especially now, when the developers removed the "taxi" option) between battles, events etc. Fortunately, everything changes when you enter the battle.The viev of max. 50 (!) beatifully detailed naval ships shooting hundreds of cannonballs in each other just amazed me. The falling masts and exploding ships are seen hardly ever, but even without them battles are really realistic and beautiful. The combats are the strongest advantage of this production.The optimalization is mediocre. On my PC (i5 4440, 8GB RAM, GeForce 650 GTX Ti) i have about 25-35 fps in Open World and 30-50 fps in battle with HD resolution and everything set on low except the water (medium) and trees. Also i noticed really interesting thing: whem I set all settings on a maximum lvl, I have about 5-10fps in Open World and about 15-20fps in battle, so there is a chance that they will improve it and even weaker PCs will be able to run this game.And that's all. You have to decide if you will like the hours of sailing in OW for one exciting battle. But thrust me - in my opinion it is worth it.

Also i noticed really interesting thing: whem I set all settings on a maximum lvl, I have about 5-10fps in Open World and about 15-20fps in battle, so there is a chance that they will improve it and even weaker PCs will be able to run this game.And that's all. You have to decide if you will like the hours of sailing in OW for one exciting battle. But thrust me - in my opinion it is worth it.
