number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								Well, while I used to recommend buying this game, I cant at this point.It was a simulation, and now for "balance" have even broken the rules of physics.long cannons that fire the same 6 pound projectile as medium cannons, at a higher velocity... somehow now do less damage than the cannons that fire the projectile at a lower velocity..AI have turned into snipers.. they can hit your modules (water pump, rudder, etc) with alarming regularity. The chances of you hitting on of their modules are staggering. Enough so, that you will feel very lucky when you actually hit one.I will re-make this reveiw if and when they fix the game, which I expect they will.. but Im not going to hold my breath.=======================Original review below===============    This game is classic naval battles. Rolling seas, winds, sails, cannon aiming and your skill at managing these will go into each shot or broadside you send to the enemy. Aim for their sails with chain to try to demast their ship or shred as much of their sails as possible to slow them down. Or, aim for their water line with ball or double ball to open up some holes and let some water in. Aim for their crew with grapeshot to widdle their numbers prior to boarding. Your choices, your skill, your guile, your ship make the difference between success in battle and a wattery grave.      You start out on a small ship, with a few crew. The world is open, your oyster to pluck pearls from. You can trade with other ports, set up proffitable routes and make your money as a trader. Or, you can fight battles for your nation, earning money and skill in naval combat. You can hunt down pirates and smugglers, taking their cargo for your own. Or, you can be a Pirate! Hunt down enemy ships, fight, board and steal their cargo, commandier their cargo ship and bring it back into harbor to sell or use as you see fit.     Dedicated PvP and PvE servers allow you to play with as much (or as little) player interaction as you desire.    I started out on a PvE server, playing with a buddy. We learned to sail, shoot, fight, craft on the PvE and eventually, we longed for a battle against other players. The fights with AI are fun and definitly worth the practice of battle, but the fight against another human controlled ship, who can make mistakes, fool you with their guile, surprise you with their speedy ship, or just beg you to spare their ship and cargo from your plunderous ways, make the game exciting and very playable.   This game is in early access, and as such, is constantly being developed. Each week or so are updates that improve, expand or occasionally break things. But that is to be expected in an early access game.   I have played several early access games and this is one of the better ones because you can instanly file bug reports from within the game and the developers actually listen.   I cant wait to see what this game will eventually become, but at this point, I do recommend it to friends.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								Naval Action is a very addictive, slow-paced, deep game with plenty to do that all comes together to make for a very enjoyable experience that is best enjoyed in a group.As it stands now, only about a week out of Early Acess, Naval Action is a healthy, promising game with a friendly and invested playerbase. The game focuses a lot on basing its mechanics on players' actions in the game world, and as such you can expect to see a vibrant world form as a result. The game's features are still being fleshed out so there is certainly still room to give players more control over the world they play in, but you see from developer's responses on the forums that they plan to give players the tools we need to make this world ours.So what can you do exactly in Naval Action's giant sandbox? First off, you can fight basic battles with AI. These battles usually come in the form of 'missions', or Naval Action's equivalent to a quest. Missions simply order you to defeat the enemy at a given random location in the sea in exchange for bonus XP and gold. These rather mundane missions are the mainstay of the grinding experience for most players as it is a straightforward way to progress and gain the experience and gold needed to get the next best ship. Battles with the AI can also come in the form of hunting down AI trader ships or patrol fleets by yourself or with a group. Engaging with traders is a good way to try and make some money by “commandeering” valuable goods or ships, and engaging with patrols is a good way to get yourself killed; unless you bring friends.You can also of course fight with other players. You can do organized PvP in the form of Small or Large battle queues that you sign up for every few minutes in any port, or you can hunt down players in the open world. You can also participate in large port battles with other players against other players to wrest control over cities and the resources they provide.And of course, you can trade and craft in order to make lots of money. These latter options require a lot of knowledge and time to do right, but can pay in dividends. It is also important to note here that any decent ships you might wish to command must be player-made, and crafting ships is no small task. The economy of this game is one of great potential for the budding capitalist.Combat as a whole is very well done in Naval Action. It is deep and too complex to go into detail here, but know that this is no arcade style ship game. It is slow paced, but can be incredibly intense, especially in PvP and in large battles. Ships are detailed and well designed, the open world is a delight to sail in, and there are plenty of friends and enemies to be made playing this game. I wholeheartedly recommend it to anyone interested in games like EvE that maybe are looking for something more than context menus in their combat scenarios.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								Naval Action is a hard core, age of sail naval warfare pseudo-simulator, emphasis on the Hard Core. Firstly, it nails the whole alone on the ocean feel (when you get away from busy ports). Part of the gameplay is learning to navigate using only a map and compass. If you're looking for a real Age of Sail feeling type of game, this is it.What Naval Action is not: easy. Naval Action isn't a Pirates of the Caribbean game and takes basically no cues from the movie franchise. Naval Action is more like Master & Commander than Pirates of the Caribbean. You could hunt a single enemy player for hours before engaging in an hour-long gunnery duel and boarding action. Speaking of fighting, the combat is challenging, but fair, and the game doesn't try and hold your hand when you start. It takes a while to learn how to fight with the wind dictating your movement and with guns that have poor accuracy and slow moving projectiles, but nothing is as satisfying as landing a complete broadside and watching your enemy's armor become Swiss Cheese.Notice that I said Pseudo-Simulator. It's hard to be an actual simulator and be fun, so there are some player gimmes, like teleporting between cities, but more complicated sailing manuevers such as controlling your yards individually and the accurate sailing model give a sense of complexity missing from other naval themed games. However, there are two major caveats that Game-Labs gave up: The first is that you never have to sail at true speed throughout the Caribbean. There's an Open World overmap which you'll probably spend most of your time. In the Open World, the entire map is available for you to journey to but you can't fight in it and can't interact fully with your ship, and time goes faster, which in turn makes it seem like you aren't travelling at a snail's pace across the absolutely massive Open World map. When you reach a battle (either by attacking or being attacked), you'll transfer to a tactical Battle map where you move a true speed at true time and most of the simulator elements become available. If you've ever played Star Trek Online, think Sector Space vs. System Space. The other caveat is that it is always windy. You'll never get stuck in doldrums or without a breeze, either in the strategic Open World overmap or in an instanced Battles. But that doesn't mean you can go in any direction you please, you still can't travel directly upwind, though fore-and-aft rigged ships will travel faster close-hauled than square-riggers. Yeah, you'll get to (or really, *have* to) learn some nautical sailing terms in this game, too.The game is hard, and relatively unforgiving if you just think you can walk in and trounce the first enemy you see. Tactical planning is much more important that twitchy skill or APM. That being said, there are a ton of guides on the Game-Labs forums that will help you out on avoiding the major mistakes many players make. For good measure, I'll give you a first bit of advice: Don't go British.Good Sailing, Captain!

content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
Early Access Review
								First time reviewing a game simply because I enjoy this game immensely even in it's alpha stage and want to help it grow and flourish.  If you enjoy team tactics, "Eve style" MMO strategy/diplomacy, naval warfare, age of sail history, pirates, beautiful graphics or any of the above I highly recommend you check out Naval Action.  Even in it's alpha stage the replayability and fun is undeniable.  This game is also much more approachable than Eve (not to knock Eve, also a great game) but still presents a lot of the same dynamics that make this genre so much fun.  Plus, combat is not simply clicking the right guy at the right time but involves "twitch" reflexes, accuracy and in general is more instinctive.  Even though the ships are often going slowly when you factor in managing your crew, getting off cannon broadsides/chaser shots, factoring the wind/adjusting sails all the while not trying to hit anyone (on your team at least ;D)... you are never not calculating or focussing on what you're doing.  10/10!

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								Naval Action is not a perfect game.  It's still unpolished, with a rough UI, grindy and clunky level progression, repetative missions.  They just throw new players in, with no explanations or direction.  Obtaining even a moderate size ship is the result of many long hours of combat.  Battles are slow, with small ones taking 30 minutes and larger battles nearer to 90.  Sailing a ship to a distant port can take literal hours of tacking against the wind, with no navigational hints or visible land at where you are in the vast carribean, left guessing your position.Yet still, this is the best game I have played in a very long time.  Just a few months ago, before I knew of this game, and in the middle of the Aubrey Maturin series, I found myself wondering "Why isn't there a good, multiplayer age of sail game?"  I asked my friends, and they all agreed this was strangely missing from the world.Naval Action is everything I had hoped for.  The games slow pace means that combat, particularly PvP, is high stakes and suspenseful.  Rushing in towards an enemy, closing the distance while their broadsides crash into your ship unanswered, only to swing around at the last second and run yardarm-to-yardarm beside them, firing your carronades loaded with grape shot onto their decks as they bear, and boarding them in the smoke, is potentially one of the most gratifying experiences that modern gaming has to offer, with the possible exception of large battles.Imagine 40 ships, some of them with over 100 massive cannons, running with wind, all firing at the enemy fleet at the same size a quarter mile away. closing in to a chaotic 80 ship melee at close quarters, blinded by thick clouds of smoke, fighting both sides of your ship while trying desperately not to smash head-on into friends and foes alike.  This routine occurrance is one of the most epic sights I have ever encounted in any videogame.I have found myself wary of Early Access games as of late, due to abandonment or extremely bad development decisions.  But not here, the devs seem to pay attention to player's input, and the game, though unfinished, is already in a very playable state.  Though there is not much 'content' as far as missions go, the sheer fun and complexity inherent in sailing battles keep it fresh, and skill very much matters, as a more experienced player in a smaller ship could win through maneuvering and tactics alone.I can't recommend this game enough.  If you like the age of sail, and are looking for a game to sink quite a bit of time into, this is it.

								You would be hard pressed to find a more accurate age-of-sail game, and this is coming from the perspective of someone who has real life experience with square riggers.  The game mechanics in Naval Action are sufficiently realistic that you will find yourself using tried-and-true historical maneuvers.That being said, the developers have managed to execute this rich realism in such a way that it is intuitive and easy to learn.  You can jump right in and start sinking ships, without first reading a treatise on sail theory.

content:
Posted: April 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								Good game.  There's crafting components & ships; there's trading up and down coastlines; and there's combat, both individial and group based.  The real fun is finding the balance between these three competing dictates.  The initial grind is hard and boring but is as needs must for you to become a competent captain.  Find a clan, learn the secrets and amass the cash & experience necessary to become a captain of a first rate ship of the line.  Plenty of forum and youtube available to learn the basics and gain proficiency.  In port (non ship) based UI is drab and boring, but is obviously only a placeholder.  Only negative is the 1hr server restart every day at 0700 hrs UTC.  Why they need this leftover from late '90's gaming is a mystery, but there it is.  One of the more expensive Early Access games out there, but certainly has it's addictive side.  You can easily find yourself 100 hours in barely a 3rd of the way to MOAR CANNONS.

Early Access Review
								The game is released as an alpha access, and it shows. On top of that, they peddle it for 39.99. The game is said to be a beautiful realistic experience, but most of it is portrayed in spreadsheet type layouts. The layouts spill over the sides of my moniter when set in its native resolution so that I can't read costs correctly, the UI is very wonky and seems to have little organization involved. Having said these things, the combat, once you learn how to do it, is quite realistic and a bit fun. The combat is definitely what this game has going for it.Overall the game didn't meet the expectations it sets, and the only thing justifying the purchase at the 40$ price tag is promise of the game costing more in the future for content which might be developed in the future.I sent in a refund request and hope it gets fulfilled because I could spend 10$ on Sid Meier's Pirates! and get a much more exciting, immersive, fun game set in the 'most beautiful period of naval history - when sailing ships ruled the seas.'I wanted this game to be good, but it's just not there, and it's not worth 40$ as is.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								Note: I've had Naval Action since very shorty after the closed beta started. I've played off and on since then, but I'm not an expert by any stretch of the imagination.Naval Action is a game about the 'Age of Sail' that lasted from the 17th-18th centuries. You take command of any one of a number of sailing vessels, starting from cutters and yachts, to the largest Man-O-War. Most ship classes are named for ships that actually existed (you can't rename them as of now, and I don't know if that's planned), and a few from more realistic fiction also fill the roster. they can hold different numbers and sizes of gun, larger crews, reinforced planking, and all manner of other upgrades to set them up for your tastes. Nothing exists at the moment to change them astecticly, however.As these are sailing ships, the weather  (naimly the wind) can be your best freind, or worst nightmare. if you have to head northwest, and the wind is coming out fo the northwest, it's going to be a long and slow slog up to your destination. Learning how to use the wind to your advantage will be the hardest challenge you face in Naval Action. You ship can take damage, and if shots hit below the water line, you're liable to start leaking. Masts can be shot off, rudders damaged, and crew can be killed with grapeshot from the ship's guns, Sails can be shredded to ribbons with chain-shot.The game itself has a map that encompases the whole of the Carribiean, and parts of North and South America. There are ports for a number of nations, all of them currently at war, as well as ports where any ship may enter. There's Pirate ports (I've yet to find Nassau, though D:)  and Pirates coming out of them. You'll start off by sinking (or if you can manage it, capturing) these pirates, before venturing out to wage war with the other nations, or trading valuble (and sometimes illegal) commodities thoughout the world.It's a game best left for the patient, it takes me a good half hour to get to Cuba from Charleston, and another ten mintues to get to Hati or Jamaica. The overworld map is pretty large, to say the least.the graphics in this game are top-notch when in combat-mode, though are a bit simpler when in the overworld. The menus are far from complete (though even they have come quite a ways). The sound is suprisingly good for a yet-to-be-finished title. Get yourself a good set of headphones, and you'll be sucked in, with the sounds oc water and creaking wood in between the smoky roar of your deck guns.Pros:-The game is quite realistic - Wind makes a difference, and you can use it to your advantage.-Looks georgious while in combat.-Sounds georgious while in combat.-You can sail the Suprise.-Bigger ships do not always trump smaller ships (get on the stern of a frigate, and have the wind on him, and you can happily rake him in the backside all day long).-PvE options for people to learn on, but while XP transfers to PvP Gold doesn't seem to (a nice tradeoff IMHO)-Gives me a reason for having a whole playlist of Sea Shanites (Which I liked before I even knew about the game).-You can get large numbers of players together for large naval battles, when everyone knows what they're doing, ti's a sight to behold.-The Developers are really active in the community, and seem to enjoy us enjoying the game, which is nice.-A large number of nations to choose from, depending on how you want to start out, and what you want your ship's flad to look like.Cons:-Realisim means that you can't go directly into the wind like AC4, you'll have to learn how to tack (this isn't as much of an issue for those who have sailed before like myself, but newcomers might want to watch a few tutorials Which I might even make a few myself)-Larger ships with square-sails are complex to operate for the newcomer.-No ship insurance built into the game as of yet.-Not every command can be re-bound. The functions of the number keys come to mind, how I'd LOVE to set up a custom joystick to handle that instead, but it's a bit less conveiniant then I'd like for that.-the overworld doesn't look quite as pretty as combat, and you will be spending time in the overworld a lot.-no spyglass in the overworld, where you'd realllllly like to have it-not optimized, which is to be expected, but those of you who cannot stand anything less then 60 FPS, turn back now.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								The Age of Sail game that serious PC gamers have been waiting for.It isn´t for casual gamers, the scale of the map is huge and navigation takes a significant amount of time.The combat is excellent, and with each update every aspect of ship warfare is simulated with increasing fidelity.There are a lot of people reviewing the game prematurely, or at least without any real understanding of the concept of early access, or certain decisions made with regard to the business model. 99% of these reviews are uninformed drivel. It becomes apparent very quickly that Naval Action is a labour of love, each ship is beautifully crafted in a way that honours the real world originals, the combat is intense, lumbering, yet somehow despite that slower pace is always edge-of-your-seat split-second decision making. Quite the feat really.Most of the negative comments here come from the fact that the developers have decided to sell ´premium ships´ in order to pay for the very high capacity servers. Seems perfectly reasonable once you look at the details and reality, as opposed to simply get all hot under the collar because you want everything in life for free. The game world is huge, and to support that many players on one or two servers requires income other than the initial sales. The game is very reasonably priced, and there is no subscription fee. These ships aren´t pay-to-win. Stat-wise, they will be more or less the same as the normal ships, and unlike premium vehicles in other games it is possible to lose them (they can be sunk four times before they are permenantly lost). Seems reasonable enough to me.Another reason some of the uninformed masses have complained here, seems to be the fact that there are no ingame tutorials or anything. It´s early access! All efforts are currently being directed towards creating and improving game mechanics. The UI, filler and content like more ship types will follow. Currently they are releasing minimum one new ship design per month.If you understand this, then this game might be worth looking at in its current state. For all others, stay away from our baby.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								Does sailing around on a high quality naval vessel appeal to you? Engaging in port battles, trade runs and ship to ship combat against both NPCs and other players (on PvP designated realms)? Then this could have been the game for you!Unfortunately a number of features let it down such as the world map scaling with the ships so a trip to Honduras from Jamaica takes the same amount of time it would take a ship travelling at the same speed in the real world.This is further hampered by storms with zero visibility (sailing past obscured ports at 100m is common) and that there is no marker on the map for either your position or that of your group members. Travel is done by zig-zagging between ports based on compass bearings and combat navigation is done in degrees from north.Due to recent changes, resource acquision is now entirely player based in a world where 90% of the 300 population server is in the capital and most of the other 100 destinations have no resources to trade. Combat harks from AC Black Flag with crew management detracting from the combat experience (try choosing between sails, gunnery and boarding while in combat)Overall this game is no longer worth the $40 price tag. If you're still interested wait for the full release and keep an eye on the reviews at launch

content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								I have been following the development of Naval Action since early alpha.If the idea of open world realistically simulated 18th century sailing ships is your thing this game is definitely the one to check out. Quick Disclaimer: For people expecting arcadey Assasin's Creed IV - Black Flag gameplay - look elsewhere, this is not a game for you.However if you don't mind the steep learning curve, and being sunk multiple times while learning how to fight an accurately modeled, painfully detailed sailing ship, how to tack into the wind, and sail using compass and stars, this is definitely a game for you.Community is excellent, gameplay is fun, open world is beautiful and massive. If you would like to see more, check out some of the videos i made of the game (although taken at alpha - sea trials stage)


YouTube™ Video: Naval Action - Beautiful Age of Sail - First Look 

			Views: 4,212		

			This is a first look at the alfa for a game called Naval Action. A beautifully designed open world Naval Combat game set in the Age of Sail when big sailing ships roamed the high seas.		

That being said, this is the Early accces game in the full sense of the word. Towns business, main gui, crafting, trading and anything apart from sailing, and battles is extremely basic. Most of the UIs are placeholders. Those that expect port business like in Sid Meier's Pirates will be disappointed for some time.However the feeling of sailing the beautifully crafted open world and engaging in hectic sea battles either vs players or the AI, and mastering the sails is bar to none yet seen in this genre.This game is one of the very few in early access that i wholeheartedly recommend to all sailing ship enthusiasts.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								It is a more realistic version of POTBS, but that has its pros and cons.  The gameplay is much like POTBS;for those that played it and enjoyed it, this is probably a game for you to consider.  The physics are much more realistic than the more arcade nature of POTBS (angles of attack matter, ships list, waves, ricochets, etc.) however so is ship handling and battle length.  This game has a lot of potential, but considering the amount of time it takes to travel in the open world, and the amount of time a single battle takes, if you don't regularly have uninterupted blocks of playtime 4hrs or longer, you probably won't be able to do much in this game.  Currently ports are just menu screens, which seems like something this game falls drastically short of compared to POTBS.  A lack of any kind of initial in game guide compounds the difficulty of the game, but that can be fixed by watching/reading online guides.  It looks like a good game, but I can't recommend it due to the amount of time doing anything takes.

number of helpful: 7 of 13 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								I really struggled whether i would recommend this game or not.For now I would still recommend the game itself, but not the current status.My recommendation: Wait till the next big patch and check it out again. (Please also see my UPDATE-notes)Also pay close attention to the reviews. The ratio of downvotes is off by far regarding the negative reviews, but best make up your own mind.Here is my approach:☸ ☠☠☠ Introduction ☠☠☠ ☸Starting in 2003 with Pirates of the Caribbean by Bethesda with I was obsessed by sailing games. Although the game got the franchise forced on it - which you really could feel - I was hooked from the first minute on. On the lookout for some mods to make the experience some kind smoother, it was Naval Action which caught my attention instead. The time I discovered it was still in greenlight status and yet I was eager to play it from the looks of the impressive pictures.I started my journey in Naval Action in early February and sank a bunch of hours so here is my attempt to give you an overview of the game BUT let me tell you from the start: If you are short on Playtime each day, this game might not be the one for you.☸ ☠☠☠ Gameplay ☠☠☠ ☸The grind to the top is hard and time-consuming but working your way up you learn more and more about the game - cooperating with other players helps immensely. It has a very steep learning curve and no ingame-tutorial whatsoever. You will have to look up quite a bit of things but the community ingame is mostly helpful as well - as long as you dont ask about very basics. And if you let it happen you will meet a lot of nice people collaborating.general:- Age of Sail | sandbox sailing simulator- a sandbox game, and will require you to make your own fun.- mostly clanbased niche-game / rather unfit for casual players - dynamic and slow paced action- player-driven economy- vast openworld-map of the Caribbean with close to 400 harbours- as close to realism as possible in battles and sailing- basic crafting system so far- various ships from 7th to 1st rate - no fancy UI so far- unfinished but work in progress descriptionspro:- Sweet Graphics and Soundeffects- plenty possibilities ingame: Trading and Crafting, Missions (PvE), Duels and battles (PvP)- rare but epic and relentless battles- various possiblities for cooperating with other playerscon:- little to none Endgame-Content- very repetitive (portbattles and missions)- long journeys with nothing to do- combat can take a long time and end in chases up to 1,5 hrs- AI sometimes has unfair advantages- shrinking Playerbase and therefore less PvP- crafting is extremely time consuming atm (It is already beeing reworked[forum.game-labs.net])☸ ☠☠☠ Community ☠☠☠ ☸Coming to NA I was never really the “clan person” but Naval Action showed me how nice it can be. Since you sometimes have a lot of time to kill sailing for a staging, missions or trading it can be fun just talking to other players. A clan is no must-have but it definitely brings more possibilities to the game. Most of the nations also have common Teamspeaks where you can meet up and organize with other players.general:- different ingame chat-channels for different matters ( nation, global, help, ...)- very active forum- most nations have set up TS for collaboratingpro:- Mostly helpful players ingame and on the forums- chat and forums are monitored and toxic players are dealt withcon:- Few active players☸ ☠☠☠ Development ☠☠☠ ☸Naval action is developed by a small team, so dont expect a high pace of developent. BUT the game is formed by the active help of the community. general:- one of the best Age of sail games with a lot of potential- work-in-progress / active development- sometimes drastic changes- sometimes one step forward, two steps back- sometimes groundbreaking new content- expect changes both good and badpro:- content is getting updated frequently- Constant contact with the playerbase- Open for criticism and suggestions- mods and devs have a open ear for problems regarding the game and its mechanicscon:- few content in the last patches- patch notes have few details - no really clear agenda atm- devs are sometimes too emotional interacting with players☸ ☠☠☠ Conclusion ☠☠☠ ☸Do you like being part of an evolving game in early access, like to try new content every month (or so), you can spare the 40 bucks and like the Age of Sail you should definitely give Naval Action a shot. But be warned you will have to sink a lot of hrs into this game to actually achieve something and expect changes both good and bad.The devs have somewhat like a plan[forum.game-labs.net] but seem to priorize different matters never the less each patch. I would advise to wait a few month before you actually buy and see how it plays out. I hope they will eventually get their♥♥♥♥♥♥together.UPDATE:As for the patch 9.96 I would still recommend the game itself but not in the current status since its insanely difficult for new players right now: - Closed Rookiearea as a huge Plus. BUT: - At the moment the market is flooded with gold which makes everything absurldy expensice for new players. - PvP is a ganking fest - mostly consists of either ganking or beeing ganked.  - The new crafting and ressources made it even more time consuming. I still really like the game, but i wouldn't recommend it to new players at the moment. Changes come and go in Early Access so this review will be updated eventually.

number of helpful: 7 of 13 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								Naval action is a early access public alpha that takes place in there sailing era of between 1600-1800 in the Caribbean. The main premise of the game is to bring the age of sail to people who love naval combat.Pros: a massive MASSIVE map to explore, raid, trade or sink you way around in ships ranging from the civilian to heavily armed warships.Great amount of factions instead of just Britain, Spain, Netherlands and France. There are 8 at this time.Combat is heavily based on three things. Which is good. Speed, skill and teamwork. ( a group of small ships working in unison can literally sink a 3rd rate warship.) The Dev team have clearly done their research by reflecting the fact that the amount of guns didn't always win.A trade system which works on supply and demand much like Port Royale franchise. It is hard however as prices don't stay the same as players and wars affect both.Cons: there is no marker on the map to show your position in relation to mission markers. (I had a mission near Jamaica but I found that I was next to Bermuda)There is no way points to help with navigation which both these points can cause huge stress when trying to get to your mission. Especially when you get storms around you.There is no way to test drive ships to see if they are for you and you how they are played.Base resources are too expensive and experience gain from battles is low. It takes 20 missions to get 1000 experience points.You should be able to ring the ships bell any time with each button press to ring it. ( make use of morse code) There should be a progression table to show what you gain from promotions.It is highly function and extremely thrilling with combat and sailing physics and cannon and projectile physics too. It is worth as an early alpha £25-£35 due to its currently working and huge amount if features alongside a already vast community and friendly and dedicated Dev team.Don't ram a ship bigger than yours. You'll be shoved over with leaks in you're boat.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								After several hundred hours in this game I can say most of the negative reviews like so many written by the children on Steam.  Are ones written by people who dont bother to notice the game is in Early Access or more commonly called BETA.   Which is a testing phase not an actual release state for the game.  They expect this instant action 15 minutes of cannon balls and sword swinging Pirates of the Carribean style game... well they are not only wrong but ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ly wrong.   The fact is the game is by far the best age of sail game I have played in a VERY long time.  Is it fast paced, hell no.. is it easy to learn not really.  But it isnt the most complex game I have ever played, that honor still goes to Falcon BMS.   But it is by far one of the best looking and most well done age of sail games out there.   While it still ahs work to be done and is far from release.   But it is shaping up to be one of 2016s best games.In short, if you bought this game thinking World of Warships arena fights, you are wrong, give the game to someone who would appreciate it and just leave quitely.

number of helpful: 7 of 13 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22
Early Access Review
								Pros: The battles are amazing. The ships are finely crafted, and the targeting and damage systems for flying cannonballs both look glorious and feel authentic.Cons: Grind, grind, grind. The game is now Open World only. Meaning you have to sail for hours across an empty ocean (boring!) to get to any battle. You have to grind for weeks to be able to sail anything larger than a frigate. Ganking is rampant, and the game is hemorrhaging players. Several months ago my server was averaging 160-200 on when I was on, now it's down to maybe 60-80 total, across all factions. The game is dying.Many fans have requested custom battles, ranked matches against other players (arena-style), or historical battle reenactment. Any/all of these would build on the game's strengths, but the developers instead are hellbent on having their game be EVE 1806 AD. There is a half-hearted attempt to have arena or matches in port, but I have never once been successfully matched with an opponent. It's broken, and they won't fix it or replace it with something better. Do not recommend.

Just except to have some patience and time in game.

number of helpful: 8 of 15 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								For die hard sailing ship fans this could be the game for you.  For a very early alpha game it shows great potential, plus the devs are constantly updating and fixing bugs, damage, more acurate ships etc. All though there is no set campain missions (Yet) there still is fun in sinking other ships and trading. Upon Joining the Americans (PvE) I was greated by a warm welcome of other players who asisted me in trading and fleet missions to get me a better ship. All thoguh I'm still out classed by their massive ships we still raid the Spanish coast togehter. ProsLike i said, constant updatng don't expect for the glitch or bug you find to last long. Friendly players who are happy to join in your vendetas and help in your crafting or battles. Large amount of ships and ship classes to choose from. Even two of the same ship can have major changes. Either diferent thickness or being faster. easy grinding, most missions give 5000+ coins and different amounts of XP, depending on the mission you chose. Absolutly beautiful world down to the waves lapping against your boat. So even when your not filling a ship at port side full of holes you can still sail around and enjoy the scenery. Trading although a good mechanic still a little sketchy and chalengeing to properly do, best stick to sinking ships to start off. ConsStill in alpha so major bugs and what not everywhere. Sink mechanic kind of boring they just go straight down. You can get lucky and set the oposing ship afire but still, would be niffty seeing a ship rolling to one side or the other or even completly over and then sink. No set tutorial, just drops you in the middle of the ocean and thats that. Find your own way. Best to look up how to videos or consult your local players. Navigation is simple. Map and compass. To simple... map could use gridlines at least. Finding your missions out in the open water. No waypoint no tracker nothing. You just gauge off your map and hope you get close enough to actually see it. There is fast travel but you can't fast travel with loaded goods and when you do theres a set time limit before you can again. (usually 3 hours) To be expected for an MMO but needs work. Sailing is actual time and requires a tone of time. Even sailing the full American controled coast from top to bottom might take close to half an hour. If  the wind plays nice. Port menu kinda boring but I won't complain about that to much. It is just a menu. Still a bit pricey for an early game full of errors. But has huge potential if you dont mind waiting. Still best to wait for it to go on sale. Massive ship battles are long at least an hour. But the payout is great.Just a few of the pros and cons. But I recomend it for all pirate or privateer fans. Saill across the 7 seas,  hoist your nations colors and fight for survival amoungest players, enemy nation ships, and pirates.

								Pro's:A game with extreme amount of potential. Graphics are top notch.Combat Mechanics are amazing. Absolutely amazing. Con's: Gank or be ganked is the name of the game now. I wish there was a "Neutral" option when it comes to recommending the game...

number of helpful: 11 of 21 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21
Early Access Review
								Right off the bat I want to just say: this is great game and I've never spent so many hours with any one steam purchase.  It's early access so there are of course some problems and the Devs can be a bit tetchy at times but it's nothing like has been made out in recent Steam reviews and obviously Early Access means things are changing all the time.  The UI and clan mechanics are a tad basic atm but that's prety minor stuff, escpecially when you consider extremely polished battle system and the quality of the ship models.So the game tries to simulate/gamify being a sea captain in the late 18th/early 19th Century and it does a pretty good job of this.  Obviously it's not a true simulation, the scurvy and weevilvs have been swapped out for live map coordinates and a teleport function if you get really lost, but that's probably for the best.  There are two modes, the Open World which is a large map of the Caribbean where you sail from port to port and the battles.  The battles are phenomenal: beautiful to watch and exciting to play with a realistic flavour absent in SO SO SO many other pirate/sailing games.The game offers various playstyles but I mainly play RvR (Realm vs Realm) where you sail for one of the 7 in-game nations (+ Pirates) and attempt to conquer ports off eachother.  Not all factions work the same way but most have clans that work together to conquer or blockade ports, diplomats that work out deals between the factions and some people who pass it all by and just go sailing the open seas looking for enemies to sink, ignoring RvR completely.  There also are competitions, both dev and player run for people looking for a quick consequence-free ship battle.  Some of the best parts of the game aren't even dev made and that's communities and the culture built up around the game.  There is some toxicity of course, and that's a shame, but it represents a small part of the game experience compared to the vast majority who are courtious and polite and for the most part passionate about history, sailing and just having a good time.  For example: at the moment there's a guy putting out weekly Youtube videos following the battles and conquests on the game with specials on tactics and ships and other assorted game topics.https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCQBM7edgbrg0liG9V5sy-1AThee's another guy making a 3D model of a British 2rd rate from 1768 who posts regular updates on his progresshttp://forum.game-labs.net/index.php?/topic/19328-hms-barfleur-1768-3d-model/and like them there are lots of people doing really cool and interesting things that make the culture around the game a fantastic added benifit.As I said before it's an Early Access game so there are some kinks to be ironed out and that is what's causing the most amountof angst both in the forums and in the Steam Reviews.  It's a game that lots of people are passoionate about so when things head in a certain direction they don't like people get salty.  There's also been a few atempts at using bad steam reviews as a way try and influence the Devs against certain decisions.    I'm not saying that's the reason for all the negative reviews but it's a factor in a few of the most recent ones. The devs can get a bit defensive but personally I wouldn't say they've crossed a line or been rude to people who hadn't first been rude to them. People get salty because they care about the game and they care because it really is a great game.  It's not going to be everyone's cup of tea but if you're on the fence about this one I'd say give it a go.

number of helpful: 13 of 25 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29
Early Access Review
								Pretty much everything you read about this game is true, both good and bad, but it most certainly does not deserve all the negative reviews that dominate the top of board, at least one of them written by someone who still plays the game. Go figure.This game is in early access. It is not finished and some things you might take for granted - such as a tutorial - simply don't exist. The players (some of them) are helpful enough but it takes ages to talk through - or write in chat - all the game mechanics you will encounter in your first few minutes playing. If you are thinking of buying this game, do read forums, game guides, check out youtube and so on to find at least the basics of how to play so you don't entirely swamp Help chat with questions when you start.The devs and chat and forum moderators are ... erratic. Sometimes it seems like Geppetto has carved this beautiful game, but he grew old, tired, blind or something and left it to his wayward apprentices to finish. There must have been some great vision to have got this far, but until recently it seemed to have been lost with a history of abandoned trials (which players predicted would fail, and they did) finishing up with three grand announcements about a server wipe, allocating crafting resources to the 25 Port Battle winning participants, and merging the PvE and PvP servers. The server wipe was widely accepted as a good idea and is planned for 20th April 2017, and I think it is to the dev's great credit that the other two ideas have been withdrawn. The PvE server will now stay for at least 18 months after release, followed by a review (and quite honestly I will be surprised if release is in 2017 - I think there's quite a lot of life left in PvE, but your guess is as good as mine).On technical points the devs actually seem very good at listening (despite what you might read), but they are sometimes poor at communicating and they appear to have a total blind spot when it comes to humour, particularly it seems from American players (I think they don't pick up very well on American cultural references). If you post anything funny that could possibly be misconstrued as an accusation (against them or a fellow player - it doesn't matter) you can expect a week's forum ban. They are very heavy handed.The playerbase is also sometime overly aggressive, misogynistic and unsympathetic to people who like to play in a different manner from them. But this is an MMO so it goes with the territory, I'm afraid. However this is almost certainly the best age of sail game you have ever played so if the only thing putting you off is that it is an MMO with all that entails, perhaps the PvE server might be for you. People are polite there; there is no aggression - literally at the moment: no other player can ever attack you and right now AI ships won't attack you either (but you can attack them). This will probably change so there is some form of AI aggression (this is an early access game so things change - I really cannot repeat this enough), but either way it opens the possibility for playing the game like a sailing sim, roleplaying or whatever takes your fancy, things you cannot usually do in a combat-orientated MMO.Personally, crafting is my thing so I play on a PvP server, where there is real demand as well as risk. The crafting system isn't yet sorted so - as with so many other bits of the game - don't come here with too high expectations, but the 20th April server wipe will bring changes which look good from here. I look forward to finding out.Finally, if you are reading this before 20th April, don't think you need to put off buying the game till after then. Start before and you'll keep your combat and crafting xp and be given 4 free ships after the wipe. Come on in, the water's lovely.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								Avoid this development team in the game's current condition. You'll regret buying it.I bought this game because of my love for ships and while this does indeed quench that desire ... I've noticed very little has changed in the time i've played, watched videos and read the VERY vaguely explained patch notes themselves... Ocasional FPS buffers, sometimes a ping spike 'patch' that helps stabilize long-winded trips out into the deeper confines of the ocean tides... But nothing very stable that can be considered extensively "important" (major ship additions, revamped shop UI's and such, better ship ramming (still can flip a ship just by rubbing it long enough) and still could use some major reworking when it comes to physics effecting ship shrapnel... stronger FRIENDLY communication with the players and so forth is still nowhere to be found. Most admins on the forums themselves defend the game's "positive" aspects. But degrade ANYONE that negatively shames their game and development team. They silence those that post their concerns. This wouldn't be too severe if it wasn't for the fact they don't simply silence those that make stupid retorts like "this game sucks" or "fix the game" ... they silence those that actually give suggestions, tell them where they're doing things wrong, and take their frustrations out on the players themselves as if they are the reason they are failing. Having played over 40 Alpha games, purchasing my way into many of them to help the developers where i believed they could make a beautiful game, and earning my way into a few as well like Crossout and World of Warships (albeit those will be coming out as F2P's later on. WoWS being in open Beta/"launch stages" in retrospect) I can not stress this enough about testers' relationship with their respective development team..Developers who refuse to accept they need to work on something specific, or blame the community for their incompetance, WILL NOT MAKE IT PAST THEIR FIRST YEAR OF FULL RELEASE WITH POSITIVE MARKS nor make headway in marketing and eventually collapse within a 2 year timeframe.You can not blame the customers for a developer issue. You can not blame slow development on a small player base due to your lack of new content to test and lack of communication with your players/ability to advertise effectively to the right playerbase.And you sure as hell can not blame your players for being mad at admins that refuse to man up and accept they're out of line with their constant slandering of the playerbase when the playerbase PURCHASED a game that refuses to show progress going towards their release date.A perfect example of this is Ant's review.  found here Until this game can show some true expansion into becoming an even greater game, and hold to their promises... this game will not be able to be taken seriously. Especially if they must rely upon the bribery of the players' vote to make progress when it should be their own diligence and desire to see a gem of a program shine beyond that which are considered their competitor development teams...You've been "released" here on steam less than 11 months, and are still bare-bones. I don't expect a lot from a young game like this. But the things i, as a paying tester and requested support "pillar" in the progression of this game's future, do expect (as do many other players here)... are 4 things in particular.1) a strong, focused development team looking forward with a clear vision for the game in development. 2) An administration/moderation team that is here to help the playerbase no matter the issue, and to help quell concerns in a professional way.3) consistent, DETAILED patch notes to help us see exactly how the game is progressing or where problems may come about.4) New content.. either supported by the playerbase or made with the intent of progressing the game's development and expand upon the game's replay-capability and stretching out to new players... Right now NONE of that is being shown nor thought about. Matter of fact the opposite is being shown. And until these 4 core problems are looked at and rectified, there will never be much more than a "small niche" of players that have stayed loyal since the beginning. (at the moment that "niche" is about 1300 players across multiple servers.) And of course, the population of players that refuse to watch the game to be treated so disrespectfully while game admins are spitting at the community...I'm sorry. But you're sinking faster than the RMS Lusitania at this rate... and it's being done by your own hands.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								I love parts of this game but just cannot reccomend it as it stands. The devs have a fantastic setup for the future of this game and will surely make a game that will go down in history. But as of right now, there is just too many flaws that make me rage quit this game every time I try and get into it. I'll list some of my complaints below. Keep in mind that I have been playing this game quite a bit to try and see if maybe I am doing something wrong, but I am convinced that this game has too many issues for me personally.1. There is no tutorial at all. This game has a very very steep learning curve, almost like hopping into IL-2 1946 on max realism for your first time. You are dropped into the game and are on your own immediately. They don't even tell you how to open your sails to move. You are forced to get in touch with a clan who can train you and provide you with some basic knowledge about how to even use the port menus. Joining a clan isn't too bad of an idea since almost all of the larger clans are happy to help but if you like to be a lone wolf it can be very frustrating.2. The AI is extremely overpowered if you try to battle by yourself. This is perhaps my biggest pet peeve about this game. If you are by yourself trying to do a mission on your level it is nearly impossible to sink the AI. I did a battle in which I was in a Navy Brig, the AI was in a regular Brig. I had 37 leaks on his ship and he was at near zero armor. He was still floating like nothing happened. He could even sail into the wind at 8 - 10 knots while the second I turned into the wind, I came to a dead stop. I was at around quarter armor all around and had 0 leaks and I was taking on water at crazy rates after one broadside. I have never been able to take on an AI in battle unless I had a fleet with me or took on a low level mission while using a large ship. The AI seems to be way too accurate, way too maneuverable, and have armor that seems like it's made out of cast iron.3. The optimization is absolutely terrible. Not much really to be said on this subject. The game has pretty bad optimization.4. The game is extremely grindy for XPIf you want to level up within a day you have to get used to doing back to back missions. It's not bad at first but once you reach level 4 or 5, it takes forever to level up. If you want to get this to play for only a couple hours a day, you might want to get used to the cutter because it will take you weeks to level up. While this can be a con, it is also understandable since you don't want everyone rolling around in the best ship.I have many more complaints, but I am really not trying to go on a b*tch fest here. I'm just trying to say what I don't like about this game. I will probably continue to try and like this game but as I said before, unless you are constantly with a couple of people to help you in battle, it is near impossible to win fights unless you go against a small ship. For $40 I would personally say wait until this goes on sale for at the most $25 and pick it up then if you really want it.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								My first game review, though I own many games on steam.The reason for this is Naval warfare in the age of sail is close to my heart.Firstly, like many others have said, the graphics are very pretty, which nice on its own, does also lend a sense of immersion.So I hope graphically it continues to to be the way it is so far.There is a few choices of nations, to start, which cant be a bad thing, some reportedly are underplayed, but there is time im sure to balance that out, though some will always be the underdogs in a way, as they might of been historcially, due to various influences.I have seen people knock the game so far for not having a tutorial, well, there are many video's on youtube and also in my opinion, there isn't a lot of complex mechanics going on in the game at present. As for the complexity and realism of sailing an age of sail warship and gunnery, there is information all over the internet. The game doesn't hold your hand in many respects and I personally like that, for instance, you dont see where you are on the sea, you have to work it out yourself. But I hope they can introduce somehow realistic mechanics, maybe a sextant, the sun, stars, or similar to add to realism, for navigation.The game map covers the caribbean, whilst large it's not something you can get lost in for days, but I have heard it takes  several hours real time to sail it's width, wind dependant I assume.The interface currently is really basic, hopefully that will improve and be polished.You can dock in ports, which is represented in port by an interface, no avatar combat or walking around port. You can buy and sell in other ports and I think there is organised warfare between nations on some scale.Naval Action, has the beginning of possibly a great niche game, one that I think many people may want to play, it looks beatiful, the sailing and gunnery seem realistic. It remains to be seen how the game develops in a broader sense, with trading, crafting, warfare and the meta game, but the nuts and bolts of the game seem well established.

								This game is AWESOME! Open world sandbox, PvP and PvE, port battles, and just the joy of sailing are a few things you will find in Naval Action. The graphics in this game are stunning at full settings; from the ship models to the world itself and ambiance. The sounds have a ways to go but meh, it's quite easy to look past with the rest of the beauty this game has to offer. If you are a fan of the age of sail I HIGHLY recommend this game :DUpdate:A year later... this game is still awesome :)

content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								Early Access review. Don't treat this game as finished. You should assume the professionalism of the team behind the game and trust they will fix major issues.--First and foremost, I want to think that this is one of those games where if you don't like the context or subject matter at least a bit, you're going to hate it. If you do love it, you will probably find it effortless to learn the game, as I did. I didn't need a tutorial, I didn't need to ask questions, all the information you need is on the screen and if you've spent any time playing games and know the most basic requirements for floating a boat on water, you will figure it out. I recommend a peek at the game's key bindings for a hint as that is what I do in any new game I pick up. I see most of the negative reviews on this game are a result of new players not knowing what to do or supposedly not having questions answered.This doesn't make the game bad. In my experience, this is one of the most polished vehicle combat experiences I've ever handled. In the CURRENT state of the game, however? You will not have a lot of fun if you do not like shooting boats with your boat as of writing this review, trade is entirely unfinished as are non-combat missions.Another point of contention is the UI. We all know it's not the prettiest. But it works. And this is early access. Devs require support, so they offer the game before it's done in trust that you will understand this is not full release and tell them what needs fixing. UI is something on their list. They know. It even says "test UI" in-game. Another thing! This is not an instant-gratification game. There IS a grind. And if you don't want to slag away at your XP (as it stands in the current state of the game) in order to get bigger boats, more crew, either don't purchase, or wait and see how the game develops.This is all my subjective perspective and doesn't at all speak for other experiences. But I hope this may at least help you decide if this is or isn't a game for you.

								Pros--Fun ship to ship combat -Good to play with friends -Only requires a medium spec PC-Amazing graphics Cons--You will (NEED) to play with a group or friends to be succesfull -The trading system seems to be useless atm -There is a real grind to get better ships with most battles bringing around 100-200XP and you need 100 xp for the first rank 2500 xp for the 2nd and 5000 xp for the 3rd rank then it goes even further....(it's hard to find battles you can win so it takes hours) also each battle lasts around 20 mins depending on the amount of ships and ranks --I recommend this game fully, the frame work is there it just requires more updates to improve after player feedback updates are frequent------------This game is not woth 30 pound only buy if your willing to stick with the game through development---------

content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is actually pretty damn awesome, even with it being nothing like I expected it to be (I was expecting vast open world battles that greatly focused on realism).  While the game is more realistic than the others that are currently on the market, there are still some things that throw it off.  Battles are initiated, which are followed by a loading screen.  Anyone in the area joins the battle when its initiated, and others are able to join while its in session by going to that location and joining.  The game is pretty slow, yet feels very fast paced.  Most battles tend to last about 30+ minutes, but every second of those 30 minutes is a great experiance.Probably one of those games that over the next couple months I'll put a couple hundred hours into; and will more than likely return to afterwards.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								For those interested in a deep, methodical, and strategic Naval Combat & Trading game, this is the cream of the crop. Even while in early access, I have found immense pleasure in sailing the Caribbean, using only a compass and landmarks to navigate, and engaging enemy vessels with a number of beautiful ships. The combat is comprehensive, utilizing demasting, chain shots against sails, wind, and positional damage--shoot below the waterline to start sinking a vessel, or use grapeshot on their weather deck to kill crew before boarding! This game is certainly not for everyone; it is NOT an arcade game, and if you do not have the patience to truly explore and learn the skills needed, you may not find that you enjoy this game. But, for those of you with a hardy constitution and a love of the sea, you'll find no better game to capture the sense and feel of Napoleonic Naval Warfare.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								Sitting at the dock of the bay, minding my own business when all of a sudden on the faction chat there is a call to arms.10 pirates are harassing some of our controlled waters and they did already for a couple of days.  So a lesson needed to be taught.Within 10 minutes the bay flocked with faction members and all jumped on Teamspeak.I was sailing my yacht, the smallest ship in game.The pirates were sailing Frigates.Anyway, I'm a speedy Gonzales compared to these monsters, so I just need to stay at their stern or bow to avoid their deadly volleys. So we were spread out in the bay, sails down and playing the waiting game and set the ambush..When suddenly they got spotted, I raced my yacht to them and started to call an attack.Battle started and BAM, 25 players all sorts of ships VS 10 Pirates.One or two fled, the others got sunk. While our nation was still teamed up we've raced to the pirates respawn harbour and took them for another fight, reducing their available ships in our nations waters.This is what makes this game great.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								So it's time to change my review since I'm now 800+ hours into this game.I have pretty much experienced all the game has to offer, and I have to say Naval Action is my game. It's my Star Wars Galaxies, my Eve Online, and every other game I've played over the years that has sucked me in to become an obsession.Let me be blunt. Naval Action falls into the marmite category in that you will either love it or hate it depending on what you look for in a PC MMO.  It is NOT a game for people who want instant fast paced action. It's not a game for kids, and it's not a game for those who don't have even a slight interest in 18th century naval warfare.It IS a game for the more mature gamer who enjoys a PVP game that has moments of inactivity (sailing) with burst of exciting naval combat with opposing players. The ships are beautiful and combat is very realistic.  I've read all the recent negative reviews about this game having no end game content. Frankly I find this absurd. The end game 'content' quite simply is PVP. These guys have rushed to get in the biggest ships then wonder why people run from their 1st rate fleet. Their ego limits their ability to get out of their first rates and into something more PVP focused. In addition, they forgotten that this is an ALPHA game with much of the content still in development.The other comments I read are about chat bans. As a 41 year old gamer, I've seen it all. Many MMO's have such a toxic community, it can be enough to put you off playing the game. NA on the other hand have a low tolerance attitude towards toxic idiots who have gotten it into their heads that due to the anonymity of the internet, can say and do what they like without fear of consequence. In naval action, such idiots are quickly dealt with leaving the rest of us rational and respectful players to get on with the game without having to deal with the drama queens.  Seriously folks, if you've been turned off a game because of its community, you'll find the NA community to be one of the most helpful and friendliest out there.So as a potential purchaser of Naval action, let me tell you about what you can expect.Once you get through the early stages of the game and get into a ship that has a role in combat, you will want to join a clan. NA is a social game and really it's all about the clan. Do your research, find a good one and I can promise you, you'll have a great time.  Once you are sailing with your clan, your world of possibilities opens up, and you'll spend a lot of your time going out and either defending your own waters against enemy players who try to harass your countrymen, or you'll go to their waters and try to harass theirs.  PVP is usually never hard to find.For the PVE'ers, there is content for you here too, but I can imagine without PVP, it will become repetitive fast. PVP is were it's at!Like EVE online, NA has it's interesting politics. You'll no doubt find a nemesis, that guy you are determined to catch and sink.  There's lots of personalities out there, and you could be one too. Being 'famous' is all part of the attraction of NA, just like the real sea captains of the time.  For me, it's these clashes of personalities ad egos that makes this game so much fun.At £29.99, in terms of fun per investment, I can tell you with my 800+ hours in this game, It's given me approximately 790 more hours of fun than AAA The Division at almost double the price.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								Have had the game during early days when it was available only as a paypal bought option at the Sea Trials stage. I did mess around with the open world starting points when those came out. But, was a bit more difficult at the time due to mass packs of enemy AI running around. Currently, I'd say the devs have some work ahead of them. Nothing insurmountable or even that difficult that I would say they have to do. I have yet to really see anything that could be a bug or even be considered game breaking. Damage modeling is exceptional, and doing targeted shots can be very useful.. Not a run and gun shooter or action game. Combat involves ensuring position prior to going into a fight, and using strategy, tactics, proper formation use, and pure skill at manuevering a ship. If you want something that is a slight challenge, with sandbox attributes, and a good solid community then this is one of those games. I would rank the community as being close to if not on par with the great community EvE has built over it's many years.

								Loving the game so far!  My laptop struggles a bit (plus a slow internet connection), but I look forward to trying it on my desktop with better internet. There is some uncertainty about etiquette for entering battles vs the AI that other players are already engaged in.  Some people welcome the help and others feel like you're stealing their xp.  Hopefully some sort of optional lock-out system will be implemented (or already exists and I just don't know about it).  All-in-all a great game, worth the $40 even in Early Release.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								Create a character, pick a nation to work with (or ye Pirates), then start learning the art of naval combat.  Once you learn a little you will gain XP and gold to be used to purchase larger ships.  Bigger ships brings more intense battles as well as higher XP and gold rewards.Or if you prefer to be a merchant you can travel the Caribbean searching for the best markets to purchase base materials like logs and metal ore.  Then transport it back to your base of operations and craft ships and materials that you can sell for a profit.  If you get good at it there is a huge markup on high-end ships.For an "Early Access" game it feels fairly polished.  The only exception is the port/crafting/shopping interface which is expected to get a makeover.

content:

Early Access Review
								This is a great game, and can only get better from here. The combat is very well done, and detailed. The open world if VAST and interesting if a bit sparse at the moment. The pvp fights for conquests are interesting and the game does little in the way of holding your hand.The game is best played with a group of people out hunting down missions or other players, as well as working together to bettter the nation you play on. You can join a PVE server if pvp is not your thing, but you also don't entirely need to participate in pvp if you don't wish to on the pvp server itself either if you stay away from the front lines.All in all, I feel like the game needs a little more time in the development cooker but as far as early access is concerned this is a game that has already sucked out over 174 hours of my time as of writing this. number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								One of my first reviews because this game deserves itFirstly the developers have obviously put a lot of thought in to this game and continue to add fixes and patches, really great work on their part. I was scepticle with this game at first I've tried games alike to this in the past and although they were good there was nothing that made them gripping, this game seriously has it all.The graphics are actually amazing for this game, they also keep adding little tweaks which make them more intense as the patches come out. The clans are great use and you are part of nations opposing every other nation, get in the right clan and its 24/7 game play.You can play this game in several ways depending on what you want to achieve. You can play as a trader and make your money, you can also combine that and be a crafter making ships for others to buy from you. The crafting aspect is actually very good, one being that you don't just get automatic rights to craft anything you like, it creates more thinking and a tech tree to follow, one part makes this part and you only get a certain amount of labour you can use per hour which means people can't gain silly amounts of advantage. Also you have to craft certain types of ships with just a small % of a chance you'll get the blue prints to other ships meaning it takes time and tactic to be able to craft different ships.Now if you go for the battle side this is a very broad game play. We have port battles, PvP or just plain old hunt the AI. I must admit alot of thought has gone into this; you need to be able to think, control and watch. The devs keep patching this area and adding or smoothing out the tweaks and doing an amazing job for it. When sailing in battle you have to think which direction you are going, where your sails are pointing how much sail you have, how many people on guns, how many people on plugging leaks. It really is in depth as a game gets for this area you quite literally can control everything. Overall I would extremely recommend this game and urge anyone thinking to get this. The price tag is worth it!!! Constant patches and planned improvements that are set this game to be one you won't get bored on. I've clocked so many hours and the worst part is I never saw those hours go by, its truly addictive when you join the right clan community; my main tip is to join a clan to maximise every aspect of this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								An open-world combat and trading experience, Naval Action is a pretty damn good sailing game. It is heavily in alpha, however: UI elements are plainly unfinished, there are very few tooltips to help anyone get started, and even statistics are poorly formatted and explained.With all that being said, what exactly are you getting?You're getting an open world experience whereby you sail around, encounter enemy players (read: not a member of your nation) and then challenge them to battle. You and them begin an instanced ship-on-ship battle whereby you can either stand and fight or run by avoiding fire for a minute or so.Ship customization isn't here yet, though equipment and crafting is. It is possible, but difficult, to craft an entire ship from scratch by buying the components for it. Obtaining these resources other than buying them, however, is apparently not possible.The game prides itself more towards realism than arcade simulation: physics make targeting enemies on the open sea difficult, as both your ship and the enemy ship bob and crest with waves. There is a map, but it does not tell you where you are. You have to navigate the world the old-fashioned way: using your compass.It does support PvP and PvE servers, and in PvE you can only fight NPC ships. In PvP you can be challenged by just about anyone, and trading becomes far more challenging. Hiring fleet vessels to protect you in a PvP scenario is a must.Overall, it's highly unpolished but well worth $55 CAD. If you like this concept, but are intimidated by its skill ceiling, take a look at the Steam game Windward instead.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								Having aspirations to become a naval officer and chagrined I will likely never have the chance to captain a warship under independent command (given my country's pitifully small navy), I took great interest in Naval Action. While rather pricey for a game still in an open alpha, the game itself is quite fun – with new content being added regularly.While still a game in active development with quite a few flaws and the sometimes painfully repetitious grinding for higher ranks/manpower/resources to make components to construct ships, the freedom afforded in the game is outstanding. Learning optimal angles to sail in the wind, manoeuvring to ripple off broadside after broadside at foes with great plumes of gunsmoke obscuring your vessel, your battleline - and ominously, that of the enemy. The ability to board an enemy vessel to take a grand prize for yourself and the crew. This game exudes the spirit of the Napoleonic era.More than that, nothing quite beats the exhilaration of participating in a PVP fleet action in a wee 7th rate cutter against 4th and 5th rate enemy ships.  The stark terror of the sea about your small ship awash from a 25-gun broadside of 18 pound shot, with a mere six-gun broadside of 6-pounder shot to reply with.
