content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								In some ways acting as a successor to Pirates of the Burning sea, Naval action is a far more realistic voyage into naval combat. The game has a large focus on trade, and the major nations must struggle for control over all of the major trading ports in their attempt to acheive naval superiority. Large scale naval battles are acheived in a grand fashion, with beautifully rendered oceans, and ships. Smoke billows off of freshly fired cannons, and drifts away slowly with the breeze. Battles in Naval action require a bit of practice, and an understanding of basic seamanship will help asspiring captains greatly. The action here is slower than many games, and requires a bit of tactical positioning; it is critical that players learn to use the wind to their advantage if wishing to avoid destruction.Naval action is still in early access and has a number of issues at the moment.While the game is lovely, this graphical fidelity comes at a performance cost; further optimizations will hopefully reduce the strain on mid-range systems such as my own, but with my rig the game is perfectly playable. The UI leaves much to be desired as well, as the developers have opted to use a placeholder GUI while they work on core mechanics. This issue should easily be resolved in the coming months.CPU:i5-3750k 2.6ghz - OC 4.0ghzNvidia Geforce 660ti 16gb ddr3 ramWhile It might not be for everyone, I personally rate Naval Action at ~ 9/10.Technical issues keep me from giving it a perfect score, but I fully expect those to be resolved at a steady pace.

number of helpful: 9 of 18 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6
Early Access Review
								Naval Action presents one of the most unique and revolutionary attempts at melding an MMORPG with a "World of Warships" style gameplay. As someone with 600+ hours and on a hiatus since this game's Early Access Steam launch, I can truly say that this is one of the more ambitious games on the market which will unfortunately be both its strength and weakness. It goes without saying that Naval Action will be in early access for the indefinite future, with many massive features such as whether there will be an "over world" section of the game or not still on the chopping block. This and many other important "MMORPG" aspects such as trading, PvP, PvE, in my eyes are still yet to be finalized by the developers' vision, which I confirmed after observing discussions of this game's future with developers on their Naval Action forums. It is important to list this project's current faults to anyone considering purchase in the forseeable future (months or so from writing this review at the least):-Player population is dismal. Will spike when major content releases like most MMORPGs experience player traffic, however Naval Action is considerably more niche in the genre and sees maybe 1000~ players on generous days. When Naval Action releases on Steam fully, it must truly be impressive to maintain a truly enjoyable playerbase for a game of this scope.-Most population/interest is focused in the European zone. If you want a truly "massive" experience, you will learn to accept European latency. -Development is slow and often times due not just to a small dev team, but rather their circular decisions on some core aspects of the game. For instance, in the short few weeks I was active the dev team consistently patched varying versions of the "PvP tag circle" mechanic which would initiate battles. While a rather divisive issue in the community, the developers' responses/patches were usually delayed and they ultimately went back and forth on their decision to this mechanic multiple times. I wonder how much developer time was wasted on this indecisiveness, when they could have been improving other aspects of this game so desperately lacking? (PvE, Exploring, Tracking, Economy, Quests, UI, etc.) -Bare bones. The combat simulator portion of this game is enjoyable, but so far Naval Action fails to sell the idea that you are a Naval Captain in a truly massive conflict where players pull the strings. Expect dull trade runs, "fishing" by pressing a button, zero quests, and very boring PvE battles to farm up ranks to use better ships. Casual players beware.Now let's discuss the positive aspects of Naval Action:-If you're a fan of historical naval tactics, engagements, naval vessels, etc. from about 1600-1820, you will be greatly impressed at this game's attention to detail. Battles lack the "arcade" feel, while not being completely boring, especially if two players finally commit to a sea battle. Expect 30+ minutes of fighting where every shot counts, de-masts are devastating, and managing your crew/repairs both on the open sea and in battles are crucial to your career and survival. Digital ships are modelled straight from primary historical sources with amazing graphical fidelity.-Developers are active and intertwined with their community. While they are subject to criticism, apathy on the forums is not one of them. Funding does not seem to be an issue either, so do not expect development to stall purely because of money.-Scope. Macro-management. Immersion. While nowhere near its final implementation, I feel the developers' vision of nations full of players fighting/politicking/backstabbing/and monopolizing the Caribbean in a purely player-driven experience all with an 18th century flair can be fully realized. EVE Online is often used as inspiration in Naval Action's development, but it's clear the devs here are interested in striking their own path. Even lacking in its physical form, I feel this is still a pro in my eyes as so few games these days have this kind of ambition.So down to the final question: Should you buy it?My answer is: No. Until this game releases, I would not spend your money unless you're truly interested in shaping this game's future. Currently, it is still in VERY early development and ultimately boring once you've gotten your fill of the naval combat simulator Naval Action truly is at this point. Not an MMORPG. I eagerly await Naval Action's launch and to see if the developers' vision truly holds to their promises.-Carr

content:
Posted: April 4
Early Access Review
								I've been watching this game for awhile now but the tons of negative views kept me at bay... And that was stupid. This game is pretty great, as is evident by the tons of b****ing by people with 1,000-ish hours of playtime complaining which is generally a good sign that the underlying game is sound. The UI is rough around the edges, as is getting started. But once you move past that you're greated by a beautiful engine, fantastic physics with engaging and immersive gameplay. Waves will lift your cannons above the horizon making you miss shots, you won't pay attention to the wind and get your ship virtually stuck not moving, you'll have your main mast blown away by cannonfire... At the time of writing the player numbers are rather low as the devs are about to reset stats but it hasn't bothered me much. Still finding plenty to see and do and helpful players to talk, fight and interact with. A++ game, don't listen to the people ♥♥♥♥♥ing and moaning with hundreds of hours of playtime. There is a reason they keep coming back and are so mad, because the underlying game is pretty fantastic. tldr - 'real combat,' sweet physics; waves are real, cannon balls are real, rekt & get rekt. UI shi**y, rough around edges, but's it's an Alpha still. F**k da haters.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								If you loved PotBS, you will love this game. This is basically the same game with a few better mechanics. + Firing require additionnal aiming, affected by the sea. + Graphics are much better+ World map is much larger, it has pro and cons but I believe it is better like this, players will be able to "own" regions since it would be really hard for anyone to quickly travel across the entire map for defense. It could easily take up to 6-8+ hours to cross the entire map.+ Economy is more simple, which is a bad and good thing. Everything is viable so there is no chance everybody end up producing the same thing like in other games due to the cost effectiveness. At the same time it remove a little of depth.+ Devs are creating events with special rewards / blueprints.+ Roles are more flexible, players can be at anytime a privateer / trader / navy officer.+ Can customize cannon pounding of each deck+ Damage is realistic, constantly shooting a mast will destroy it, same with rudder, crew etc.+ Navigation is pretty good, you can  control each individual mast, assign crew in sailing, repair, gunnery, survival, boarding.- UI is really ugly, in fact we keep discovering context menus or label that are actually clickable. At least, it quickly become the least of our concern.- Maybe it is not actually a con, but I know there are mortar ships in the game and while I have not personally been able to used them or see them in action, I am pretty sure they aren't a good addition to the game since the completly move away from the standard fighting style.Neutral : I am unsure whether or not update progress is fast yet since I have recently started. It look like the devs added a lot of content since then however the game still really feel like an alpha after 6 months. I would assume it could have been faster but I do not know the size of the team, at the same time making sure everything is tested throughly isntead of rushing through everything is a good thing.

								Considering that this game is in Early ALPHA, I'd say it's quite an experience!On my first exploration day I managed to capture (by grape-shooting crew) 2 ships: a Lynx and a Snow. number of helpful: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								While the game is still in development, and the dev team are interested in feedback from the players, their obstinate refusal to offer anything close to realism in the way of maritime navigation is the deal-breaker for me. No matter how pretty you make the sunsets, no matter how detailed the ships, no matter the accuracy of the eye-candy for the period, having to rely on landmarks for navigation is possibly the stupidest game mechanic decision they have made. They give you a compass and what amounts to a speedometer, and tell you to navigate by sight. No concession to anything realistic about sailing is made. The world map is lovely, yet worthless in regard to getting from A to B. Yes, you can see the port you just departed from, and yes, you can see the port you may be attempting to reach. You can even see the crossed sabers indicating the position of the ship(s) you are instructed to sink, etc. What you are not given, and what you will be never given (unless the dev team comes down off their high horse) is any indication of where the hell you are on that same map. I played Pirates of the Burning Sea at launch, and then again 2 yrs ago. While Naval Action is in the "simulation" category, and PotBS was not, for all of its faults, PotBS was a better game. It had character and style. NA has plenty of screenshot-worthy moments, but the ludicrous and intentional lack of navigation realism cannot but render this game to me anything beyond a mobile Geoff Hunt painting. If you want to sail a pretty ship around scanning the horizon for a landmark to fix your position, then buy the game.  I think I'll uninstall for now and come back when the game is finished. Maybe, by then, the devs will realize that their desire for players to experience being "lost at sea" because navigation tools like an octant or a sextant would make it too easy is a cop-out.I have not, and will not say anything about the lack of tutorial, etc. because it IS an Early Access game. If you have a couple of spare $20 bills lying around, buy the game. If you would rather see your money put to better use, send it to me and help me pay off my student loans.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game has a lot of potential to become a great game, but in the state that it is currently in it isn't. The developers don't really see what will keep a gamer  playing their game and what wont. It is not player balanced with nations. Basically it is USA and Brits fighting. If you are a player that doens't like to struggle in a game then join the USA nation and be bored most of the time. If you would like to have a challange and maybe get♥♥♥♥♥♥♥daily by USA now and then, then you shoudld join one of the other many nations in this game.  Another thing that is pretty bad about this game is that the gameplay is pretty repetative gameplay. No matter if you are pulling some NPCs from a different nation or doing missions on your own, it is all the same thing it never changes or there isn't anything different on how the scenario can change depending on the weather or any other factor. My recomendation to those who are thinking of buying this game is that if you would like to spend the money to see how the game is, well just watch videos first of the game on Youtube and then make your decision. The grinding is a pain in the butt though.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								Naval Action has very few bugs and has very good gameplay, having both a low skill floor, and a high skill ceiling, which are usually the biggest problems when a game is released. The economy system is currently very unstable due to the low player base, and once the player base grows so does the potential. The crafting system could use some tweaking, for instance they could add a project tracker where no matter what tab you are in on the crafting menu you can see what you need in order to build that new ship, and with the low player base getting a new ship can be a pain sometimes, but it has potential. The battles are very fun, and it is very satisfying to set an enemy ship on fire and watch as it sails next to one of its allies and blows up, although it can be quite anticlimactic when you fire one broadside and sink the ship, because you got lucky and all the shots went under the water line when the ship was rolling away from you.I have 60 hours put into the game and have yet to see one bug or crash.I would say it is better quality than some games that are already released, and Naval Action is still in alpha testing. As others have said the biggest issue is probably the UI. The UI is very simple and easy to use but it isnt very pretty. If you dont mind having a very minimalistic UI in your menu screens, then I would definately recommend this game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								One of my first reviews because this game deserves itFirstly the developers have obviously put a lot of thought in to this game and continue to add fixes and patches, really great work on their part. I was scepticle with this game at first I've tried games alike to this in the past and although they were good there was nothing that made them gripping, this game seriously has it all.The graphics are actually amazing for this game, they also keep adding little tweaks which make them more intense as the patches come out. The clans are great use and you are part of nations opposing every other nation, get in the right clan and its 24/7 game play.You can play this game in several ways depending on what you want to achieve. You can play as a trader and make your money, you can also combine that and be a crafter making ships for others to buy from you. The crafting aspect is actually very good, one being that you don't just get automatic rights to craft anything you like, it creates more thinking and a tech tree to follow, one part makes this part and you only get a certain amount of labour you can use per hour which means people can't gain silly amounts of advantage. Also you have to craft certain types of ships with just a small % of a chance you'll get the blue prints to other ships meaning it takes time and tactic to be able to craft different ships.Now if you go for the battle side this is a very broad game play. We have port battles, PvP or just plain old hunt the AI. I must admit alot of thought has gone into this; you need to be able to think, control and watch. The devs keep patching this area and adding or smoothing out the tweaks and doing an amazing job for it. When sailing in battle you have to think which direction you are going, where your sails are pointing how much sail you have, how many people on guns, how many people on plugging leaks. It really is in depth as a game gets for this area you quite literally can control everything. Overall I would extremely recommend this game and urge anyone thinking to get this. The price tag is worth it!!! Constant patches and planned improvements that are set this game to be one you won't get bored on. I've clocked so many hours and the worst part is I never saw those hours go by, its truly addictive when you join the right clan community; my main tip is to join a clan to maximise every aspect of this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								An open-world combat and trading experience, Naval Action is a pretty damn good sailing game. It is heavily in alpha, however: UI elements are plainly unfinished, there are very few tooltips to help anyone get started, and even statistics are poorly formatted and explained.With all that being said, what exactly are you getting?You're getting an open world experience whereby you sail around, encounter enemy players (read: not a member of your nation) and then challenge them to battle. You and them begin an instanced ship-on-ship battle whereby you can either stand and fight or run by avoiding fire for a minute or so.Ship customization isn't here yet, though equipment and crafting is. It is possible, but difficult, to craft an entire ship from scratch by buying the components for it. Obtaining these resources other than buying them, however, is apparently not possible.The game prides itself more towards realism than arcade simulation: physics make targeting enemies on the open sea difficult, as both your ship and the enemy ship bob and crest with waves. There is a map, but it does not tell you where you are. You have to navigate the world the old-fashioned way: using your compass.It does support PvP and PvE servers, and in PvE you can only fight NPC ships. In PvP you can be challenged by just about anyone, and trading becomes far more challenging. Hiring fleet vessels to protect you in a PvP scenario is a must.Overall, it's highly unpolished but well worth $55 CAD. If you like this concept, but are intimidated by its skill ceiling, take a look at the Steam game Windward instead.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								At time of writing Naval Action is still in its early access alpha phase. So if you start to play this you have to come in with the right mind set. It's not finished and things are are changed around and tweaked by the developers all the time. New stuff is also being added, for example national diplomacy just went in.Ok so assuming you are happy to run with the alpha state of the game what are you getting? Well it is what it says on the tin. 18th Century sailing ships ( plus or minus a few decades ) sailing round the carribean doing their thing. You pick a nation when you initially load up and that is locked ( you used to be able to become a pirate inside the game but im not sure if thats still the case after the last patch). The various nations have been perpetually at war taking and retaking each others ports for the last few months, unofficial alliances created by the larger of the games clans held or didnt, we'll have to see how the new diplomacy meta game changes things.The game itself is beautiful, you wont be disapointed with how it looks. My rig is pretty awesome at the moment top end and under 6 months old but my last machine was a few years old and still ran things at a good frame rate and with quality settings. The ship models are nicely crafted and you can tell the artist/s have howned their techniques over the years as the newer ones are looking decidedly nicer than the first ships that came out. This is mostly in the texture work though and I'm 100% sure upgrade work is on the backlog.Ship to Ship combat is handled on an instanced basis. You sail along in the Open World, tag your target and head into an instance to fight. I was initially quite disappointed with this approach but got used to it it. There are pro's and con's to it but it is what it is. The combat itself is the most involved and worked on part of the game, once you get your head round the initial mechanics it one of those easy to learn hard to master things. Same goes for sailing ( in the instances ). You need to use both rudder and sail direction to aid your turning through the wind.In fact everything Naval Action does it does very well. You may not like a particual direction the developers have decided to take something but they will have done a good job of it. Problem with Naval Action ( if it is indeed a problem ) is the stuff they haven't done. If you came at this game after playing something like Assassins Creed Black Flag ( like I did ) then you will be disappointed with no avatars. Theres no walking around your ships, or getting out and exploring islands, boarding is handled in a very simplistic UI manner. To be honest i can't see this sort of thing ever changing. They are too small a team and the cost implications of doing full on character art/animation/traversable enviroments are so unbelievably massive that they will never be able to do these things. It's a shame but it doesnt spoil the game they have made, it would just have made it more utterly amazing!But if you set your expectations to the right level, read around the reviews, check out the official forums. If you have an interest in the period and sailing then i think you will enjoy this game. Make sure you ask questions in the various chat channels, people are usually very helpful and willing to show new players the ropes.

number of helpful: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								While the game is still in development, and the dev team are interested in feedback from the players, their obstinate refusal to offer anything close to realism in the way of maritime navigation is the deal-breaker for me. No matter how pretty you make the sunsets, no matter how detailed the ships, no matter the accuracy of the eye-candy for the period, having to rely on landmarks for navigation is possibly the stupidest game mechanic decision they have made. They give you a compass and what amounts to a speedometer, and tell you to navigate by sight. No concession to anything realistic about sailing is made. The world map is lovely, yet worthless in regard to getting from A to B. Yes, you can see the port you just departed from, and yes, you can see the port you may be attempting to reach. You can even see the crossed sabers indicating the position of the ship(s) you are instructed to sink, etc. What you are not given, and what you will be never given (unless the dev team comes down off their high horse) is any indication of where the hell you are on that same map. I played Pirates of the Burning Sea at launch, and then again 2 yrs ago. While Naval Action is in the "simulation" category, and PotBS was not, for all of its faults, PotBS was a better game. It had character and style. NA has plenty of screenshot-worthy moments, but the ludicrous and intentional lack of navigation realism cannot but render this game to me anything beyond a mobile Geoff Hunt painting. If you want to sail a pretty ship around scanning the horizon for a landmark to fix your position, then buy the game.  I think I'll uninstall for now and come back when the game is finished. Maybe, by then, the devs will realize that their desire for players to experience being "lost at sea" because navigation tools like an octant or a sextant would make it too easy is a cop-out.I have not, and will not say anything about the lack of tutorial, etc. because it IS an Early Access game. If you have a couple of spare $20 bills lying around, buy the game. If you would rather see your money put to better use, send it to me and help me pay off my student loans.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								Naval Action is something that can be taken the wrong way or bought in vain if you are unaware of what you are getting into, so this review is to help.I myself am a huge Age of Sail fanatic, so I have long been anticipating the release of this game, I was just able to get my hands on it just before release and I must say, the game is very satisfying. As for if you will like it, that is going to be covered in the section below, as for overall what you need to keep in mind this factor, which as in most games is in NA: Grinding.Requirements to enjoy this title: Not Pros or Conds just "if you apply to these, then get it"Passion for Age of Sail or Open Mind, if you are pickey and not particularly interested, dont even try.Decent PC, the game is graphics intensive but it is worth it, it is such a beutiful game.Time, you either need to have lots of free time or be willing to accept smaller amounts of progress for less time.There are various others but those are the main headers that should be noted. As for cons, well, here are some I can name:$1600 gaming PC cant run this game much bove low settings.The gameplay becomes repetetive, but in all fairness, real life Age of Sail was even duller than this.Open world FPS is very low if PC is not powerfull enough and needs overall polishing. [Early Access, subject to change]And here are some warnings that I just thought I would throw out there, not pros or cons, just to be aware of:Though this game is not for younger kids I still would like to put it out there that there is some inapropriate content for children in the art of the vessels sternplates and bow designs.The game has some semi-official factions that you can find on the forums such as the "SLRN" which operate in unity and perform raids and defend ports, etc. for those who are a bit more committed.Anyways, that would bring my review to an end, I give this game a 8/10, and for it being an Early Access title with much more planned I give it a 10 out of 10, but that is assuming they are adding much more content as they promise such as a better UI and more ships, smoother open world, etc.[This review comes from a Age of Sail fan who has played PotBS as well as other well known titles, and rest asured, this blows them all right out of the water. And if you need a quote from all of this it is: "THIS GAME IS AWESOME"]

content:
Posted: August 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								 With over a thousand hours played I think it's fair to say I've already gotten my moneys worth from this game which is still in alpha. The graphics, combat, community and sanbox feel of the game really keep me playing. Once you get yourself into some of the larger ships and begin opening different ports the game really opens itself up and offers a lot of options to the players. Some days I run trade routes some days I attack traders running their routes some days are spent attacking enemy ports others defending our nations ports or helping an ally nation in it's goals. The battles are fun ranging from 1 on 1 to epic 25 on 25 battles. The combat has a slight learning curve it's not hard to catch on and be competent but there are a lot of little nuances that can be learned which really makes putting in the effort to learn very rewarding. Naval action is still in it's alpha phase and it shows in things like it's user interface which the developers plan to keep very basic until other parts of the game are developed. Patches come rather frequently from the Dev team with various add ons to game play, added ships, and rebalancing. Some players may be turned off by the constant tweaks but for the most part the changes coincide with the opinions of its active player base. I've played quite a few early releases and I must say it's refreshing to see developers constantly moving forward on what i see as quite an ambitious project. I highly recomend this for anyone interested in pirates and age of sail naval battles. This is the best thing going since Sid Maiers Pirates for you old school gamers.

Really if this title wants to be legendary, they'll just turn it into an open world Pirates! and call it a day. If the devs don't do that, then someone else will or Sid may dust off the Pirates! franchise and deliver what everyone wants. Till that day comes, enjoy. I will say however that the ship combat is problematic. At times it doesn't really feel like your cannons do anything. Causing magazine explosions really seems to be just random chance luck. Ammo like grape shot is very problematic and you'll often times kill more enemy crew with regular balls than grape. Chain shot does work but again, finicky. It often takes a lot of sustained chain shot fire to make any tangible dent in the sails.Frankly, I don't think the early access is worth the $40 price. You have to like this kind of gameplay or be a Pirates! fan to justify $40. The devs probably don't know they are asking too much for what is there. $20-$30 would be resonable for what is here. In the end you are buying potential. If the devs do not execute, it'll be forgotten and another dev, maybe even Sid, will come out with something that will make this look something a kid barfed up. But if they do execute, it'll be much harder on any other dev trying to churn out a similar title. This will be the benchmark.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								I love this game, I have put about 40 hours into it now and I got hooked to it the day I bought it. Naval Action is a open world ship sailing MMO simulator. It is very similar to Eve if anyone knows about it, but it isn't as overwhelming as Eve. There is several different nations you can choose from, from the major players back in the 1700s like Great Britian and Spain, to the smaller nations like Sweden, Dutch, and even the Pirates. There is trading, crafting, and conquering territory with other people in the nation that you choose. There are PVE and PVP servers, both in US and EU. The map is the entire Carribean, with the entire coast line from half way up the Eastern US, all the way down to the Northern coastline of Brazil. There are a huge amount of ports you can travel to and see what they produce and in what quantities as you plan out trade routes to make money or to craft ships, items, upgrades, etc. As you level up, you can sail bigger ships more proficiently as you are able to command more crew to sail these larger ships. Surprisingly, I have yet to see bugs besides a small graphical glitch when sailing around. One thing thing that can be a pro or a con is that traveling to different places takes time while in the open world part of the game. You can simply alt-tab or watch a video on another monitor, if you have one, to pass the time. When you are in the open world sailing around, the wind matters a lot in how you travel around, so you must plan accordingly or it will take forever to get to the place you want to go, and wind defintely matters in battles you get into. When you get into a battle, you and the other party will be put into an instance and other people from the two nations can join the battle while it is going on, but they have five minutes to do so before the battle is locked to the players or AI within the battle. In battle, you can sink other ships, board them and capture their ship, or run away if you feel the battle isn't going into your favor, but the enemy can stop you from running away if they can hit you at least once every one minute and 30 seconds.It is still far from finished and the devs seem pretty decent as they listen to the feedback the community gives. Also, they have plenty of ships being added into the game as the game moves through early access, along with UI changes and other features added to the game.I just have to say I am addicted and can't wait to play more of this game.

Early Access Review
								Having aspirations to become a naval officer and chagrined I will likely never have the chance to captain a warship under independent command (given my country's pitifully small navy), I took great interest in Naval Action. While rather pricey for a game still in an open alpha, the game itself is quite fun – with new content being added regularly.While still a game in active development with quite a few flaws and the sometimes painfully repetitious grinding for higher ranks/manpower/resources to make components to construct ships, the freedom afforded in the game is outstanding. Learning optimal angles to sail in the wind, manoeuvring to ripple off broadside after broadside at foes with great plumes of gunsmoke obscuring your vessel, your battleline - and ominously, that of the enemy. The ability to board an enemy vessel to take a grand prize for yourself and the crew. This game exudes the spirit of the Napoleonic era.More than that, nothing quite beats the exhilaration of participating in a PVP fleet action in a wee 7th rate cutter against 4th and 5th rate enemy ships.  The stark terror of the sea about your small ship awash from a 25-gun broadside of 18 pound shot, with a mere six-gun broadside of 6-pounder shot to reply with.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								In some ways acting as a successor to Pirates of the Burning sea, Naval action is a far more realistic voyage into naval combat. The game has a large focus on trade, and the major nations must struggle for control over all of the major trading ports in their attempt to acheive naval superiority. Large scale naval battles are acheived in a grand fashion, with beautifully rendered oceans, and ships. Smoke billows off of freshly fired cannons, and drifts away slowly with the breeze. Battles in Naval action require a bit of practice, and an understanding of basic seamanship will help asspiring captains greatly. The action here is slower than many games, and requires a bit of tactical positioning; it is critical that players learn to use the wind to their advantage if wishing to avoid destruction.Naval action is still in early access and has a number of issues at the moment.While the game is lovely, this graphical fidelity comes at a performance cost; further optimizations will hopefully reduce the strain on mid-range systems such as my own, but with my rig the game is perfectly playable. The UI leaves much to be desired as well, as the developers have opted to use a placeholder GUI while they work on core mechanics. This issue should easily be resolved in the coming months.CPU:i5-3750k 2.6ghz - OC 4.0ghzNvidia Geforce 660ti 16gb ddr3 ramWhile It might not be for everyone, I personally rate Naval Action at ~ 9/10.Technical issues keep me from giving it a perfect score, but I fully expect those to be resolved at a steady pace.

content:
Posted: April 4
Early Access Review
								I've been watching this game for awhile now but the tons of negative views kept me at bay... And that was stupid. This game is pretty great, as is evident by the tons of b****ing by people with 1,000-ish hours of playtime complaining which is generally a good sign that the underlying game is sound. The UI is rough around the edges, as is getting started. But once you move past that you're greated by a beautiful engine, fantastic physics with engaging and immersive gameplay. Waves will lift your cannons above the horizon making you miss shots, you won't pay attention to the wind and get your ship virtually stuck not moving, you'll have your main mast blown away by cannonfire... At the time of writing the player numbers are rather low as the devs are about to reset stats but it hasn't bothered me much. Still finding plenty to see and do and helpful players to talk, fight and interact with. A++ game, don't listen to the people ♥♥♥♥♥ing and moaning with hundreds of hours of playtime. There is a reason they keep coming back and are so mad, because the underlying game is pretty fantastic. tldr - 'real combat,' sweet physics; waves are real, cannon balls are real, rekt & get rekt. UI shi**y, rough around edges, but's it's an Alpha still. F**k da haters.

number of helpful: 9 of 18 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6
Early Access Review
								Naval Action presents one of the most unique and revolutionary attempts at melding an MMORPG with a "World of Warships" style gameplay. As someone with 600+ hours and on a hiatus since this game's Early Access Steam launch, I can truly say that this is one of the more ambitious games on the market which will unfortunately be both its strength and weakness. It goes without saying that Naval Action will be in early access for the indefinite future, with many massive features such as whether there will be an "over world" section of the game or not still on the chopping block. This and many other important "MMORPG" aspects such as trading, PvP, PvE, in my eyes are still yet to be finalized by the developers' vision, which I confirmed after observing discussions of this game's future with developers on their Naval Action forums. It is important to list this project's current faults to anyone considering purchase in the forseeable future (months or so from writing this review at the least):-Player population is dismal. Will spike when major content releases like most MMORPGs experience player traffic, however Naval Action is considerably more niche in the genre and sees maybe 1000~ players on generous days. When Naval Action releases on Steam fully, it must truly be impressive to maintain a truly enjoyable playerbase for a game of this scope.-Most population/interest is focused in the European zone. If you want a truly "massive" experience, you will learn to accept European latency. -Development is slow and often times due not just to a small dev team, but rather their circular decisions on some core aspects of the game. For instance, in the short few weeks I was active the dev team consistently patched varying versions of the "PvP tag circle" mechanic which would initiate battles. While a rather divisive issue in the community, the developers' responses/patches were usually delayed and they ultimately went back and forth on their decision to this mechanic multiple times. I wonder how much developer time was wasted on this indecisiveness, when they could have been improving other aspects of this game so desperately lacking? (PvE, Exploring, Tracking, Economy, Quests, UI, etc.) -Bare bones. The combat simulator portion of this game is enjoyable, but so far Naval Action fails to sell the idea that you are a Naval Captain in a truly massive conflict where players pull the strings. Expect dull trade runs, "fishing" by pressing a button, zero quests, and very boring PvE battles to farm up ranks to use better ships. Casual players beware.Now let's discuss the positive aspects of Naval Action:-If you're a fan of historical naval tactics, engagements, naval vessels, etc. from about 1600-1820, you will be greatly impressed at this game's attention to detail. Battles lack the "arcade" feel, while not being completely boring, especially if two players finally commit to a sea battle. Expect 30+ minutes of fighting where every shot counts, de-masts are devastating, and managing your crew/repairs both on the open sea and in battles are crucial to your career and survival. Digital ships are modelled straight from primary historical sources with amazing graphical fidelity.-Developers are active and intertwined with their community. While they are subject to criticism, apathy on the forums is not one of them. Funding does not seem to be an issue either, so do not expect development to stall purely because of money.-Scope. Macro-management. Immersion. While nowhere near its final implementation, I feel the developers' vision of nations full of players fighting/politicking/backstabbing/and monopolizing the Caribbean in a purely player-driven experience all with an 18th century flair can be fully realized. EVE Online is often used as inspiration in Naval Action's development, but it's clear the devs here are interested in striking their own path. Even lacking in its physical form, I feel this is still a pro in my eyes as so few games these days have this kind of ambition.So down to the final question: Should you buy it?My answer is: No. Until this game releases, I would not spend your money unless you're truly interested in shaping this game's future. Currently, it is still in VERY early development and ultimately boring once you've gotten your fill of the naval combat simulator Naval Action truly is at this point. Not an MMORPG. I eagerly await Naval Action's launch and to see if the developers' vision truly holds to their promises.-Carr

content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								Switching from negative to posite and back to negative... Back and forth, just like ping-pong. TL;DR Buy this game only if you are desperated for Age of Sail game with nice graphics - otherwise avoid / wait till final release.Good things that changed in last months / weeks:1. Port Battles in land2. Battlescreen changesBad things:1. Overhelming number of bugs / exploits / problems / crashes (known by Devs and planned to be fixed in the future, gamebreaking problems but yet Devs decide in meanwhile to add Pray Button that is supposedly a trolling easter egg, but no one knows, even Devs don't know. They prefer to work on some stupid new structural damage model that no one was asking them for, because the current one is simple and works perfectly. They prefer to add also fishing mechanic that does not influence gameplay in any way at all, just a decoration). If there are small / big bugs and exploits in the game for like 6-7 months or even more, they should hold the work on all big patches and fix all bugs / problems with the highest priority.2. Very little suggestions being implemented from what playerbase suggested. Even if they add something what players suggested, usually they implement it in the very day way, not how it was initially suggested / planned and if their implementation fails utterly, they blame playerbase for suggesting this. Example: Fellvred Small Battle Event, event ran everyday by a player to create nice PvP on the server, rewards, leaderboards, balanced and even battles. Devs noticed the huge interest in that (30-60 participants everyday) and decided to add something "similar". What they did is 2 zones on the map called Admiralty Event aka PvP Event. What is it? Gank fest, gank others or be ganked. Getting jumped by 10-25 ships while being solo or 5 small frigates chased by 5 SOLs (ships of the line). Either come in bigger fleet, either come in bigger ships or either runaway arround from dread fleets. Very often these events are empty or one-sided (e.g. 20+ US players in the zone and only a few enemies). 3. Hard communication with Devs, they rather say nothing if not needed, because they are scared of players using their own words against them4. Problems with changelogs, ninja-patches with no information what has been changed. Nerfs and buffs without details, because Devs prefare not to make players angry. For example they nerf a ship speed from 15 knots to 14 knots and will call it in changelog "Speed of several ships adjusted" if there will be any changelog at all...5. Lack of interest for Devs to ban all exploiters in the game. Players using alts exploiting game mechanics etc. They rather use their all effort to fight these that put negative reviews or try to say that they are doing something wrong. They report these reviews to Steam, try to make them be removed, warn players and sometimes threaten with the ban on forums or in-game. Yet they claim that they got no enough time or proof evidence to investigate obvious cases of exploiting on purpose. No one has ever been banned in this game for using exploits, that's the fact.6. Banning players that disagree or have different opinion (in-game and on forums)

Early Access Review
								This game has some of the best naval combat out there. Tactics and strategy are important in both setting up an engagement and once the battle as begun. The player base has taken a hit in recent months, associated with some questionable discussion over ship wipes and the big development picture, but overall there's nothing like this game on the market.Unfortunately the developers appear to have gone off the deep end recently, and intend on splitting the player base between time zones EU/NZ/AUS/US, unfortunately this means that our already small player base will become even smaller. With this in mind it will be very difficult to find meaningful content by way of encountering other players to both trade with, sail with or setup RvR battles that need 50 people.I'm going to switch my recommendation to no, until they devs can show that they can turn it around.

Large scale naval battles are acheived in a grand fashion, with beautifully rendered oceans, and ships. Smoke billows off of freshly fired cannons, and drifts away slowly with the breeze. Battles in Naval action require a bit of practice, and an understanding of basic seamanship will help asspiring captains greatly. The action here is slower than many games, and requires a bit of tactical positioning; it is critical that players learn to use the wind to their advantage if wishing to avoid destruction.Naval action is still in early access and has a number of issues at the moment.While the game is lovely, this graphical fidelity comes at a performance cost; further optimizations will hopefully reduce the strain on mid-range systems such as my own, but with my rig the game is perfectly playable. The UI leaves much to be desired as well, as the developers have opted to use a placeholder GUI while they work on core mechanics. This issue should easily be resolved in the coming months.CPU:i5-3750k 2.6ghz - OC 4.0ghzNvidia Geforce 660ti 16gb ddr3 ramWhile It might not be for everyone, I personally rate Naval Action at ~ 9/10.Technical issues keep me from giving it a perfect score, but I fully expect those to be resolved at a steady pace.

number of helpful: 9 of 18 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6
Early Access Review
								Naval Action presents one of the most unique and revolutionary attempts at melding an MMORPG with a "World of Warships" style gameplay. As someone with 600+ hours and on a hiatus since this game's Early Access Steam launch, I can truly say that this is one of the more ambitious games on the market which will unfortunately be both its strength and weakness. It goes without saying that Naval Action will be in early access for the indefinite future, with many massive features such as whether there will be an "over world" section of the game or not still on the chopping block. This and many other important "MMORPG" aspects such as trading, PvP, PvE, in my eyes are still yet to be finalized by the developers' vision, which I confirmed after observing discussions of this game's future with developers on their Naval Action forums. It is important to list this project's current faults to anyone considering purchase in the forseeable future (months or so from writing this review at the least):-Player population is dismal. Will spike when major content releases like most MMORPGs experience player traffic, however Naval Action is considerably more niche in the genre and sees maybe 1000~ players on generous days. When Naval Action releases on Steam fully, it must truly be impressive to maintain a truly enjoyable playerbase for a game of this scope.-Most population/interest is focused in the European zone. If you want a truly "massive" experience, you will learn to accept European latency. -Development is slow and often times due not just to a small dev team, but rather their circular decisions on some core aspects of the game. For instance, in the short few weeks I was active the dev team consistently patched varying versions of the "PvP tag circle" mechanic which would initiate battles. While a rather divisive issue in the community, the developers' responses/patches were usually delayed and they ultimately went back and forth on their decision to this mechanic multiple times. I wonder how much developer time was wasted on this indecisiveness, when they could have been improving other aspects of this game so desperately lacking? (PvE, Exploring, Tracking, Economy, Quests, UI, etc.) -Bare bones. The combat simulator portion of this game is enjoyable, but so far Naval Action fails to sell the idea that you are a Naval Captain in a truly massive conflict where players pull the strings. Expect dull trade runs, "fishing" by pressing a button, zero quests, and very boring PvE battles to farm up ranks to use better ships. Casual players beware.Now let's discuss the positive aspects of Naval Action:-If you're a fan of historical naval tactics, engagements, naval vessels, etc. from about 1600-1820, you will be greatly impressed at this game's attention to detail. Battles lack the "arcade" feel, while not being completely boring, especially if two players finally commit to a sea battle. Expect 30+ minutes of fighting where every shot counts, de-masts are devastating, and managing your crew/repairs both on the open sea and in battles are crucial to your career and survival. Digital ships are modelled straight from primary historical sources with amazing graphical fidelity.-Developers are active and intertwined with their community. While they are subject to criticism, apathy on the forums is not one of them. Funding does not seem to be an issue either, so do not expect development to stall purely because of money.-Scope. Macro-management. Immersion. While nowhere near its final implementation, I feel the developers' vision of nations full of players fighting/politicking/backstabbing/and monopolizing the Caribbean in a purely player-driven experience all with an 18th century flair can be fully realized. EVE Online is often used as inspiration in Naval Action's development, but it's clear the devs here are interested in striking their own path. Even lacking in its physical form, I feel this is still a pro in my eyes as so few games these days have this kind of ambition.So down to the final question: Should you buy it?My answer is: No. Until this game releases, I would not spend your money unless you're truly interested in shaping this game's future. Currently, it is still in VERY early development and ultimately boring once you've gotten your fill of the naval combat simulator Naval Action truly is at this point. Not an MMORPG. I eagerly await Naval Action's launch and to see if the developers' vision truly holds to their promises.-Carr

content:
Posted: April 4
Early Access Review
								I've been watching this game for awhile now but the tons of negative views kept me at bay... And that was stupid. This game is pretty great, as is evident by the tons of b****ing by people with 1,000-ish hours of playtime complaining which is generally a good sign that the underlying game is sound. The UI is rough around the edges, as is getting started. But once you move past that you're greated by a beautiful engine, fantastic physics with engaging and immersive gameplay. Waves will lift your cannons above the horizon making you miss shots, you won't pay attention to the wind and get your ship virtually stuck not moving, you'll have your main mast blown away by cannonfire... At the time of writing the player numbers are rather low as the devs are about to reset stats but it hasn't bothered me much. Still finding plenty to see and do and helpful players to talk, fight and interact with. A++ game, don't listen to the people ♥♥♥♥♥ing and moaning with hundreds of hours of playtime. There is a reason they keep coming back and are so mad, because the underlying game is pretty fantastic. tldr - 'real combat,' sweet physics; waves are real, cannon balls are real, rekt & get rekt. UI shi**y, rough around edges, but's it's an Alpha still. F**k da haters.

Early Access Review
								Sandbox. Set your own objectives. Develop your playstyle. Be a pyrate, be a successful trader, design ships, engage in pvp in the open seas, or fight atop a ship of the line in epic massive battles. Simply go sailing about, at your own rhythm and enjoy all the possibilities. Naval Action in a nutshell.----------------Game is in constant development. The Game Labs crew uses a open model in which testers ( that's us ! ) discuss mechanics back and forth, present ideas and see them implemented. The Devs do take all the seemingly solid ideas and promote them into the game - sometimes they work, others not so much - but we have the chance to see our own community discussions turned into a game mechanic - Cool huh !?

content:
Posted: March 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								The deck pitches, the waves rock your ship, the cannons must be timed. No magic buttons to replace lost crew, no magic loads, no magic turns or repairs. You have to learn how to sail your ships, handle your sails, you have to learn how to aim and when to fire your cannons. The best game I have ever played when it comes to realism in this era. Its great fun and it will only get better.However, at this point the developers seem more interested in buffing the current content then adding the new. The battle part of the game is fully fleshed out and yet every patch they add .5% more cannon smoke or .02% sail fluff, while crafting is untouched and national strategy languishes. The game has not progressed much further then when I purchased it (4 months ago.) Open world sailing is a huge grind and a monstrous time sink without payoff. You can literally spend an hour getting where you want to go and see nothing except the rear of your ship for the duration.I love this era and was so excited that this game came out. I love the concept and the battles are its real strength, but I cannot recommend it at this point.

Early Access Review
								I'll list the pros first, as I think that's fair. They are what drew me to the game originally. I will update the review if and when my opinion changes. And yeah, these things are my opinion.***Pros:1. First I will say the game has an amazing feel when you are in combat, at least in PVP. There are some things they haven't fleshed out fully, but it's still pretty interesting and the damage modeling is realistic.2. There aren't many games like this, in this genre. It has a lot of potential.3. A great alternative to a white-noise machine. Just load up resources on your trade ship, set sail on that hours-long voyage across the open blue. The sound of the wind and the rushing of your bow wave will have you nodding off in record time.***Top three cons I listed to the devs on the forum:1. Point ship in desired direction and move something in game to keep it from timing out, fight cheating AI for whatever reason, repeat, repeat repeat repeatrepeatrepeat2. Seriously after a year or so, you have done nothing but little tweaks to simple coding items. Nothing has really changed or improved with this game since OW was released.3. Basically 1 and 2... I suspect the devs are just playing a bait and switch game with "content" in patches. It's pretty bad when players are putting out more content (as in the ships by Ragnar) than the devs have. Might as well open the game to the players to mod... we'd have a decent game by now... with a UI that doesn't look like a half ♥♥♥♥♥ middle school computer concepts project.I already paid, so I'll probably keep watching this game, but I'm not holding my breath.***CONCLUSION: They haven't changed much about the game, and they don't seem to be really working on it. It's one of those early access games that leads people in with some juicy nugget and then keeps leading them on. It's the worst kind of tease.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								Naval Action is an odd creature.I've played this game for almost 250 hours and in that time I've enjoyed myself immensly, but I've also encountered many issues.The developpers spend a lot of time on balancing ships. They obviously make a bunch of mistakes or balance it the wrong way, but that's normal and in the end it always gets rectified. I've not done that much PvP but from what I've seen so far it's looking a lot better than at launch. The biggest issue here is that there's no reason to use the smaller vessels in this game. Once you unlock a larger ship, you ditch the old one. They tried rectifying this by making most port battles limited to the smaller vessels, but in the end people still play the largest ship they can when they can. It's not an easy thing to solve mind you.The graphical team have done an excellent job on the ship design. Most of the ships look very good, there's no way to argue against that. But that's where it kinda ends, which is my first issue.Other than very detailed ships there's not much else. One of the largest playerdriven events in this game hasn't been properly updated for months. When you go into a portbattle you're still fighting a couple of random towers in the middle of the ocean, and whilst an update to this was promised many months ago, we've yet to actually see any chance to that.I remember the concept art being shown for actual forts and the like, but ever since then, nothing. If you bring it up on their forums they usually don't reply to it.The cities you go to when you need to go to port are pretty much all the same and are largely a result of copy pasting. Which wouldn't be that bad if it wasn't the only thing other than ships that could make the game look and feel authentic.Another glaring issue is the user interface. It's♥♥♥♥♥♥ It's harsh but that's pretty much the essence of it. It looks really bad and is never once explained ingame. New players who buy this game, log in to the game and see the user interface are instantly turned off and who can blame them. My real question here is, why the hell has there been no attempt to even upgrade the interface. The usual response from devs and other players is: "They're going to do that on release". To me it's a bit of a cop out and in a game that is hemoraging players and has difficulty with player retention, small things like this are very helpful. First impressions are key, especially since you can now refund the game within the first two hours.There are other smaller issues, like the whole officer thing. They add in perks that are helpful in combat. Perks that are helpful in crafting. Perks that are helpful as a trader. Yet they only allow you to recruit and train one officer whilst it's clearly intended to allow you to have multiple officers. Why this is the case? Nobody knows.However, the thing that is the most baffling of all, is the devs reaction to critisicm and the apparent willingness to buy positive reviews from their players by promising new content if a certain amount of reviews is reached. This is why you should most certainly take any positive reviews for this game with a grain of salt. And whilst yes, you never said the reviews had to be positive, saying that: "Positive reviews will make us work harder" makes it obvious you meant give us positive reviews.Recently they posted a reaction to a negative review. The most striking thing that was said, was that the responses of the admins on their official forums were not always representative of company policy. But if someone with the tag 'admin' says on your forums that a feature is getting pulled because of critisicm, then it's YOUR job to make sure that employee doesn't post stupid things like that. It's always easy to, after the backlash, come out and say that he/she didn't speak for you, but the damage at that point is already done, and from my experience dealing with the devs of this game, it isn't that much of a stretch to believe the devs capable of pulling a feature because they got some critisicm.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								Originally, I gave this game a huge thumbs up and highly recommended it to all who would listen. What was an amazing game with a lot of potential is turning into a lame duck. Combat is taking a serious turn for the worse as they are trying to move toward a more 'historic' approach to naval battle which seriously reduces the amount of damage done to enemies. No longer can you do damage at 200 meters or further from ships. Group pvp is now more of solo-within-group pvp as you can only have so many people within 200 yards of enemy ships with an angle to penetrate. Battles which were once exciting and skill-based are turning into hours-long snoozefests where you literally have to be almost on top of another ship to damage them. While they may tweak this to (I'm sure they will?) reflect the desire of the player base as a whole, it is indicative of the attitude of the developers. It is obvious that they are making the game that they want to make, regardless of the appeal to the larger gaming community in general or in regard to the opinion of those who they allowed to PAY to test and give feedback. Boarding combat is extremely uninteresting and detracts from the game. It is basically a PC version of rock/paper/scissors. All the suspense of childrens game with the graphics to match. The ship cannon combat graphics are awesome, but the boarding graphics don't even have crew representations, it is literally a text screen/overlay that pops up and reports the results of the 'hidden' boarding battle.  Some ships have a numerical crew (listed in your HUD) of up to 1200+, but when you board it shows an empty deck while the battle 'rages' in text.Since the steam release the in-port UI screen has literally been a blue screen with absolutely no graphics. It is about as close to a MUDD based game as you can get and has been that way for the last 3 1/2 months. Instead of taking the time to remedy such an obvious blemish to the game that they are charging $40 for, they are more interested in breaking things that are already working well, such as the combat system.Finally, the game is a serious time sink that doesn't allow you to just log on for 30 or 45 minutes and accomplish something. You literally need to commit to 2 or 3 hours to really have an opportunity to enjoy yourself. Out of those 2 or 3 hours half of that time will be you sailing around waiting for the fun to happen. Speaking of mind-numbing, the time it takes to sail in between ports is fantastically slow. I have watched butter melt that was more interesting. For someone with ADD/ADHD, this game could possibly be used as a torture device. Handcuff them to a computer desk and make them 'explore' in a 'historical' sense. The developers are choosing to ignore testers (who paid to help test their game) for voicing opinions in an attempt (most of the time) to help shape this game. Well, I was a believer and advocate for this game, not so anymore. They seem to only want to listen to those individuals who give them the answers they are looking for, essentially the 'yes men.'

There are no grafics in control scenes when i habour.Things who helps create the mood of the time, and the game. Personal advatars is not present. Customizing your ship and sails, not present. For the pice i atleast expected a few of these things.The game itself in an open world is a slow grinding thing, it takes ages to get XP and climp in rank to be able to command bigger ships . ..  I mean ages and in the long run it will be boring considering you might loose your hard earned ship in a sec ! Making money is a bit more easy but still requires a load of missions or trading.If your a hardcore 18 century naval fan then you will like it, if not you will be bored in the long run of the games current state.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								11/10For a game thats still in Alpha its superb.  Has very playable content with VERY few bugs.  Its immersing and fun, but most importantly its CHALLENGING!  Some people argue that its empty in terms of content and a 'grindy' game which is true  (hello?  Still in alpha!) but personally I don't mind the grind at all as every battle there is a good chance you will sink if fighting a bigger ship or even 2v1!  You can group up with friends or randoms and battle against large AI fleets that cruise the waters and have epic scale fights, or have a chill and do some trading and crafting.Not for the type of gamers who want to blow everything up and own at battles within 15 mins.  Takes a long time to master the mechanics or sailing and aiming effectively and each time you advance in rank and get a new ship you have to re-adjust your skills to fit the new speed/turn/gun placements.  The detail they have put into combat is fantastic, and you have to pay attention to a lot of factors to stay ahead of the enemy to win.  and for such an early game combat looks fab!If you liked cids pirates and such you'll love this game!

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								Fans of economic PVP games or Caribbean pirates alike will both get their kicks in this game.  Bear in mind it is still in early access, but if you're a fan of EVE Online or Pirates of the Burning Sea, you should get excited about the potential.  The combat simulation is deep enough to keep you coming back for more, with PVP being about more than mashing skills but also, positioning relative to target and wind, and proper target ranging.  Economic elements of the game include building and stocking your storehouse with resources to build your fleet, with the higher tiered ships being guild-wide undertakings that must be protected at risk of losing days/weeks of hard work if it is destroyed, (yes ships can be perma-destroyed).  Starting price tag may seem steep for an EA game i'll agree, but if you're the niche player of the target audience, its money well spent for a good time.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								Hello! I am a guy that is fan of the age of sail and bought this game today. I think many people like pro/cons lists so here:PRO'S:- Realistic combat- Beautiful designed ships- Good trade system- Can play with friends- Huge ship battles - Many upgrades- Open worldCON'S- Traveling is to long and boring- When traveling in open waters, you encounter almost no ships- Ugly town UI(just blue screen with options)- No crew visible when traveling(minor con)- Boarding in combat is a blue screen with crew members decreasing instead of seeing your crew members fight- Crew members will do the gun load animation the whole battle wich takes away realism- No single difference between factions except for different starting place- Little ship viarity- Low amount of servers- Before entering combat, you get a loading screen(takes away the open world a bit)- Pogression is slow- When you start out, you feel uneeded and weak- Not much team communication within battles- The almost triple A asking price(EDIT, extra con)- No tutorial for new players to get them started.Well, i know this is early acces so i hope it will become worth its asking price at one point but right now its just thievery. I think the price for a MMO like this should be max $20. I think the asking price turns many people away and leaves the world even more empty. There are to little features and there is few things to do. It gives almost no sandbox feel and you only see its an MMO if you come close to city's wich are usually full of new players(wich is also the reason why there is almost no ship viarity being that every new player starts out with the same ship!).I have my refund requested. I tried to get into it but i can't. I if you were looking for a open world sandbox game set in the age of sail, buy sid meiers pirates. great game and 3,7 times cheaper.Sorry but i am not putting 100+ hours in a game that doesn't spark 1 single thought of enjoyment.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								First and foremost, this game has so very much potential and is excitingly unique.  I feel terrible not recommending it.  For me though, it was totally let down by the almost incomprehensible (and startling ugly) menu screens.  It seems like so much work has gone into the rest of this game, and the menu screens have been added almost as an afterthought.  I have requested a refund, as none of the screenshots show these, and I don't feel they are representative of the game as it stands, and people should be made aware of this before being expected to part with the price of a far more developed game.  (I question whether one can call themselves indie, and charge the same as many of the large developers.)  That said, I have to emphasise that I love where the developers are going with this, and I will definitely be buying another copy if/when the menu system becomes a bit more comprehensible.  And perhaps add even the smallest tutorial?

content:
Posted: October 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								Dear Players, interested players,I've read a lot bad reviews here which I mostly can not understand. Those reviews were written rashly and mostly without knowing the available given informations which those players actualy should know. Please ignore them!Thus I kinda feel forced to give my feedback of the game:But before a little warning: This game is not a game for players which want to achieve something easy! It is not for landlubbers but for captains.Personal:I've started to play the game active at febuary and know I've played the game around 700h. I loved every single hour I spend on this game - Sure sometimes it wasnt the best way the game evolved but overall I wouldnt want to miss it and would also do this again if I had to.Now to the feedback: As every player should know, early acces games are not fully developed as a normal game. This game still is not released, hence we get new stuff almost monthly if possible. That also means, that sometimes the game itselfes changes (E.g: The trading system constandly evolves). So of course, it could happen that you might missjudge the market (and loose some gold ingame) or that you can win a lot through speculation. Trading belongs a open world game like crafting should. (Ayou need better ships? Than you have to build them!)But this game is not mainly a trading game, it is an open world sail-battle game with wonderful and detailed coastlines and ships. You have to pay attention to the wind direction and a lot other stuffs. This game wants to present you the most detail and most wonderful playing experience within the 18th century on sailing ships. Thus it is pretty hard to understand especially cause there is no real "tutorial" to get the basics, still it is worth it and hell yeah, it makes a lot of fun!Hope I see ya on the seas captains! Faithfully yours,Twig

number of helpful: 8 of 17 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 22
Early Access Review
								The developers have created a graphically beautiful world with complex combat mechanics that approach realistic big ship sailing and age of sail battle better than any I have seen. The potential is there for a rich player experience. However, one should realize before purchasing at this Early Access stage that it is currently more potential than reality. Don’t get me wrong: you can have a lot of fun playing Naval Action when in battle. However, most of the peaceful activities such as trading and crafting can be more of a drudgery than a joy. That could change though. THIS IS AN EARLY ACCESS GAME. That means that mechanics, rules, and even some basic paradigms of the game are changing. Many players don’t think they are changing fast enough. Others hate the changes and want things left as they were.One of the biggest impediments right now is just low player population. As Naval Action gets closer to release or after release, hopefully the population will get higher. Many problems with the game are a direct result of not enough players around the world to make PVP action readily available, to fill player battles, and to truly test a player run economy.If you’re the type of player who wants instant shooting action, this game will probably never be for you. If you are primarily interested in PVE play, it may never be for you as well since the developer’s stated priority is PVP play. While PVE is available right now, it is unclear how much development time it will get in the future to make it a richer experience. If you are the type of person that after dedicating time in a game which is in testing and development you’ll get all huffy when things change or when a wipe is necessary, you should probably wait until release. We’re testing here. However, if you are interested in this period of history and want to literally experience the fun and pain of a New World, you should give Naval Action a try.
