number of helpful: 8 of 17 people (47%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								Awesome game! I will expand this review weekly in the comments below: Day one: The world is massive, truly massive. Sailing is fairly easy if you understand the mechanics of tacking. If not, it's easy to get the hang of it. You start out with zero gold, but it's not a problem. You can gain gold easy by doing missions where you go out and fight pirates. Once you accept a mission, you look at your map and a crossed sword appears somewhere at sea close to the port you accepted the mission from. Exit the port and use your compass to get a general bearing, because you can get lost if it's out of sight of land. The fights are not click fests, so fast twitch COD type players may get bored. Strategic players will LOVE it! You have to use the wind to your advantage, change your cannon shot according to your plans which change constantly due to the ebb and flow of battle. I like to use chain to damage the enemy's sails at first from a distance while avoiding his broadsides if possible, then I maneuver behind his stern and use ball shot to damage his stern. Once his stern is damaged, I switch to grape shot and take out his crew. It's not just point and click however. When you use grape shot you need to time the waves so the boat is leaning towards you and you can actually see the crew for better results. It can actually make the difference between killing 2 crew members or 12! You can also try to demast or reduce his sails to where his speed is very low and then board the ship. If successful, you get to keep the ship and everything in the hold!!! Battles are not fast. Sometimes it takes over an hour for me to kill a pirate. I'm told that as you get better it gets quicker, but it's still a lot of fun and quite realistic even for a rookie like me and I usually stink at killing anything in PVP or even PVE type situations.  Awesomeness!!!     Getting on to other aspects of my first weekend. Travel and exploration is quite realistic. There is no gps and your position is not marked on the map. At first I hated this, but now I love it. It's realistic. The ocean is vast. You can get lost easy. At first I just sailed in the general direction of an island with a port I wanted to locate to see what trading goods they needed. Big mistake. The island was quite far and I got lost. I spent two real life hours in open sea with no sight of land anywhere. I finally ran into a small island which was well of course of where I thought I was headed. Since then, I've found that the best way to travel and not get lost is to open up your map, pick the location you want, and zoom in. You can then see the coordinates. Start your journey in the general direction using your compass and check your coordinates on the map occasionally, adjusting your direction based on your current coordinates. It's very simple. If the first number on your coordinate target is say 75:00 N  15:10 W and you're at 78:00 N  17:00 W, go in the direction that makes the first number go lower, then adjust your steering to the left or right to make the second number go lower. Keep adjusting untill the numbers match and you'll find your destination. You'll actually see it before the numbers match especially if you use your spyglass by using the "Shift" key. I haven't gotten lost since I started using this method.     The world map encompasses the entire Gulf of Mexico, the eastern seaboard of the United states, South America, and the Bahamas, Cuba, etc. It'a absolutely huge and would take hours and hours to get from one end to another. Ports are controlled by various countries, each with certain advantages. I chose England because there were a lot of players choosing that country due to it's rich naval history. You can take ports from other countries, but I haven't tried that yet.     As you discover ports, it reveals what they produce and what they consume as far as resources like Oak, Iron, tea, hemp, etc. If you like to trade, you can open trade routes. Buy stuff cheap at one port and sell it higher at another. I just started trying this and it seems like a lot of fun, but the market is very competitive.      Crafting seems awesome as well. You can actually craft your own ships!!! And best of all, they can vary in terms of quality so you and your friend may craft the same boat but one might be significantly better than the other! The only drawback to crafting that I see so far is that it uses something called labor hours and you're limited to so many a day. You can also add outposts in ports you like and then construct buildings like silver mines, oak forests, etc and harvest your own resources, but these too use up labor hours. So unlimited crafting is not an option although I believe that perhaps you can purchase labor hours form other players. I'm not sure on this because I haven't crafted much yet, but i see people shouting out they have it for sale. It still looks like crafting will be a blast on a limited basis of course.       You can also fish, and actually catch fish while you're traveling, but the market for most of the fish is not very profitable. One exception is Bull Sharks. They go for 5000 to 10000 gold and I caught three on my first day. Species of fish vary according to your location. I caught the Bull sharks as I sailed closer to the Florida coast.        You can upgrade your ships and buy new ones and there are a lot to choose from. You must rank up to get better ships. I've ranked up once already, but I haven't purchased a new ship yet because I liike my cutter and I'm not sure which ship I want to buy yet.You can also build a fleet of ships which makes fighting much easier at the cost of lower experience gain.      There are guilds you can join so you can declare war on other nations. I haven't joined one yet, because I'm still trying to learn the game and there is a lot to learn. There is a chat function with a few channels like nation, global, help, etc. You can friend people in game.      The game is early access, but gets regualar updates. The potential here is amazing. The sea is beautiful to sail upon. There are weather effects. I'm hoping they incorporate hurricanes! There is no tutorial yet, so I use Youtube and google to learn stuff and the help chat in game. I've played a lot this first weekend and even though I still don;t know what I'm doing in many aspects, I love it.      One of my favorite moments was when I was lost at sea for two hours. I had not seen a single ship or even a hint of land as I traveled fishing along the way. I kept catching new species of fish. Suddenly, in the distance I saw a large ship. My heart started pounding as I clicked on him to see his nationality. He was English like me! It was an amazing feeling. I felt as if I had truly been lost and not just in a game. I realized that unless he was lost like me, he had to be coming from somewhere, so I followed his course backwards while he disappeared im my wake. Eventually I came upon a small English port on an island. I could easily have clicked on him and chatted asking him where the nearest land was since I had not learned to use my map yet, but I wanted to do it on my own and eventually I succeeded. This is one of the things that make this game pure Awesomeness for me. Not knowing if an enemy might be lying in wait for you over the horizon. Coming up on an unknown port in the dark and barely being able to see the lights of a few buildings in your spyglass, but realizing that at least it's land. The sense of relief when you see that it belongs to your home country or an ally....the dread when you see that it belongs to an enemy and you change course before someone sees you . You set your sails to take advantage of the most favorable wind and escape sailing out into the unknown....Day 2: Today I started crafting parts for a ship I'm going to build. In order to build a ship you must make an outpost at a port, then build a shipyard. The shipyard is expensive...50,000 gold

content:
Posted: March 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is no longer worth the time or money it costs to play it, in fact, it is overpriced garbage. It is advertised as an MMO with many different features to keep you interested, and at this point I dare say it is falsely advertised. In the early days of EA resources were scarce and crafting was a challenge. You had to compete with other players for limited resources and not everyone could craft a ship every day. This also gave incentives for your nation to expand and take the ports of others in order to give your nation access to more resources. I enjoyed the competition and enjoyed nice ships being a rarity. The developers have since catered to care bears who only want an easy mode game, and as a result there isn’t really anything left to do. Resources are now in infinite supply. There is no point to capturing the ports of other nations for their resources. You will find everything you will ever need in an infinite supply in the ports right next to your capital. The developers plan on wiping many aspects of player accounts due to the influx of cheaters. They have said they will soft wipe the servers, which means players will lose all of their gold, ships, and resources. They do not plan on wiping XP or crafting level. This won’t slow down a cheater who by definition isn’t playing by the rules; instead it will punish the average player. Sounds fun doesn’t it?The one thing this game does decently is the combat. There is some fun to be had in pvp. This alone may keep you interested for a couple of days but it too will become monotonous and boring quite fast. When I started playing there were enough players to be spread around 2 to 3 different servers. At the time of this review there is only enough players left to fill half of one server, and it's easy to see why players are leaving this game in droves. I give this game a 3/10 and would say its worth about $10.00.

number of helpful: 7 of 15 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								I'd like to start by saying this is a niche game and still in development. if you are looking for an assassin's creed pirate gameplay experience then... walk away. If you are looking for more realism and tactics with a mmo aspect to the game then you might have a winner!Naval battles: let's start with that as it is focused on the golden age of sails 17/18th centuries. they are awesome...You have access to many ships as you level up in the game. Some are fast and manoeuvrable other strong with great fire power. Each ship has a purpose (hunter/scout/ fire power platform etc.) They all have advantages and drawbacks, it is up to you to focus on the good aspect and play accordingly to get the most of your ship! Playing with others in different ships will allow you to build tactics to win an engament.PvP can be very intense but beware of ganking not so fun^^ so open your eyes while sailing in open world.The graphics are nice and the ambient sound during battle are immersive.Crafting and trading are available. i'm not going to lie.. it's a long process and it takes time. But if you are into that it works well. To sum up, you need ressources to build ship parts that will ultimatly be used to build your ship. Ressources can be bought or produce in ports and every ports produces specific ressources. So you will have to sail a lot to gather the much needed ressources to craft. If you can't craft well trade for what you need by sending contacts in ports.The open world: it's huuuge! it encompass the south of the USA, the mexican gulf, cental america and the north of bresil (and all islands in between). sailing to one point to the far opposite point of the map will take hours!! fortunatly you can open ports docks to fast "warp" your captain from one area to another (without the ship). Each area is controlled by a kingdom you can choose from when starting the game (GB, USA, Spain, France, Deutch, Sweden, Danemark and the Pirates)Kingdom vs Kingdom: As said earlier on, the game has a mmo part in it. it is represented by nation fighting each other over control of ports.  Going to war (or allying) is acheived by a round of vote inside the nation. Once the votes are closed well, you know who is going to fight you. To capture an area, you need to flip the targetted area by increasing the hostility level in this area. This can be acheived by PvP and  PvE mission. Once the region is "flipped" a porty battle is open (46hours after the flip). This is the occasion to have a 25v25 players fight! (very intense). Nations will organise to attack or defend. This can bring epic battles.Capturing an area has a strategic value as ports produce ressources needed for the craft of your ship. It also gives different bonuses to your ship.Regarding the UI, it is indeed a basic Unity menu but it doesnot hurt the game mechanics nor the pleasure of sailing. Moreover it is the last step you take in game development. Why spending hours of work in a UI you will have to change constantly as the game evole (The UI will be released  before launch. and that the intelligent thing to do).,As a beginner,  you might get a bit lost starting as there is no guide provided. But a quick google search will give you access to many player's guide and "how to" explaining the basics.Regarding the play time needed to evolve (carft / make money etc..) well this game has a MMO aspect to it so yeah it takes time. This is why the game is best played within the comfort of a clan/guild or with friends. As you can centralise and put your effort together to gather ressources and craft ship. Crafting in this game imply that you organize yourself with other to reach your goal. if you can't produce a ressource, trade for it, find people providing the goods, many people do that. Making money is very easy and can be obtain by doing mission or trading goods between port. Furthermore it is always fun to hunt enemies with group of swashbuckling lads!To suml up: It is a slow pace game, beautifully designed (very stable for a beta) The game is still in devlopment and the devs are making changes and are tweaking it but imo they are going into the right direction.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								Pros:- Very in-depth combat system with detailed damage model and sailing behavior- Beautiful graphics- huge open world map of the carribbean- Weather effects- Active and smart devs. Can't overstate this. Very thoughtful and consistent approach to the development process. Mechanics and content changes are quite frequent and are published in advance. Feels much more positive and responsive than POTBS dev team years backCons:- RvR, ROE, economy need more depth. Basic system works but feels like a placeholder until some focused development in that area happens- textbox UI doesn't help with immersion- definitely not a ready product. expect changes, wipes and other frustrations- expensiveOverall if you're a mature, patient gamer, tall ship fan, ready to see the game grow with you - a must have. No better naval game on the market.If you're hardcore player, competitive, looking to win at all costs - don't buy. There are cheaper titles that reward this play style better. And the game mechanics feel a little shaky and probably not too hard to exploit at the moment.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game will grab your attention and not let go!Yes, it is "just" early access. Yes, a lot of work still needs to be done. When you first log in, the menus might put you off a little. They are functional, but ugly. Once you set sail however..... wow. Just wow. The ships, oceans and shorelines look stunning. Some days you sail on a calm sea under a hot bright sun, other days you will find yourself in a wicked storm that limits your visibility and slows you down. Rain and thunder roll over you and your ship heaves over the waves.Combat is amazing as well. It takes skill to maneuver your ships around, especially in the massive port battles! Those usually start out with the two opposing sides forming tactical lines, but halfway through the battle you will find yourself amongst a boiling mass of angry cannons, thick smoke and breaking masts. Ever seen one of those old paintings depicting an age-of-sail naval battle? It's like that. Exactly like that.Also; the community is great. (And please; if you decide to buy this game, keep it like that!) The game is not for the faint of heart. You have to navigate around the map yourself (no TomTom in this game), and because there's no manual or other documentation yet it can be hard at first to understand everything. That's part of an Early Access release. But the community is there to help and it does a splendid job. Never before have I been brought up to speed in a game so quickly with the (freely offered) help of others!And last but not least; the dev-team is great. They keep the players up-to-date through the forums on a very regular basis. They say what they're going to do and they do what they say. Player suggestions, complaints and requests are answered and taken into development whenever possible. Amazing work for such a (relatively) small team of developers.If you love movies like "Master and Commander", enjoy the ship-battles in "Pirates of the Caribbean" or enjoy watching age-of-sail documentaries about battles like Trafalgar, Chatham or the lives pirates really lived in the 17-1800's, then this is the game for you. Remember; it's early access. Not everything is completed and you'll have to climb a bit of a learning curve, but it is well worth it!

								Naval Action is a beautiful naval combat game with a lot of potential.It's still in EA at the time I'm posting this review, but It's already a very strong game.The graphics are amazing, so make sure to have some proper hardware if you wish to max out the settings in this game.(i5 and GTX 960 / 970 should be enough for 1080p)Currently the player base is very small, due to slow paced development.Having a team / clan is key in this game. content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								If you have ever wanted to feel like the captain of an Age of Sail ship this game is your chance.You can command any vessel starting from small cutters and yachts up to huge Ships of the Line. You can trade, sail the seas, fight enemy ships and conquer enemy towns for the benefit of you nation and your own.Here is a short list of my most favorite features of the game: - Extremely realistic sail mechanics. - A map on which you have to find out yourself where you are (no GPS). - Beautyful sea, weather and world. Just sail and admire the sunsets. - Advanced damage model with leaks, demasting, fires and explosions. - Trading goods between towns and crafting ships. - Huge naval battles with up to 25 versus 25 players in beautyful ships.If you do remember Pirates and liked it, this is the perfect game for you.If you want to see some more you can stop by at www.twitch.tv/PlakRocks or www.youtube.com/c/PlakRocks to watch some move videos of this great game.

								Amazing game all around. I will be sailing around in the open world and just look around me and I see the beautiful scenery that the devs have put so much work into. I go into a battle and I truly feel like the captain of a ship, just as I did in my youth. I sail about, seeking adventure, wealth, and most of all, filthy pirates.From a technical standpoint, the game is indeed an alpha, but it's quite well polished, and bugs are rare. The developers are amazing from all that I have seen, and are very receptive to the community's thoughts. There are features that need tweaking and some that have yet to be added, but I am confident in gamelabs. The loading screen quotes are also very witty and fun, just to mention that.Overall, if you have any interest in the age of sail and becoming a captain, this game is certainly for you.

								Greetings,I have been gaming for quite some time, since early nineties, and I have to admit that this game surprised me a lot in a very possitive way. This game is a true masterpiece and for me it is among the best games which were ever created. It's just awesome. I admire attention to details the most, for it's more or less a simulator of age of sail warfare. I like the community on PvP EU which is great, some hardcore, some casual, all sorts of players.Though the anti dev people have some valid points, please remember that the game is still in development. I don't focus on the fraction of the work which is still tuned, but instead I appreciate the 99 percent of the work which was done right by the devs. They do a tremendous job on the title. Thumbs up for courage to program such non-mainstream title. If you like age of sail just go get it.

								This game could definitely use some quality of life enhancmenets, especially when it comes to navigation. I know it's a sim, but it should also be fun. Right now it's fun for only the extremely niche hardcore and nobody else. This is why the game is getting negative reviews, people expect an enjoyable experience and this tips over toward being a bit too hardcore and a little too time consuming to do stuff in. I kinda like the game just for sitting around and sailing and stuff but I have to say the game overall is just not very fun as it is right now. And I mean, I played EvE for years, so PVP is something I enjoy, and I don't mind getting my ships wrecked. So that def isn't my issue. The game just isnt very playable to the average gamer who wants to have fun.That being said, this game has TONS of potential, and is only in Alpha, there is plenty of time to improve the game and make it more accessible. Right now the game is "playable" but I wouldn't recommend it in this state.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								A beautiful sailing game, based on the unity engine.I've played this game in the closed early access for some time now, and it's finally out on Steam. What you can expect from this game? A realistic sailing simulator, with pretty ships during the age of sail, tons of fun playing multiplayer. It's really exciting to be in a big naval battle, line formation, giving the ships of the line their name, just  firing upon the other fleet, watching the smoke build up more and more as the battle goes on. The sounds of the cannons echoing over the ocean, and then the cracking and splintering of wood as the cannons impact the hull of the ship, with little pieces flying all over and landing in the water.Apart from that, there is also the open world, which allows trading, exploring, sinking pirates, the usual stuff one would expect from a naval open world game. The time is sped up in the open world, but the travelling time is somewhat realistic, with the carribean area being very detailed in terms of islands and nations.Would I recommend this game? Definitely, it's not finished yet, early access and all,  there are still a lot of missing features, especially in regards to the open world, but the game already brought me so much delight, that I definitely got my money's worth.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2016
Early Access Review
								I loved this game when i originally bought it but unfortunately in its current state i cannot reccomend it. I tried it with friend after they added the open world and unfortunately it doesnt work. When the game was originally released it was a world of warships style battle game set in the age of sail but then they decided (on a whim it would seem) to switch it into an open world game. Unfortunately this led to the game feeling completely incomplete and a unfocused. They need to rediscover what made  this game great and focus on that. Currently you gain 4xp for a battle (which the community says is the best way to level up) but that 4 xp counts towards the 500xp needed to level up. All of the big ships require a huge crew and you only get bigger crews through leveling up.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								its a great game and is very addicting, but there are issues and yes its an alpha but these need to be addressed now before its a full game. 1.) the aiming- the aiming is terrible, i cant find out where to aim with it, its a thin red or white line when i aim at the enemy ship, the cannons fly right over the ship when i aim at the water it shoots to low. its just very annoying and needs to be fixed and updated. 2.) the map- the map is very little help as all it does show the land masses and how big the map is, BUT THERE IS NO INDICATOR OF WHERE YOU ARE AT, NO ARROW OR DOT OR LINES OF TRAVEL. now its realistic but i think for players sanity of finding out where to go needs to be updated. 3.) now if you like it hardcore then skip this if you do. you pay alot for your ships then they sink 5 times thats it, its gone, you can of course buy repair kits for nearly 3000 gold for each on a 5th rate, i get it but the price of ships need to be lower abit for that (FYI there are 7 rates and a 5th rate can cost up to 150000 gold and there are limited numbers of ships that can be bought in the port so you might not see the ship you want avalible). NOW that is out of the way the goods. its a very realitic game though the ai is stupid but i wish you could walk on your ship but I cant deny i put hours into this game. the level up is a bit weird but you will understand it later and for an very new alpha it has alot of potental to be one of the best games ever. big open world sailing on your own vessal the size of the HMS VICTORY is pretty cool i think. and there are plenty of nations to choose to be, even a pirate. plenty of varity of ships as well so i still recommend it and support this amazing game just a few errors but its new i'll cut it some slack. NOW THEN YA LANDLUBBERS, SEE YA AT SEA. SET SAIL, HOIST THE ANCHORS, DOUSE THE ROYALS

content:
Posted: May 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								=== More Complete Than A Lot of Recent AAA's === Does Combat for the Era Justice ===Even for an Early Access review, I can definitely recommend this game. It does naval battles very well, but it also does an open, real time world very well too. The game has plenty of content in terms of both progression and exploration. The world is huge. It sort of simulates a live economy of goods and services. There's also almost a dozen factions/countries with a pretty decent community so far.The game plays well and looks good. There are a ton of 'Pros'. The only two 'Cons' is that it's a massive time Vampire and there are a couple of bugs that are super annoying right now. I imagine the later will get fixed, but the first is going to be up to you. It's all multiplayer and getting together with friends is easy, fun, and fairly balanced. I wouldn't say it's dependant on playing with friends, too; it's got plenty of content.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								Outstanding game so far. Naval Action captures the difficulty, chaos, and terror of naval combat unlike any other game since Silent Hunter III. Its open world is influenced heavily by EVE Online and Mount & Blade, and while systems are rudimentary, they are all in tact and functioning. The size of the world is truly impressive -- the entire Caribbean, modelled precisely. It takes about 3 real-life hours to cross the map, if you have the wind... The political system is very intriguing and already shaky alliances have formed between certain nations. Gameplay is remarkably tight for an early access title -- I have encountered literally no bugs, glitches, freezes, etc. The combat is difficult but accessible for new players, and the graphic fidelity in the battles is basically AAA quality -- think a cross between Wargame: Airland Battle and World of Warships at max settings but with MUCH better ocean, sound and smoke effects. Ships are modelled in much more clarity and detail than WoWS and waves and storms can dramatically influence battles. This game needs more press and exposure. I've played every major war game, sim, etc., and Naval Action is the most promising I've played in a long time. Is it worth $40? Absolutely. The test UI is clunky and certain features need iteration, but the game is pretty much there and without the glitchy nonsense that afflicts most Early Access titles. This is 100% more polished than Day Z SA.

content:

Early Access Review
								Great game, no silver spoon, a lot of skill required to be competitive, skill can trump gear and ship classes, ai is decent and consently being improved, but pvp is where the game shines.If you like eve online, slower pace and 18th cenutry naval era then this is a perfect game, it is still in development, devs active on the forums discussions and you can give them feedback and suggestions on how to improve the game.Its not a game that will reward you instantly (other than achieving something) do not expect to sail the biggest ships within the first week or within the first month.  Heck it might even take you a few tries to sink or capture your first ship, but once you start learning about the combat mechanics you will get better and better and on your way to gain more crew and the ability to man bigger ships and learn how to sail those.Definitly worth the price.

But i escaped and am now living in bosnia herzegovina in disguise as an elderly hunter with down syndrom living out in the forrest, I have made friends with some of the local squirrels after I caught them nawing my testicles off of me.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								picked this game up after watching a streamer play it for a few hours. as a fresh account not knowing how to play the community picked me up and took me for a ride (pirate faction). they helped me level up by backing me up against AI ships, coached me about the controls and even theory crafting about ships and loadouts for different roals. everyone was very nice.the game play is very fun you really feel like you are on the high seas. the open world is HUGE and player driven economy and port's can be captured by nations, that is the big pvp stuff.if you are on the fence about it, i think it is a great choice to just go ahead and give it a try. join a nation with a active community (better with friends)

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								Loving the game. Less than 12 hours in, the game is packed full of action and adventure. Not only that, but it's actually the best Age of Sail game I've ever seen. Literally. Early Access truly does not exist to these developers in their dictionaries. They have dedicated their time to make one of the best games in the Naval category. After starting as a basic cutter, you progress through the ranks of your nation (or "pirate nation") and end up being a First Rate ship of the line*. During this time you'll experience friendships, hardships, fun, and other emotions. But in the end, you love the game and enjoy the work you've taken in over the time of such. You learned how to trade, how to fight, and how to ship as a naval captain.  If you want to play a game filled with adventure, action, the sea, and naval combat, then this is the right game for you. Maybe you just want something to waste your time on? Then this is your game. I recommend purchasing this game in Early Access for multiple reasons that are too much to explain on this. In other words, you'll have a great time with this title.*I do not currently own a 1st Rate ship. I am merely only giving you an example.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								One of the best early access games I have ever played.I encountered like 2 or 3 little bugs in more than 40 hours playing it. If you disable anti aliasing (currently drops FPS into nowhere) you get a great performance even with lots of ships in a battle.The servers never crashed so far and the ping was always around 20-30ms. No lag at all.The game itself is great so far. There is a lot of content for an early access game and you can do a lot of things from piracy over crafting huge ships to run missions or hunt hostile fleets (NPC and players).The ships are very balanced and every ship has it's own advantages and disadvantages compared to others of the same class.The NPCs you will mostly fight will get better if you climb up ranks and you will have a hard challenge every now and then.If you like a rather slow combat style, ships, open world and a ton of cannons - this game might be something for you.The game has a lot of potential and I'm sure the devs will know how to make use of it. I cleary recommend the game and I would pay the 37€ again.

Early Access Review
								Get this game. This is a very good game. Though it takes some time to get gold and ships do cost a lot... This game is still in development and I would strongly recommend you trying this game out if you are into a very realistic sailing simulator set arround the pirate age. I love the combat in this game and I hope they will add different maps and reigions to the game, also lowering ship costs in the game might make it easier and more fun to play. So it definately still needs some big changes to be made. There are only a few ships affordable (easy to get with the amount of gold you earn in each battle) are only a few.  I think this is a game that really shows off the "Age of sail" and at the moment I give it a 8.9/10 since it still is in alpha stage and I personally think that there are quite a few improvements to be made and many things to be added. Though afterall this is still in alpha.

Early Access Review
								Okay so for start...Yes you are right this is a high price for an early acces game.......But it's worth it because there is no other game I know that has really awsome good old fashion sailing battles like this game.Cannonshots roar out, smoke fills the horizon  you see wood chips fly of  enemy ship's sails tear and masts break.the combat is so good it makes all other naval games  look like bad april fools jokes.Navigating in the vast open world can be a challange cause you only have a map and a compass to guide you with no fake location marker so yopu have to look for land marks and plot course aheadYes it's alpha the menu's in harbours are crude and the trading is kinda bare bone now but I have a feeling this will all shape up in the upcomming months.Also note worthy is that the coop with friends works really well.I hope many many more will take the risk jump in and suport this game casue it's one unique gaming experience

content:
Posted: March 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								Very realistic game, it's a complete naval simulator. During the battles you must consider the wind direction, take care of the orientation of your sails to turn correctly.During this beta period the developers are taking so much care about the community asking about the continuous development of the game, for example; I'm playing in the Spanish faction which have some problems with port capture balance, but nowadays the developers ask the community to try to solve them correctly and make the game more competitive and more balanced.Trade system seem a bit simple nowadays although factions have to take care of their ports because ports:-Demand Material, and Produce materiales, some of the materiales produced are needed for the boat craft system.The game is so perfect in the small details in the boats, that is incredible to believe.Soon is a new actualization with more new content.If you like the naval simulation, you'll enjoy the game for sure.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								Wow! So for early access this game would be great as if they did nothing else! Very suprised at the game mechanics, graphics, MMO fluidity, and trading system. So what for some of the positives:1) Easy Chat for Nation, global or learning.2) Smooth Battle sequences and transition into them.3) something fo reveryone - if trade is your thing, trade. Craft - craft. Fighting - well you have to learn to sail and battle on the high seas, if not you losse your neck to the enemy or pirates!4) Graphics are amazing.5) The world is vast and based in some of the natural history (although many liberties taken). If you want to sail all over, make new warehouse and dock at ports, expect to have the realism and time invested in doing so. At first I didnt like this aspect, but now after playing hours upon hours I respect it.6) Potential. Even though this game is great as is - it has great potential to go in many directions.7) Action. There is down time in the game - but if you want action it can be found almost anywhere on the seas.Some negative points:1) Hard learning curve at first. If your not dedicated, I could see where you would easily give up. It would be nice to have a tutorial or two for the new gamer coming into the world. So often on the chat I see, "So what do I do - Im new?"2) Action will get old - and so will crafting  at a certain point. Although the ship production line is quite extensive, it would be nice to open the ports, towns, and overall system to incude other aspects such as food, living quarters in town, explorations, and aging of ships just to mention some ideas.3) Capture and boarding of ships also gets old, would be nice to see something in the way of diplomatic surrenders like, "If you stop shooting at me ill give you half my cargo!"So I hoped this helped. Alot of hours in before writing review, and Ive enjoyed this game immensly! Cheers!

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								Im not going to explain in depth what the game has to offer. Plenty of others better at this game than me have done that. What I can say and assure you is that you will get your moneys worth. For an early access game this is very solid. To me it seems they nailed the ships, fighting, sailingmechanics and left things like the ui to be worked on and other things too of course. But making what has to do with ships spot on before release makes it a very enjoyable early access. The game doesnt seem to suffer from having an application run on the side like spotify or mediaplayer playing music (movie music in my case to enhance the atmosphere). Sailing isnt just turning left or right as you will find out. You can change to manual skipper that makes you control the trim of the sails and make much sharper turns but it will take some training to get it right. I hate to buy games that makes me feel dissapointed but this game Im glad i purchased.

content:
Posted: February 11
Early Access Review
								Naval Action is a very short indie title about a man waiting for his ship to arrive and I ♥♥♥♥ing hated it.The main reason I hated this game was mainly due to the usual false expectations scenario. Rather than just completely rip this game apart let me explain what I thought the game was going to be, and then what the game actually is.What I thought Naval Action was going to be:Everything I thought this game was going to be came from what people posted about on the internet. Nothing I am writing in this section is what I hoped the game would be, this is what I expected based on others experiences with it. Like I mentioned above, this is a game about a man waiting for his ship to arrive at his house. However, I was under the assumption that this would be 1st person, without any narration, and you are completely free to do whatever you want while you wait for the ship. You do not know what ship class it is, or why this man is possibly being stood up. Maybe this is him being dumped, maybe he destroyed it, maybe he doesn’t have a ship and he’s lonely, we just don’t know. While waiting for your possible ship to arrive, you are free to do whatever you want in your apartment. Doing actions will affect the outcome of the ship’s quality. Maybe you could eat your entire meal before it shows up, would that have an effect? Maybe if you drink the whole bottle of wine you will pass out and miss the ship entirely, never knowing if the vessel came by or not. Maybe you could just sit there and wait the entire time, twiddling your thumbs, eagerly watching the clock. Maybe you could just ♥♥♥♥ing kill yourself, the point is what sold me on this game was mystery. Every time I looked into this game online, for whatever reason, the game was completely shrouded in mystery, and this made me want to play the game so badly. I was honestly expecting to play this game multiple times just to see what else I could make happen. There could’ve been so many possibilities, so many outcomes, but as you can guess I ended up being tremendously disappointed.What Naval Action actually is:A monologue. The game is literally just a monologue disguised as a video game. If there are any David Cage fanboys reading this, buy this game right now. NOTHING you do while you “wait” for your ship matters. I only played this game once and I went in with the intention of killing my character through alcohol abuse, but even though I am drinking down a glass of wine every 5 seconds, the character doesn’t shut up…even while he is drinking. You are forced to listen to this guy whine and complain and there’s nothing you can do about it. Yeah, there are actions, but they are ♥♥♥♥ing meaningless. I’m pretty sure if someone smoked 47 cigarettes in a row he would maybe cough a few times in the middle of his ♥♥♥♥♥ing. The game kept giving me hope that something good would happen. Oh look! He’s getting up! Can I jump out the window? Nope. Can I open my fridge? Nope. Well, can I grab that endless bottle of rum again? Not right now, nope. When I realized that I could just sit back and the game would play itself I decided to stick through to the end, with the hope that maybe something interesting would happen, but of course not. You listen to this guy whine and complain about life for awhile and then that’s it, it just ends. He doesn’t kill himself (sadly), the ship never shows up, nothing ♥♥♥♥ing happens. The best part about the uh experience is the torture is short. My game time for this is 23 minutes and I waiting till the credits ended.So that’s it, I can’t even recommend this game to people who enjoy monologues, or hearing sad..ish life stories. Rather that waste your time listening to this guys issue’s you could go hang out with your friends, and maybe help them with their problems. I can promise in that situation different outcomes and functionality that makes an impact, I dare you to try and drink as much wine as I did in this game while hearing your friend talk. In other words, real life is more of a video game than Naval Action.

content:
Posted: September 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								I love Pirates, and to a lesser extent general caribbean naval stuff.  I also love story and adventure and in that aspect the game falls just a little short, not of what it's trying to be, just what I wanted watching early Dev diaries.  Maybe the features to craft your own story (or even have a visible or defined character-there are no RPG elements) will come in the future but im not sure that's really what the developer is interested in.And that's okay!  As a naval combat simulation alone Naval Action is fantastic.  It's gorgeous, detailed, more realistic than anything I've seen and hopping on with a friend to hunt some french merchantmen is a blast.  It has massive PvP with dynamic ownership of ports between the many belligerent Powers and a decent trading system which may be far deeper than I've seen so far and rewards planning and being in touch with the community to know goods prices in your next port.In short although Naval Action isn't everything I want in a Carribean Adventure it's EXACTLY what IT wants to be.  If you understand what you're getting I highly recommend.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								I really, really, really, really want to love this game. I still have my hopes for it and will keep playing. I would'nt recommend the game at the moment unless you like seeing a gem of a game get developed before your eyes. The game lacks excitement but has tons of potential. The missions are tedious after a while but are unfortunately the only good way of making money and xp. Otherwise, esecially at the beginning, you are attacking traders and making some money and xp. IF the devs have done one good thing its the ship mechanics. They remind me somewhat of Assassin's Creed Black Flag. All they need to do no is provide a arena mode were you will earn money and xp when its done. Like Overwatch. Then when your not in the arena mode and are waiting for a game, your out doing those missions i was talking about as well as attacking traders and ships from other nations. It would then be my idea of the perfect game.

								Wow! So for early access this game would be great as if they did nothing else! Very suprised at the game mechanics, graphics, MMO fluidity, and trading system. So what for some of the positives:1) Easy Chat for Nation, global or learning.2) Smooth Battle sequences and transition into them.3) something fo reveryone - if trade is your thing, trade. Craft - craft. Fighting - well you have to learn to sail and battle on the high seas, if not you losse your neck to the enemy or pirates!4) Graphics are amazing.5) The world is vast and based in some of the natural history (although many liberties taken). If you want to sail all over, make new warehouse and dock at ports, expect to have the realism and time invested in doing so. At first I didnt like this aspect, but now after playing hours upon hours I respect it.6) Potential. Even though this game is great as is - it has great potential to go in many directions.7) Action. There is down time in the game - but if you want action it can be found almost anywhere on the seas.Some negative points:1) Hard learning curve at first. If your not dedicated, I could see where you would easily give up. It would be nice to have a tutorial or two for the new gamer coming into the world. So often on the chat I see, "So what do I do - Im new?"2) Action will get old - and so will crafting  at a certain point. Although the ship production line is quite extensive, it would be nice to open the ports, towns, and overall system to incude other aspects such as food, living quarters in town, explorations, and aging of ships just to mention some ideas.3) Capture and boarding of ships also gets old, would be nice to see something in the way of diplomatic surrenders like, "If you stop shooting at me ill give you half my cargo!"So I hoped this helped. Alot of hours in before writing review, and Ive enjoyed this game immensly! Cheers!

content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								I have bought this game when it was in very early Alpha access and only the combat testing, called Sea Trials was available. I am involved in the development process of this game for more than a year now.From the start, I was very impressed by what the Developers want to create here. And that with a quite small team of developers.Sure,there are some bugs and the game still isnt completely finished (for example there is close to no GUI for the Harbors), but you can see the effort which is put into developing the game. And the progress is also visible. This is no game, which might end up not getting developed further. For more than a year I could follow the development progress and see first hand, that tester suggestions are taken seriously and often even get implemented into the game.The game has absolutly great sailing and gunnery physics and its a blast to sail around in the caribbean with some friends, searching for enemy fleets to destroy. Or prepare and execute a port assault together to get access to additional ressources for your faction.So if you are at all interested into the Age of Sail, this game is YOUR game. Buy it!in short:Great:Ship sailingGunneryModels of the shipsreally big Open worldBattles for control over the various portsGood:Rank progressionchoice of shipsnot so good:Missions (there are missions, but they are repetitive and kinda meh)GUI ( the GUI for the harbors for example is not yet really implemented, but they are working on it)Trading (work in progress)Crafting (work in progress)bad:no tutorial at allI could write much more about this great game, but I think this is enough to get a first impression about wether this game might be something for you. I#ll update this review in case something major changes.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is great. That is, it was great, before they introduced the Open World Aspect. I loved the PvP Skirmish games, slowly upgrading my ship to the next size, battling it out in long slug fests, or sniping each other from across the map. It was great, it felt great.That combat is still here, sadly it is now hidden behind an almost impenetrable wall of barely functional UI's, bland, empty Open World Elements, and a dull, pointless grind back to the larger ships I know and loved playing in.The Open World Aspect is bare bones to say the least, and far from finished, so there is plenty to improve on, especially the UI, which even when it was just skirmish mode wasn't particularly great, but it didn't need to be.I wish they gave you the option for either Open World or Skirmish, so I could still enjoy the combat, while waiting out the Dev's improvements upon the Open World Aspects.There is no tutorial for the Open World mode (There wasn't for the combat either, but it was easy enough to pick up), it literally just thrusts you into a menu, and lets you fumble it out for yourself. After 10 minutes of faffing around, I got to 'sail', which is just a fancy word for "Point your ship in a direction, and look around for things to do" You can choose to battle ships that you see about, but 9 times out of ten, you won't see anything your 'level' anywhere. All I saw for an hour were Snows or Larger ships, which made easy pickings of my Cutter. The little battles that pop up here and there, are either 'closed' or spawn you so far from the action that you can't hope to get more than a few shots in.Since the Open World side of things was introduced, I have barely been able to play it for more than an hour at a time, eventually returning to see what has changed, to find nothing at all different about my experience.Before that, the game was fantastic. Brilliant combat, and a real intense atmosphere when you get into a full blown fight.I recommend it on the combat alone. If you can put up with a rather dull and frustrating grind, this may be for you, in its current state. I just wish we had the option to skirmish.Edit: Tried to play again more recently. Had some free money and a ship to play with. Sadly I didn't have the rank to have the crew with which to crew the ship effectively. Rendering it pointless. And ranking up? You need to grind missions. And missions? Long dull trip to point A. Wait for ship to appear you are allowed to fight. Hope you can kill it before it either A: runs, B: outruns you, or C: Kicks your butt.If you win, you get a bit of gold, about 50xp towards your goal of 500xp for your First Rank. Of which there are many, with ever increasing xp requirements.I tried again to play this, and again, it just isn't fun anymore. Its a whole lot of waiting  for your ship to eventually reach a point, and once they get there, hope you can get a /little/ bit of "Naval Action" in. I wish the AI was a bit more aggressive. Usually it either just runs, even when it has a much better ship than me, or it goes in annoying circles, that benefit nothing but time wasting.There is a mission system now however (Essentially skirmish), but every time I've played, I've been put up against a much larger ship. I haven't advanced out of the cutter yet, but I'm being put up against 64 Gun vessels or worse, on my own. WTF?

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								If your looking for something different, then this could be it. PRO'sStunningly beautiful graphics, when in battle. Large open world Seems to attract more mature players. (Maybe not enough instant gratification for younger players)Lots of helpful players available online during the gameMany different aspects to the game, sailing, trading, crafting, building ships, upgrades and of course brilliant battles.Great deal of hard work from the developers with lots of regular updates and improvements to game playRewards skill and effortNo obvious hacking or cheats in the game that I have seen or heard of, though there have been some exploits that have been taken advantage of.CONSNo manual. Very confusing for beginners, initially.A lot of the online info is wrong / out of date due to game changes by the developersRequires considerable player effort to understand and enjoy - but this will be a positive factor for manyUI crude but works well enough, even if its a bit vague and confusing at the moment. This is due to be updated.SUMMERYThis is an Early Access game, but far more developed and playable than most. It has  (FEB 2016) strong support from the team. This has the potential, to be something very special. Nothing like the satisfaction of out maneuvering and out shooting an enemy. And nothing quite as humiliating as sinking after a heavy defeat, or seeing your crew decimated prior to being boarded. A recent update from the developers said they feel the mechanics are near right now and they will concentrate on added improvements to game content. Guess this means the UI in particular and general polishing.But if your considering buying the game, do be prepared for some serious searching for info in the early stages!Would sink again. 8/10 at the moment. Potential 10/10.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								Already a heap load of fun, this game has bags of potential and will only get better and better.It IS early access, but well worth the money in my opinion. The developers are working hard and patches/hotfixes are frequent.Currently the UI is placeholder and well below standard, but it's functional at least. The game itself, the ships and the scenery are looking lovely though and it really captures the feeling of being in a sea battle.The community tends to be very mature. Use of voice comms is frequent and large clans are organising for massive fleet battles on a daily basis but it's still very possible for you to solo if you are that way inclined. Some work needs to be done to balance the gold income here and there but that'll come in time.There is currently next to no help ingame, but there is an unofficial wiki and a help chat channel in which people are more than pleased to provide answers.On the whole, I'd wholeheartedly recommend this game as long as people understand that they really are buying a game that is (heavily) in development. I have no doubt that this game will see full release, the developers are excellent and the communication with the community is top notch.Finally a game that is going to give Early Access a good name.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								Great game that captures the challenges of the era. To start the game it is advisable to at least grasp the basics of sailing (with wind and sails only), once you have that part down the learning curve turns to gunnery and aiming given the available technologies during the 1700-1800s pre motorization area. If you decide to progress further crafting or building ships is also available which will challenge your abilities even moore. This game has a variety of ways to challenge the most ardent sailing-battle fan. Finally missions both individual or multiplayer are also available from beginner to advanced, but beware you may get sunk and returned to port without a boat and have to sail the lowly Cutter back home. Highly recommended.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								In a nutshell: The game is currently building its already solid foundation in Alpha testing.Ships traverse an overworld with sped up movement, similar to mount and blade. Combat occurs when a ship chooses to attack you (and attempts to keep you within a certain radius of his ship in a circular ring), or when you choose to enter an instanced event/mission/battle area.Combat involves sailing around and attempting to blast your enemy to bits before he blasts you. Ships have somewhat realistic damage models and can take hits on different sides. Leaks, fires, loss of crew will all act to the detriment of the ship. You manage crew and can select what tasks you want them to focus on. At the moment this is the most complete aspect of the game.Ships and assets can be crafted, but ships may also be captured via boarding (where you manage crew in a rock paper scissors type minigame and attempt to reduce enemy crewcount or morale to 0). Ships sunk will lose a count of durability. Crafted ships will have up to 5 "lives," captured ships or the more powerful first rate ships will only have one.Servers are PvE or PvP (other players may attack you in the overworld). The most active server is PVP1 for the EU.You may also attempt to capture ports in special port battles, and secure a port for use by your own nation. Ports have hard hitting artillery fortifications. You will need a group to attack and defend ports.Progression is centered on the aquisition of experience, money, and assets. You can obtain money and assets through trade, crafting, or combat solo or in a group, and xp through combat.Nations are entities which can take and hold ports. You select a nation at character creation, and nations will act hostile to all but themselves (player driven diplomacy is currentlg the only diplomacy in game). Pirates function like a nation, but can attack other pirates as well.PvE exists as NPC ships in missions, events, or fleets in the overworld.The UI is barebones and there is little to no official documentation or tutorial to the game.Don't forget that its early access.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								I will rate this game 6/10.This game have good graphics and solid gameplay in terms of naval combat in the Age of Sail genre. Actually the best what you can find and thus it is the reason why I purchase it.I can't give it full points, despite the only game in its  genre fulfulling all the mechanics and solid, smooth gameplay. This game is extremely time consuming. Prepare to have a book while playing this game, because it is very slow paced. The naval battles are fine, but the Open World experience is something most people want to be revamped.There are numerous other reasons why this game doesn't favour casual gamers and is more geared towards hardcore gamers. It is time consuming, limited features in economy which could be improved upon, time consuming and long distances to sail. Expect to spend more or less an hour in the Open World before arriving at a certain port or battle location.Also note the devs are a small group and take very long to implement updates. An update each month and then patches in the upcoming weeks. Much more could be desired and feedback is only considered from hardcore longtime standing players, making it difficult for new casual gamers to fit in.Good graphics, solid gameplay, but favour too much to hardcore gamers, bland economy and time consuming. 6/10.EDIT: I change the downvote to an upvote, all the above still applies, but the recent patches make the game more interesting and the introduction of alliances certainly changes a lot of things. I hope the economy can be addressed and then I might change my review completely.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								Set in the age of sail, Naval Action has a big learning curve. With no in game tutorial working out what you need to do and how to even play the game can be very difficult, however once you final figure it out, it's very rewarding. The map and ships are beautifully done, you can easly get distracted looking around. There is no in game navigating in a sence, however there is a map and compass so it's back to basics with working out where you need to go and how to get there. it can take some time looking for the start points for missions. However I feel it adds to the overall feel and look of the game, however I feel that by adding a sextant or even the ablity to navigate using the star's will make for much better immersion. Sailing the ships is easy, but as you progress up to much bigger ship's a sailing tutorial would be benefitual. There are video's on YouTube showing how to use the sails and these would be worth a watch if starting out. Overall I feel this game has great potential and if the devs continue in the direction they are heading I believe it will will be a fantastic game once fully finished, with the possibility of adding more maps to the game or even expanding the current in game map there will be no shortage of content.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								A well thought out simulation of 'blue water' sailing of ships of the "Wooden Ships and Iron Men" era popularized in the Hornblower and Aubrey/Maturin novels and films, this provides the Player with the ability to captain his/her own trade ship or warship sailing and trading between ports or engaging in realistic ship-to-ship combat.  Both one-to-one, fleet-to-fleet, and Player-to-Player combat is enabled in the PvP version. The game map is extensive, and includes all of the east coast of the Americas, the Gulf of Mexico and the Carribbean Sea.  One sails seamlessly over the entire map, encountering trading vessels and warships, some operated by other human Players, others by AI Non-Player-Characters.  In the "PvP" version, one is enabled to attack or be attacked by other Human Players from opposing national factions, or by the ever-threatening Pirate faction.  The trading simulation provides an economic model that enables the human player to earn money without fighting, or to win game money, Experience Points toward promotion (and larger, more powerful ships), and seize ships and cargo from adverse faction ships as prizes.  The game requires some patience, some understanding of the interaction between sails, wind and simple 'dead reckoning' navigaton.   A rewarding experience for those seeking some taste of what it was like circa 1800 in a warship or trading vessel going in harms way for the chance of adventure and gold.  Highly recommended.

number of helpful: 23 of 48 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								I recommend playing less than 2 hours and then having a good long think about what you just paid $40 for.Some major cons for me.UI is a shambles, and while it does say ignore the UI in the UI that doesn't help much.It's $40 and it is not even close to being worth it. I'm all for supporting a developer, I bought this with a friend, that's $80 that we both ended up getting a refund for. Had it been $20, I would have kept it and just hoped it got better. Took it as it is, a fun little sea battle game.Very little in the game helps you along, and my first battle lasted about 40 minutes 1 on 1. It was painfully slow and I had no idea what I was doing. I'm genuinely shocked at the "Very positive" reviews.Dislike the crewing of my crappy little tub, my guys just kinda did repetative things and when I had less crew than it said I had I am pretty sure I counted them all still there. That spoiled the immersion for me, it was dissapointing.YES, IT IS EARLY ACCESS!I know this, but I did expect more because the price they are asking.Take a page out of WarThunders book, have a physics system that you can see. If I broadside a ship I want to see bits of railings fly off because a ball flew through it, and those railings stay gone. I want to hit a sailor with a grape shot and see him DIE or get flung overboard. I want to see crew scurrying around doing things that makes me feel like I have an actual crew I give a♥♥♥♥♥♥about.*Edit* I stated earlier that I was with a friend, I could not find any way to group or locate or play with that person, I just happened to be playing the same game as him. We got in a sea battle together and ended up on opposite sides. That was the deal breaker for us. *Edit*That said, there are not many naval games out there, and I did enjoy the second battle which was a mass of ships, I had no idea what I was doing but I shot things and made holes in sails.The graphics are really nice and you can make some lovely cinematic stills, but uh.. you didn't pay $40 for cinematic stills did you now?End of the day, I'll follow this game and keep it on my wishlist for a future sale that is AT LEAST 50% off.Be warned guys, don;t let your desperation for some old timey naval combat get the better of you and part with your money because♥♥♥♥♥♥like this is part of the problem with the industry (that and microtransactions on full price games).

content:
Posted: March 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								Basically it's a nice game, and I want to play it for a longer time... but....   Once I'm logged into it I already feel bored and immediately log out.Why ? ...   Let me tell you some things you might need to know before purchasing it:Pros: + pretty neat interface while being on the ship, easy to understand + the first thing you'll notice are the waves. the water is so realistic to watch.. and even more realistic during battles, where u'll have more details+ steering a ship is fun too, there are a great variety of ships you can purchase during the game with many upgrades and different looks+ mixing a ship simulator with an mmo is a cool idea too+ you can be dutch, danish, sverige, american, british, french, spanish or join the pirates, which is the only faction who can attack eachother.+ day/night cyclusCons:- the waves could be much bigger at the sea- as nice as the UI is while outside on the sea, once you are in a Harbour/Port/Outpost the UI is big and confusing.- You gain 50 ish xp for a successfull mission in Level 1, and not more. You need 1000xp to Level 2 = Pure Mission Grinding!- There ain't alternatives to grinding missions, but to attack players of other countries, which you shouldn't do in early levels anyway, cause you have no effin chanceSo if you don't have mates to help you out in those missions wich are 1vs1 battles against AI Ships and 50% of them will destroy you in the beginning, you have a problem- one of those missions ( 1vs1 battles ) will last for 30minutes or longer until finally a ship is destroyed and will sink, whether its yours or the AI ship.- there are only 3 things to do in this game: missions ( which are always the same procedure ), pvp battles ( will be interesting in higher levels / you can attack Harbours too ) or you can just farm Gold by buying and selling goods in different Ports, but you cant gain xp from that and there ain't trading quests yet. If you decide to farm Gold first, you might be able to puchase bigger ships, but bigger ships need a bigger crew, and the amount of crewmember will increase with your rank/level only! so don't even think about joining a battle with a ship that needs 150+ crew and you only got your 40 member in level 1. Cannon reloadtimers will increase drastically, your turning and steering will be horrible, and you can't even manage to repair it either.So.. if you're already a fan of ships , especially old ones and don't care about the difficulties during the game, get it and travel the carribean sea! Otherwise, give it a couple more months and check if they added more content.Also feel free to check out my screenshots if you're interested.

number of helpful: 16 of 34 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								At this point and time I can in no way recommend this seemingly nice game. Here is why: First of all, the UI is absolutely horrible, and in addition, from what I gather through forum posts and the like, the devs do not intent to enhance it, or at least make it half way decent, in any way shape or form in the near future.Secondly the graphics. Played on ultra, with everything turned up, the game is still rough around the edges. For example, ropes on the ship are being formed in lines, even with AA turned to max, the contact of the ship with the water is in no way smooth, the vegetation on the islands contains very rough models, and suffers from similar AA problems, and the lighting/shading, is not remarkable either. Combine that with the fact that all you 'll be looking at in this game, are the above mentioned ship, islands and sea, the game is certainly no eye-candy at this point, for me at least. Whether the developers intend to enhance the graphics remains to be seen. Thirdly immersion. Having to go through loading screen after loading screen, even to engage enemy ships at sea, just totaly breaks immersion. I can understand, and forgive, a loading screen here and there, maybe when you enter major ports, but not when they litteraly precede every enemy encounter. Further more, when not engaged in combat, the ship seemingly runs itself, with not crew on deck, as if it was a ghost ship. Not only that, but even when you do get to see the crew, which is only in enemy engagements, the crew is poorly animated, and they do not even engage in activities around the ship, either following your orders, or passivly. They have only 1 animation ,which is to inspect the cannon, and even that is terribly done. This lack of the human factor is also present at ports, that look abandoned as a direct result of this. I really hope the developers do try and amend these issues someday.Moving on, perhaps the most awful thing about the game at this point, and something that I am afraid will not be changing, ever, is the grind. Going by reports in forums, and videos, along as with what little I could gather from struggling to understand the menu, the grind is horrendously long, even to match that of free-to-play MMOs. Difference is, I can understand why F2P MMOs need the grind, which is to generate income from people skipping said grind. But in a game you pay 40 dollars for, such a long grind is to my eyes completely unacceptable. Sure, im all for not giving everything away at once, but the system going at this point is just off the charts.On a positive note, If the game has one redeeming vertue even at this point, it is that of the combat system. That is truly enjoyable, and the battles are truly engaging. It is however too, quite slow, which I personaly do not mind, however this might be a nuisance to some people. All in all, the game feels too rough, and too early in development right now, which is not inherently a bad thing, but when the developers are asking a whooping 40 dollar fee, for this unfinished alpha, that you are going to be testing for them for free to boot, I can not, sanely recommend it. If the game gets patched up in the future, or if the developers realize they are asking too much for a game miles from being complete, and change the price, then I might come to recommend it. Until then, stear clear from this one.

								alright, in the beginning i was really drawn to this game, time period, the gun powder all that, that is why i bought it when it released.first of all, this game is NOT WORTH 37 euros, i can buy a triple A game for that money, so i EXPECT a good quality game with many features/ near finished. if its was like 10 to 15 euro range, i might gave it a thumbs up.Graphics 7/10the ships looks stunning. but the boat that you start out with, not so much. the big boates look amazing.i also loved it when you are sailing and in the far distance you see towers of a city sticking out so you know you are almost home.islands itself are quite dull, and low res.in battle, the ocean is beatifully done. the ships movement, are very well donedont get me started about the ui, its bland, boring and not user friendly, but hey its alpha right?gameplay 5/10the only thing i liked was the 'naval action' for the rest it was boring as ♥♥♥♥. this aspect of the game is not for most people.(so not for me.) you go out in the ocean looking for fights, or get a contract to battle a ship 1vs1. buddies with you could help with this grindfest. Then in the ports you can select small boat battles, and big boat battles. this is where everyone is. and because everyone is in the ports money/xp farming, there is almost no one in the open seas. developers need to get rid of that, or lower the rewards for the pvp battles.Technical 9/10this games runs very well on my system, gtx970, intel core i7.frames are always at 60fps+only minor thing i have is the daily maintance, this is the first game i see that has this. and if you are immersed you have to port, and log out for this maintence, or else you could lose progress.Final 4/10its just below average for me. but if you REALLY like boat battles from this time piriod and have patience with grinding 10 hours for a bigger ship, then by all means buy it. but for 37 euros, i can buy a triple A game that is finished and gives me more gameplay and enjoyment.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								The good:Fantastic combat model (although somewhat flawed - see below)The bad:Grind, grind, grind (done to enable their pay2win plans)What do I mean by grind?  I've got 80 hours into the game, and I'm still sailing the starter ship.  Sure, I could be sailing the first square rigger (I just bought a snow), but why should I?  I'm almost broke, the starter ship is free, and I need to save for the next tier ship.  The system is broken.  XP is too slow (by about 4x) and gold is far too scarce.  People will say you can do it faster (and yes you can), but add in the reroll (because I picked France, and no one speaks English in chat), the failed try at trading (which is grindy), the aborted crafting try (which is grindy), and a days worth of exploring, and you are right at about 80 hours.  80 hours (probably closer to 70 due to idling).Still in the starter ship.Now, you will get many saying this isn't going to be pay to win.  Call it what you want, pay to play, play to win, pay to skip the grind - it's all semantics.  The people in denial are just trying to set up an MMO with an elite class of players (the ones willing to put tons and tons of time into repetitive missions), while the rest of us sit back and wish we were part of that elite class. Repetitive missions you say?  There's only ONE mission.  Sail out for 5 mins, kill the pirate (or pirates), sail back.  20  to 25 minutes total (if you know exactly what you are doing).  A resonable pace is 2 missions per hour.  At first, longer, and you will fail frequently.  You'll get about 90xp per mission (on your way to 1000xp for teir 2 - tier 3 another 1000, teir 4 another 3750).  You will need to get to tier 3 for your first significant ship upgrade, but you had better not been spending any gold.  You'll need every cent to buy and equip that next ship  (and after that, you won't want to sail it, because you wont want to lose it).  I like the difficulty - no complaints there.  Only problem - the grind. Rinse, repeat until you are numb.  Grind even more. Oh you can go after that unarmed trader instead for 40xp- what great excitement!  You could also play PvP for xp, which is much more interesting, but your xp rate/hour goes way down - and worst of all you will sink more often.  With anything but the free ship, sinking is expensive - so no more PvP for you!  Great design, huh?No thanks.  Save your money.  They make excuses  (it's an alpha!), well $40 sets a pretty high bar, unfinished or not.I should add, they will tell you that the Premium ships will only be cosmetic, but they are being dishonest. The Premium ships cannot be lost (but can be captured) (see source link below).The non-paying customers (I mean  the ones who refuse to pay more than the initial $40) get 5 sinkings per ship, then they are right back into the grind of paying for a new (expensive in terms of time) ship. That's the reason it's pay2win (or whatever you want to call it - semantics). The starter ship is free, so have fun with that, otherwise get your wallet out if you don't have hours and hours to play.A few more things...  Although the combat model is great, the AI cheats.  It has uncanny accuracy.  Devs say they won't tone it down because players eventually get good.  Well, this just punishes the new players.  And people don't actually get good at naval tactics.  They get good at learning to deal with a computer AI.  The technique of turning your bow or stern into an enemy to soak damage is almost laughable, and so unrealistic.  Oh, and the cannons are FAR too accurate.  Players are actually aiming for specific parts of the ships (trying to hit the masts, for example, or sneak a shot into the hull below the waterline).  For Pete's sake, these were smooth bore cannons on a very unstable platform!  Imagine you are on a real rocking ship, trying to time your shot with the rocking - you certainly aren't going to be aiming at the mast.  But in this game, no problem.  Shoot that mast clean off the ship if your aim is good enough (there's effectively a gyro stabilizer better than an M1 tank's in this game).  So if you are looking for realism, you won't find it here.For anyone considering this game, look at all those thumbs down.  This is an accurate review.  Those thumbs down show you the fan boys you'll be playing with - trying to dishonestly bury these facts.Dishonesty seems to be a theme with Naval Action.  Shame, shame, shame.*source of infinite durability (almost - ships cant be lost, but can be captured) - don't let anyone else say otherwise unless they give you a linkhttp://forum.game-labs.net/index.php?/topic/4668-open-world-prototype-rules-of-engagement-ship-loss-and-spawning/

content:
